name: QUEEN ALEXANDRA'S ROYAL NAVAL NURSING SERVICE (QARNNS)
description:
The memorial remembers all past and present nurses who have served with the Royal Navy

Records go back to 1884 but, in 1902, Queen Alexandra patronised the service and founded the QARNNs as we know



it today.

The QA's serve in most naval hospitals and shore establishment both at home and abroad, and during conflicts,



including both World Wars and the Falklands Conflict, they were to be found on board hospital ships caring for, and

bringing home, casualties.



The memorial is made of blue pearl granite, with matching benches flanked by a rowan tree, known as the healing

tree; its berries are used for medicinal purposes and the wood was used to make handles for stretches in WW1.

name: ARCTIC CONVOYS
description:
Arctic Convoys - Russian Convoys



This memorial of black Aberdeen granite was dedicated on 14 August 2012 in honour of all who sailed on the Arctic Convoys during

the Second World War.



The memorial’s inscription is engraved in both English and Russian.



Between June 1941 and May 1945, the United Kingdom supplied Russia with millions of tons of war-related goods. These convoys

were protected by Royal Navy ships of many types, with only 22 losses.



Men serving on these ships undertook this most hazardous journey through seas littered with floes and bergs with force nine and 11

winds whipping the seas into mountainous waves. It was always cold, both inside and out, with the permanent duty of ice breaking

from the superstructure to prevent them from capsizing and sinking.



The convoys suffered constant attack from the German Navy and Air Force from their safe ports in Norway. Winston Churchill called

it “The worst journey in the world”.



This is the only major memorial at the Arboretum paid for by one family: the Coyle Family. The adjacent tree is dedicated to Michael

Joseph Coyle who served on Royal Navy ships escorting the merchant vessels to Russian ports.



Millions of tons of war-related goods were supplied to Russia to help in their conflict against Germany. These supplies had to be carried

by sea to Archangel or Murmansk. The convoys of merchant ships had to be guarded by the Royal Navy from attack by German naval

and air forces. Weather conditions were usually very poor with frequent heavy seas and sub-zero temperatures. Winston Churchill

called it ‘The worst journey in the world.’ The laser-engraved main image shows a British warship navigating in a stormy sea. Also

shown are badges of the Arctic Convoy Club and the Russian Convoy Club. Script on the memorial is engraved in both English and

Russian.



The terms Russian Convoys or Murmansk Convoys could also be used for search purposes.



The Arctic convoys of WW2 sailed from the United Kingdom, Iceland, and North America to northern ports in the

Soviet Union – primarily Arkhangelsk (Archangel) and Murmansk.



There were 78 convoys between August 1941 and May 1945

About 1,400 merchant ships delivered essential supplies to the Soviet Union under the Anglo-Soviet agreement and



US Lend-Lease program, escorted by ships of the Royal Navy, Royal Canadian Navy and U.S. Navy

85 merchant vessels and 16 Royal Navy warships (two cruisers, six destroyers, eight other escort ships) were lost. Commented [PH1]: This appears to be from Wikipedia



and differs from what is quoted in the previous guidebook.

In some books the Arctic Convoys are referred to as the Russian Arctic Convoys or the Murmansk Run However, I have not been able to track down an alternative



source.



The Campaign



In response to the German invasion of the USSR on 21st June 1941 the British Government decided that help would be sent

to the USSR and on 12th July Rear-Admiral Philip Vian was ordered to report to London for instructions: he was to go to

Moscow, Polyarnoe and Archangel in order to make the arrangements for convoys to be received in Russia. Between 12th

August 1941 (Operation Dervish) and 30th May 1945 (Convoy RA67) convoys carried nearly 4 million tons of supplies to the

USSR in order to aid the Russian war effort. The Convoys sailed from Liverpool, Iceland or Loch Ewe in north-west Scotland

to the Russian ports of Murmansk and Archangel.



The majority of convoys took place in the winter months in order give cover of darkness: in the Arctic summer there would

have been 24 hours daylight. The weather was frequently dire with high seas, gale force winds and ice building up on the

upper works of vessels making them top heavy with the potential to capsize. It should be noted that any one falling into

the Arctic Water in winter would die of cold within minutes.



Each convoy had a close escort whose task was to protect the merchant vessels from U-boat and aircraft attack; in addition

there was a covering force of battleships and cruisers to provide additional protection if the Kriegsmarine’s large surface

vessels made an attack.



There were three notable battles within this campaign:-



The Tragedy of Convoy PQ17 - July 1942



Convoy PQ 17 suffered the worst losses of any convoy in the Second World War. The convoy had been sailing in good order

and had successfully beaten off attacks from German aircraft and U-boats when intelligence reached the Admiralty that a

German battle group headed by the battleship Tirpitz was about to sail from Altenfjord in northern Norway (Fall

Rösselsprung). The First Sea Lord Admiral Dudley Pound ordered the escorts to retire and the convoy to scatter. The German



battle group did not leave port until the following day, and was subsequently ordered to return to port, taking no part in

the sinking of the merchant ships.



Of the 37 ships which had sailed from Iceland 2 turned back, 8 were sunk by aircraft, 9 by U-boats and 7 by U-boats after

being damaged by aircraft. Only 11 of the 37 merchant ships in the convoy succeeded in reaching a Russian port. The lost

cargo included 430 tanks, 210 crated aircraft, 3350 vehicles and 99316 tons of general cargo. The Germans lost just 5

aircraft.



The Battle of the Barents Sea - 31st December 1942



On the evening of 30th December 1942 a German force, commanded by Admiral Kummetz, comprising the heavy cruisers

Hipper and Lutzow together with six destroyers sailed from Altenfjord on Fall Regenboden/Operation Rainbow. The

objectives were to intercept and destroy Convoy JW 51B and for Lutzow to break out on a commerce raiding cruise.



The British Force, commanded by Captain St Vincent Sherbrooke, comprised the destroyers Onslow, Orwell, Obedient and

Obdurate from the 17th Destroyer Flotilla, the destroyer HMS Achates and the minesweeper HMS Bramble: there were

further escorts but due to poor weather the previous day they had become detached and did not participate directly in the

battle. In addition there was a covering force (Force R- commanded by Rear Admiral Burnett) comprising the cruisers HMS

Jamaica and HMS Sheffield plus two destroyers. It should be noted that the German cruisers and destroyers were larger

and more powerful than their British opponents.



Every time the Admiral Hipper made an attack Captain Sherbrook responded by placing his vessels between the German

force and the convoy and because they were afraid of being torpedoed the German force retired. Despite HMS Onslow

being badly damaged and Captain Sherbrooke wounded this continued until Force R arrived.



By the end of the battle the British destroyer HMS Achates and the Minesweeper HMS Bramble were sunk together with

the German destroyer Friedrich Eckholt. The German force was forced to retire to port without damaging any of the

merchant ships and the plan for the breakout of the Lutzow for a commerce raiding cruise was abandoned.



The aftermath of the battle was that Captain Sherbrooke was awarded an immediate VC and the head of the German Navy,

Grand Admiral Raeder, resigned after being harangued by Hitler for over an hour.



The Battle of North Cape - 26th December 1943



On 20th December 1943 the 19 merchant vessels of Convoy JW 55B set sail from Loch Ewe and by Christmas day were

south of Bear Island. The German High Command decided to send out the battlecruiser Scharnhorst accompanied by five

destroyers to destroy the convoy: the battle group commanded by Rear Admiral Erich Bey departed Altenfjord at 17:00 on

Christmas Day.



Unknown to the Germans Admiral Sir Bruce Fraser (C in C Home Fleet) had placed two covering forces in the area. In the

morning of 26th December Scharnhorst encountered the British cruisers (Belfast, Norfolk and Sheffield), commanded by

Vice-Admiral R L Burnett, and had its forward radar destroyed. Scharnhorst one again tried to attack the convoy but ran

into the cruisers. The Scharnhorst headed south pursued by the cruisers. Meanwhile Admiral Fraser in the battleship HMS

Duke of York accompanied by HMS Jamaica and her escorts were racing to intercept. At 16:45 the Duke of York illuminated

the Scharnhorst by star shell and the final battle began. After the Scharnhorst had been pounded by the battleship and

cruisers and torpedoed by the destroyers she sank at about 19:45. Only 36 members of her crew were rescued from the

icy sea.



Admiral Fraser told his officers, ”I hope that if any of you are ever called upon to lead a ship into action against an opponent

many times superior, you will command your ship as gallantly as Scharnhorst was commanded today”.



This was the last time a British Battleship engaged in a battle with another capital ship.



The Tirpitz



The German battleship Tirpitz (42,900tons standard) with eight 380mm (15inch) guns was stationed throughout its career

in the Norwegian Fiords and was a threat to the convoys: this meant that each convoy had to have a powerful covering

force. There were many attempts to eliminate this threat.



Operation Source: September 1942 - the attack by midget submarines X5, X6 & X7 which damaged Tirpitz putting her under

repair until April 1944. Lt Donald Cameron (X6) and Lt Basil Place (X7) were awarded the VC.



Operation Tungsten: April 1944 – An attack by aircraft from HMS Victorious and HMS Furious escorted by two battleships

and five cruisers. Tirpitz was again damaged and put out of action until June.



Operation Goodwood: 29th August 1944 – There were four attacks from aircraft carriers that caused minor damage.



Operation Paravane: 15th September 1944 – 23 Lancaster bombers equipped with Tallboy bombs attacked the Tirpitz. One

bomb went through the forward part of the ship causing extensive damage. (The Tallboy was a 12,000 lb bomb designed

by Barnes Wallace)



Operation Obviate: 29th October 1944 – 32 Lancaster bombers (9 & 617 Squadrons) caused further damage.



Operation Catechism: 12th November 1944 – 32 Lancaster bombers (9 & 617 Squadrons) dropped 29 Tallboy bombs and

achieved 2 direct hits and a near miss; this caused the Tirpitz to turn over.



With the elimination of Tirpitz heavy units of the Royal Navy could be moved to the Pacific.



Convoy Data



Prior to the disaster of Convoy PQ17 in July 1942 the outbound convoys were prefixed PQ and the return convoys QP. After

PQ17 the outbound were prefixed JW and the return convoys RA. The total convoys for each year are shown in the following

table. The number of merchant vessels in each convoy varied significantly.

The Arctic Star



Participation in the Arctic Convoys was one of the WW2 Campaigns that had not entitled participants to a specific campaign

medal. After many years of campaigning it was announced in late 2012 that members of the armed services and merchant

seamen who had participated in the Arctic convoys would be entitled to the Arctic Star. The first Arctic star medal was

presented to approximately 40 veterans on 19th March 2013.



The Memorial and the Coyle Family



Michael Coyle served in the Royal Navy during WW2, part of that service being on the Arctic Convoys. When he died his

family decided that the money that he left should go to the erection of a memorial to remember those who had served on

the Arctic Convoys.



The picture below shows his daughter on the occasion of the dedication of the memorial on 14th August 2012. The lower

left picture is the inscription on the side of the memorial and the plaque to Michael Coyle is by the tree next to the memorial.



ROYAL FLEET AUXILLARY (RFA)



First established in 1905 to provide coaling ships to fill the bunkers of RN vessels

Part of the Royal Navy but crewed mostly by civilians and Royal Naval Reserve.

Primary role is to offer logistical support to Royal Navy ships at sea, by delivering essential equipment/ supplies/



fuel/ mail.

The RFA has also been deployed to provide humanitarian aid to disaster areas around the globe.

The RFA has also been used to transport members of the Royal Marines and British Army.

Two RFA vessels were lost in the Falklands conflict - Sir Tristram and Sir Galahad.

The Royal Fleet Auxiliary (RFA)

The Royal Fleet Auxiliary (RFA) is a civilian-manned fleet of vessels owned by the United Kingdom, and provides support for



various functions of the Royal Navy, such as resupplying fuel and ammunition to Navy ships while at sea. Ships in its service

carry the prefix “RFA”.



It was established in 1905, and has assisted the Royal Navy in many different conflicts across the globe, symbolised by the

grey granite paving stones, set in the shape of a compass.



The triangular plinth of polished granite represents the bow of an RFA ship, and is surrounded by different coloured stones

forming the shape of the ship's bow wave.



The memorial was dedicated in the presence of the RFA Commodore-in-Chief, His Royal Highness The Earl of Wessex, KG

GCVO ADC on 11 October 2012.



Since 1905 the civilian-manned Royal Fleet Auxiliary has delivered worldwide logistical and operational support for a wide

range of tasks undertaken by the Royal Navy, its sailors and marines. The base of the memorial is a circular pavement of

different types of grey granite in the form of a compass, symbolising how the RFA has supported the Navy around the world.

On this base is a triangular plinth of grey polished granite representing the bow of a ship with the name of ROYAL FLEET

AUXILIARY. On the back of this plinth is etched an image of a ship of the RFA fleet from a photograph by John Crae. The

pavement around the plinth uses different coloured granite to symbolise the waves formed by the ship running through

water. At the rear of the circular pavement are two dark grey angled headstones with the badge of the Royal Fleet Auxiliary

and a list of the 24 ships of the RFA that have suffered fatalities during conflict: RFA Thrush (1917), RFA Creosol(1918), RFA

Vitol(1918), RFA Hungerford (1918), RFA Industry (1918), RFA Hughli (1919), RFA Cairndale (1941), RFA Maine (1941), RFA

Petrella (1941), RFA Darkdale (1941), RFA Ebonol (1941), RFA Francol (1942), RFA Slavol (1942), RFA Montenol (1942), RFA

Dinsdale (1942), RFA Brambleleaf (1942), RFA Gray Ranger (1942), RFA Ennerdale (1943), RFA Broomdale (1944), RFA War

Nizam (1944), RFA Bishopdale (1944), RFA War Diwan (1944), RFA Sir Galahad (1982), RFA Sir Tristram (1982).

name: MERCHANT NAYY WOOD
description:
A total of 2,535 oak trees were originally planted, one for every British and Commonwealth flagged Merchant Ship

sunk during WW2. However, to allow the trees to grow, some have had to be removed.



The memorial plinths along the sides of the wood were placed by the shipping companies and give details of the

ships lost including the location of the sinking.



2 memorials can be found within the Merchant Navy wood:

name: THE HMT LANCASTRIA
description:
HMT Lancastria a troopship, which was sunk off the coast of France, near St Nazaire, in June 1940. Lancastria was

carrying both service personnel and civilians; it is unknown how many were on board at the time but some estimates

are up 9,000. This was such a catastrophe that that Churchill ordered a “D Notice” - a total news blackout - for fear

of the damage this may do to the country's morale.



In WW2 many ocean-going pleasure liners were requisitioned by the British Government to support the war

effort.



HMT Lancastria's capacity was 1,300 passengers, it was deployed to St Nazaire, France, to assist in the evacuation

of British Nationals and troops from France, two weeks after Dunkirk.



On the 17 June 1940 it was agreed to load 3,000 onto the ship but that number increased during the boarding,

estimated between 5,000 and 9,000.



The Captain of Lancastria could have left port around 14:00 but the RN destroyer which was to escort it had been

bombed by the Germans.



So Lancastria's Captain decided to wait for an escort

Unfortunately, while waiting, a fresh air raid began at around 16:00 and Lancastria was hit by three or possibly



four bombs.

A number of survivors reported that one of the bombs had gone down the ships only funnel causing the ship to



sink quickly - around 15-20 minutes.

Opinions differ on actual loss of life but the general consensus is at least 3,000, up to around 7,000.

A simple stone memorial is located in front of the ‘Lancastria Oak’ within the Merchant Navy Woodland, bearing a circular



plaque inscribed with the Lancastria Association badge and emblem.

The story of the Lancastria is little known but represents the biggest disaster in British maritime history.

On 17 June 1940, the 16,000-ton Cunard liner Lancastria lay five miles off St Nazaire embarking troops, RAF personnel and



civilian refugees, including women and children, who were being evacuated from France, which was then on the point of

collapse. The exact number of people on board may never be known, but almost certainly exceeded 6,000; some estimates

were as high as 9,000.



The Lancastria was attacked and hit by bombs from German aircraft. The ship sank rapidly and, according to the estimate of

the Commanding Officer, Captain Rudolf Sharpe, only around 2,500 of those on board were saved.



Due to the scale of the tragedy and in the interests of public morale (this also being the day that the French government

decided to seek an armistice with Nazi Germany), Winston Churchill forbade publication of the news at the time, hence the

story of the Lancastria has never been generally known, although it is Britain’s worst maritime disaster.



Since the Second World War, the Lancastria Association and Lancastria Association of Scotland have established memorials to

the victims and carry out remembrance services every year.

name: ST PERCIVALE (ANCHOR)
description:
Sir Percivale was a Round table Class Logistics Landing Ship, she was the sister ship to Sir Tristram and Sir Galahad.

St Percivale landed troops in St Carlos Bay was the first British Vessel to enter Port Stanley following the Argentinian

Surrender. Sir Percivale was later used to support British operations in the Balkans.



The Sir Tristram was badly damaged in the Falklands Conflict but was returned to the UK at the end of the conflict,

repaired and returned to service.



Following an air attack by Argentinian Aircraft on 24 May 1982 Sir Galahad was so badly damaged that she was

deemed to be unrepairable and was towed away and sunk at the end of the conflict.



The central glade of the Merchant Navy Convoy Wood is an appropriate home to one of the anchors from Royal Fleet

Auxiliary (RFA) Sir Percivale (a Round Table Class landing ship logistics, commissioned in 1968), donated by the Merchant

Navy Welfare Board.



Outside the two World Wars, the largest loss of Merchant Navy lives was during the Falklands conflict. Sir Percivale landed

troops in San Carlos Bay and was the first British vessel to enter Port Stanley following the Argentinian surrender. She later

served in the Gulf War of 1991, was deployed in support of British operations in the Balkans and was present at the handover

of Hong Kong to China.



She was decommissioned on 17 August 2004 and had been crewed throughout her life by officers and ratings of the

Merchant Navy.



The anchor was dedicated on 8 June 2011, the anniversary of the bombing of Sir Percivale’s sister ships Sir Galahad and Sir

Tristram in Bluff Cove during the Falklands conflict in 1982.

name: HMS GANGES
description:
HMS Ganges was established in 1905 as a Boy Seamans’ training school. It accepted boys between the ages of 15 and 16 ½

with the purpose of training them to be sailors fit to serve in His/Her Majesty's fleet. It was eventually closed in 1976 when

initial training of all Naval Ratings transferred to HMS Raleigh in Cornwall.



The HMS Ganges Association Memorial is located near to the Merchant Navy Convoy Wood. It comprises four cornerstones

which represent the four countries of the United Kingdom from where the boys came. The stones are Cromar Lightning from

Scotland, Plum Slate from Wales, Irish Quartzite from Ireland and Green Lakeland Slate from England. Each of the stones

displays a carved national floral emblem: Scotland - Thistle, Wales - Daffodil, Ireland - Shamrock and England - Rose.



The main central plinth is a piece of White Portland Stone onto which is carved the H.M.S. Ganges crest above the following

dedication:



"This memorial is dedicated to the memory of all who passed through H.M.S Ganges at Shotley in Suffolk between the years

1905 and 1976."



The memorial sits on a bed of green/blue shale, to represent the sea, which is enclosed within a course of Staffordshire Blue

Bricks.



Ganges was a Royal Navy Training Establishment at Shotley Gate near Ipswich for boys aged 15 and 16. It provided

a tough regime involving education, (maths, English, navigation and naval history), physical education and parade

ground drill.



Between its establishment in 1905 and closure in 1976 around 160,000 recruits passed through its gates and it was

often referred to as "the establishment that fed the fleet".

name: DEFENSIVLY EQUIPPED MERCHANT SHIPS (DEMS) MEMORIAL GARDEN
description:
Learning from the success of Defensively ARMED Merchant Ships in WWl, the Admiralty established the DEMS

organisation in 1938.



In the first 6 months of the Second World War some 1,900 ships had been defensively equipped and by the end of

1940, a total of 3,400 were armed.



Guns were manned by personnel from Maritime Royal Artillery, Royal Navy and Royal Marines.

Their primary role was defence against surfaced U-boats and aircraft.

The 40mm Bofors gun was one of the types of gun fitted to merchant ships, used mainly as an Anti-Aircraft weapon.



Some merchant ships had larger 3-inch or 6-inch guns fitted.

Defensively Equipped Merchant Ships (DEMS)

In the centre of the Defensively Equipped Merchant Ships (DEMS) memorial garden is a Bofors gun of the type which were



fitted on merchant ships and manned by personnel from Maritime Royal Artillery (MRA), the Royal Navy and the Royal

Marines.



During the Second World War, DEMS gunners were deployed on merchant ships in numbers varying from two on the smallest

ships to up to 100 in the larger transporters. They fought off enemy aircraft, mine, submarine and surface attacks to ensure

that the merchant ships could carry supplies to services and civilians.



Sacrifices were heavy, with over 4,100 personnel killed or missing. Their names can be found in the “Book of Remembrance -

The Merchant Navy World War Two” in the Millennium Chapel.

name: THE NAVAL SERVICE MEMORIAL
description:
Naval Service Memorial



The Naval Service Memorial is located at the heart of the Naval Section of the Arboretum and commemorates those who have served,

serve today and will serve tomorrow, regardless of rank, trade or fighting arm.



The striking memorial was created by Graeme Mitcheson, from a theme developed by Lt Cdr Nigel Huxtable. It is comprised of 13

coloured glass panels on a white granite terrace and includes a figure of Kilkenny limestone.



The glass depicts the colours of the five oceans – steel grey with spume lines for the Atlantic, turquoise for the Indian, ultramarine for

the Pacific and white for the Arctic and Southern oceans.



Yellow is for the rising sun, red for the setting sun and the blood spilled at sea, and on land.



On the memorial’s terrace stands a figure of a sailor, head bowed in respect to shipmates everywhere, cap held in the ‘at ease’ position.

The figure faces west, where the sun sets. The terrace has a carved inscription of the Tennyson poem ‘Crossing the Bar’ – a phrase

used when shipmates pass away.



The glass panels cast a shadow suggesting the shape of a warship. Visible only in sunlight and for a few hours per day, it is best seen

on 11 November.



The curved shapes suggest waves and motion while the scale and colour hint at sails in a harbour. The idea for the ‘warship shadow’

came when the designer was in his garden, on a summer’s day, watching shadows cast by washing hanging on the line.



The Naval Service Memorial was unveiled on 15 June 2014 by HRH Prince Michael of Kent.



The coloured glass memorial was commissioned by the Royal Naval Association to mark the 60th anniversary of its

being granted a Royal Charter.



The 13 glass panels depict the different colours of the oceans of the world, while yellow is for the rising sun and red

the setting sun. There are also splashes of red representing the blood spilled at sea, on land and in the air in defence

of our nation.



The panels cast a shadow, suggesting the shape of a warship, which is best seen around lunchtime when the sun is

directly behind.



The single figure faces the setting sun, head bowed, and cap held in the 'at ease' position, showing respect to his

fallen shipmates.



On the terrace edge is a carved inscription from the Tennyson poem 'Crossing the Bar', which is the phrase used by

Navy personnel when a shipmate has passed away.



Crossing the Bar - Alfred, Lord Tennyson



SUNSET and evening star,

And one clear call for me!

And may there be no moaning of the bar,

When I put out to sea,



But such a tide as moving seems asleep,

Too full for sound and foam,

When that which drew from out the boundless deep

Turns again home.



Twilight and evening bell,

And after that the dark!



And may there be no sadness or farewell,

When I embark;



For tho' from out our bourne of Time and Place

The flood may bear me far,

I hope to see my Pilot face to face

When I have crost the bar.



This poem, written in 1889, is to be found on the edging strip round the Royal Naval Association Memorial.

A bar is a sandbank, sometimes, found near a harbour entrance and in the Navy the phrase ‘cross ing the

bar’ is used as a euphemism for the death of a sailor.

name: MERCHANT NAVY ASSOCIATION
description:
Although there had been merchant vessels throughout history, at the end of WW1, in recognition of their service,

King George V bestowed the title Merchant Navy on them.



The title "Master of the Merchant Navy and Fishing Fleets" is held by the reigning Monarch.



The Merchant Navy Association (MNA) was formed in 1989. Its purpose is to ensure the welfare of both serving and

former Merchant Navy personnel.



This memorial, dedicated on the 1 October 2003, represents past and present Merchant Navy personnel. The memorial stone came

from a Cornish quarry. The white seams in the rock represent the sea washing over the rocks ashore.

name: Ocean Fairway Blue Funnel Line Memorial
description:
The memorial is a tribute to the Merchant Navy Officers and Seamen of the Blue Funnel Line, Glen Line and NSMO who served during

the Second World War and especially those who made the ultimate sacrifice. It was donated by the Ocean Association of Retired

Masters and Chief Engineers, the Nestorian Association of Ocean Group plc.

name: Ocean Fairway Elder Dempster Line Memorial
description:
The memorial is a tribute to the Merchant Navy Officers and Seamen of the Elder Dempster Lines and W.M. Cory & Son Ltd who served

during the Second World War and especially those who made the ultimate sacrifice. It was donated by the Elders of the Elder and The

Ocean Association of Retired Masters and Chief Engineers of Ocean Group plc.



Royal Navy

name: FALKLANDS MEMORIAL (South Atlantic Medal Association)
description:
In 1982, the Argentinians invaded the Falkland Islands; they have long believed the islands belonged to them and refer to

them as The Malvinas. Britain's response was to send a Task Force to liberate them, whilst this was successful, it came at a

price, and 255 service personnel lost their lives.



As war was never declared this is referred to as the Falklands Conflict not war.



The purpose of this memorial is threefold:



1. To honour the Task Force;



2. To remember those who gave their lives;



3. To inform visitors about this important event in our history.



The rocks are from the Falklands, and the Azaleas are a species created by a local garden centre called "Azalea Antelope"

in memory of HMS Antelope, a Type 2l Frigate lost in the conflict.



The plaque on the reverse of the central rock commemorates the 3 female Falkland Islanders who lost their lives during the

conflict.



The wall of Cotswold stone is modelled on the memorial that stands at San Carlos Cemetery. The central plaque on the wall

shows the crest of Joint Service Operations, which is flanked by the 6 services that played a role in the conflict.



The plaque at the base of the wall shows an outline map of the Atlantic Oceans and gives an indication of the vast distances

the Task Force had to travel before engaging the Argentinians.



Some stats:



Human losses: 255 British; 3 islanders; 649 Argentinians.

Ship losses: 4 - HM Ships Sheffield; Ardent; Antelope; Coventry. Argentinian ARA Belgrano

Merchant Navy ship losses: I - Atlantic Conveyor with its cargo.

Royal Fleet Auxiliary ships losses: 2 - Sir Tristram and Sir Galahad; 56, mostly Welsh Guards, died on the latter



At the time of her sinking Captain Hart-Dyke was the Captain of HMS Coventry, his daughter is Maranda Hart the actress

and comedian

name: HMS Glorious, HMS Acasta & HMS Ardent
description:
The Loss of HMS Glorious, HMS Acasta & HMS Ardent on 8th June 1940.



Scharnhorst (Kapitain zur See Hoffman) and Gneisenau (Kapitan zur See Netzbandt), during the course of the Kriegsmarine’s Operation

Juno, sank the aircraft carrier HMS Glorious (Captain Guy D’Oyly-Hughes DSO, 1159 crew and 59 RAF personnel were lost; only 39

survivors) and her two escorts HMS Acasta (Commander C E Glasfurd, there was only one survivor) and HMS Ardent-H41 (Lt

Commander J E Barker, 152 crew killed and the 2 survivors became POW) in somewhat controversial circumstances.



Why was HMS Glorious detached from the rest of the fleet sailing from Narvik and sailing with only two destroyers for escort? Why

didn’t HMS Glorious have aircraft in the air watching for enemy warships? However, HMS Acasta torpedoed the Scharnhorst causing

damage that put her out of action for the remainder of the year.



Admiral Sir Charles Forbes recommended that both Commander Glasfurd and Lieutenant Commander Barker be awarded the Victoria

Cross: they were awarded a posthumous Mention in Despatches.



The first 2 letters of the ships names forms, GLARAC, the name of the association.

name: HMS ARDENT
description:
To the left of the Falklands Memorial is the anchor from HMS ARDENT, one of the ships lost in the Falklands conflict.

Several years prior to the conflict she was anchored in Portland Harbour when a storm blew up and she was in danger of being



driven ashore; to prevent this they severed one of her anchors and took her out to sea; the anchor was left on the sea bed.

Following the loss of Ardent, Babcock Ltd. raised the anchor, renovated it and donated it to the South Atlantic Medal Association

as a tribute and memorial to the ship and crew.



This memorial is one of the original Anchors from the Type 21 frigate, HMS Ardent. The anchor was lost in a storm in Portland

harbour in 1980.



HMS Ardent was lost in action on 21 May 1982, defending the landings to retake the Falkland Islands. The HMS Ardent

association was formed by the survivors.



The anchor was recovered some years later and offered to the Association as a permanent memorial to all those shipmates

who lost their lives in the South Atlantic. The memorial was dedicated on 21 May 2015 in the presence of HRH The Duchess

of Gloucester GCVO.

name: HMS SHEFFIELD
description:
HMS Sheffield was a Type 42 guided missile destroyer and the second Royal Navy ship to be named after the city of

Sheffield in Yorkshire. Commissioned on 16 February 1975 the Sheffield was part of the Task Force 317 sent to the

Falkland Islands.



On May 4 1982, the 4,100-ton destroyer was struck by a missile fired from an Argentine fighter bomber as it carried

out a scouting mission off the Falklands - which Argentina had invaded and claimed as their own weeks earlier.



The ship caught fire when a French-made Exocet missile hit HMS Sheffield and went deep into its control room.

The blaze caused a poisonous smoke to be released and most of the crew abandoned ship.

The “Shiny Sheff”

The Shiny Sheff memorial honours the service of all those who served in the three ships of that name over 65 years and the



20 members of the Ship’s Company killed in action during the Falklands Conflict in 1982:

The Cruiser (C24) 1937-67. World War 11 service

The Destroyer (D80) 1970-82. Gulf and Falklands conflict

The Frigate (F96) 1986-2002. Gulf. Awarded the Wilkinson Sword of Peace

In 2020 with the 40th anniversary of the Falklands Conflict rapidly approaching the HMS SHEFFIELD Association agreed that a



memorial should be placed at the National Memorial Arboretum to honour all those who served in the three ships of that

name and that there should also be a place of remembrance for the 20 men lost when the second vessel of the name was

damaged in action on the 4th of May 1982. In the spring of 2021, the artist Peter Naylor was commissioned to design a

memorial which reflected all three ships and their close association with the city of Sheffield and its industries. The City of

Sheffield Master Cutler was approached for assistance in making the memorial. The fabrication of the memorial was led by

William Cook steel casting and supported by Tinsley Bridge, Outokumpu, and Charles Day Steels. The Association are

extremely proud that their memorial was made of stainless steel by skilled craftsmen in the city of Sheffield. The memorial

consists of a stainless-steel bow of a warship set in a stainless steel base, within in the deconstructed cruiser’s crest. The

circular crest on the top of the memorial represents both destroyer and frigate.



Materials Used

Sheffield Stainless steel cast and sheet

The memorial was constructed in January to April 2022 with ground-breaking in April 2022, it was unveiled by Mrs Penny



Salt, widow of Captain Sam Salt, the Commanding Officer of the Destroyer HMS SHEFFIELD during the Falklands conflict. Mrs

Salt consecrated the memorial on the 4th of May 2022 with a bottle of sea water collected in the South Atlantic by HMS

Forth.



Symbolism

Positioned close to the South Atlantic Memorial and the corner of the Naval Field the memorial links the South Atlantic



conflict with the large part played in that conflict by the Royal Navy and supporting Maritime services.

The design of the memorial and its manufacture in stainless steel proudly links all three ships with the City of Sheffield and its



world-famous steel industries. When they were constructed all three warships were presented with ship’s bells and fittings of

stainless steel made in Sheffield.



The memorial represents a warship at speed as it cuts through a dull grey sea during operations. The sea is set in the

deconstructed pentagonal crest of the cruiser which links the second world war generation of sailors to the modern era.



The warship crest on the top of the memorial takes the sheaf of arrows from the city of Sheffield Coat of Arms. The sheaf of

arrows is a wordplay on the river Sheaf which runs through Sheffield and is also a reference to the iron and steel making

heritage of the city.

name: BATTLE OF THE RIVER PLATE (The first sea battle of WW2)
description:
The Battle of the River Plate, which took place on the 13 December 1939, was the first major naval battle of the Second World War

and the only episode of the War to take place in South America.



The German pocket battleship Admiral Graf Spee, commanded by Kapitän sur See Hans Langsdorff, had been terrorising Allied shipping

in the South Atlantic. It was eventually tracked down and engaged by three ships from the Royal Navy’s South American division (the

cruisers HMS Ajax, HMS Exeter, and HMS Achilles) commanded by Commodore Henry Harwood Harwood. All four ships sustained

considerable damage and Graf Spee limped into an estuary in neutral Uruguay to undertake necessary repairs.



Given just 72 hours to repair, the Germans knew escape was impossible and scuttled (sank) the ship in the River Plate. Two days later,

in Buenos Aires where the crew were taken, Kapitän Langsdorff committed suicide. He was buried there with full military honours and

the service was attended by British officers who were present in the city.



This impressive black granite memorial was unveiled in the presence of the few remaining River Plate veterans on 12 April 2014 to

mark the 75th anniversary of the Battle of the River Plate.



Significantly, it was the 300th memorial to be dedicated at the Arboretum.



The Graf Spee was a German battleship; her mission, to destroy allied merchant ships in the Atlantic.

In December 1940 she was engaged by HM Ships Exeter, Ajax and Achilles

Exeter was badly damaged and withdrew; the other two ships, although damaged, remained on station.

The Graf Spee put into Montevideo, Uruguay, which was a neutral country, so she could only stay for 24 hours for



humanitarian reasons; however, she managed to stay for 72 hours.

The Admiralty sent a signal to Ajax and Achilles informing them that a carrier and a battlecruiser were on their way



as support; this was in fact one of the greatest deceptions of the war, they were not.

Graf Spee's captain, convinced that stronger forces were waiting, left the majority of his crew behind and sailed out



of the port where he scuttled his ship; he committed suicide two days later.

Most of his crew stayed in Montevideo, others went to Buenos Aires, many of them married and raised families; the



last surviving crew member, died in Buenos Aires June 2007 aged 89.

The apron approaching the memorial shows the exact size of the shells that were exchanged.

The front of the memorial shows the crests and silhouettes of the 3 RN ships, the reverse side is the ship's crest and



silhouette of the Graf Spee.

There are two quotes from Winston Churchill; "This brilliant sea fight takes its place in our naval annals and in long



cold dark winter it warms the cockles of the British hearts"; and other one says, "This great battle will long be told

in song and story"



Behind the memorial is a small pavier with the inscription, "sealed herein are the names of those who served on

HMS Ajax, HMS Achilles, HMS Exeter and Admiral Graf Spee who gave their lives whilst serving their country. Also,

those who 75 years later supported the commissioning and dedication of this memorial on 12 April 2014.

name: TYPE 21 FRIGATES
description:
The Type 21 frigate, was a British general-purpose escort that was designed in the late 1960s, built in the 1970s and served

throughout the 1980s into the 1990s



There were 8 ships in the class - all except HMS Amazon took part in the Falkland’s conflict. Two ships were lost: HMS

Ardent was hit by bombs dropped by Argentine aircraft on 21 May and consumed by fire; HMS Antelope was hit by bombs

on 23 May, one of which was set off by the bomb disposal team attempting to defuse it on 24 May, causing the ship to

catch fire and setting off her magazines, resulting in her breaking her back and sinking.

name: HMS ARGONAUT
description:
Four different ships have carried the name HMS Argonaut, the first was in 1782; the second was a WW1 Cruiser; and

the third, a WW2 Cruiser which took part in the D-Day landings in 1944.



The final Argonaut, a Frigate, took part in the Falklands conflict where it was badly damaged; Able Seaman Iain Boldy

and Able Seaman Matthew J Stuart lost their lives. Their names appear on the back of the memorial, as well as on

the AFM.



Margaret Allen, the wife of lain Boldy, was instrumental in the creation of this memorial which shows the ship's

crest, under which is part of a poem written by Margaret.



Four ships named HMS Argonaut have served with the Royal Navy.

For the last three ships, the names of the crew members who died while serving on the ship are recorded on the reverse face



of the memorial.

The fourth HMS Argonaut (the Leander-class frigate – Pennant Number F56), was commissioned in 1967 and saw service



across the world including escorting the RMS Queen Mary on her final voyage to the USA.

In April 1982, she set sail for the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic to join the existing naval task force as part of Operation



Corporate. The ship was badly damaged while patrolling in San Carlos Bay on 21 May 1982 and two of her crew were lost.

The memorial is dedicated to all those lost whilst serving on HMS Argonaut and was unveiled on 21 May 2017.

name: HMS KANDAHAR AND HMS NEPTUNE
description:
On 19 December 1941, part of British Force K, based in Malta, was tasked to intercept an Italian convoy bound for

Tripoli



The light cruiser Neptune, leading cruisers Aurora and Penelope, together with the Destroyers Kandahar and Lively,

struck two mines, part of a newly laid Italian minefield. The other cruisers present, Aurora and Penelope, also struck

mines.



While reversing out of the minefield, Neptune struck a third mine, which took off her propellers and left her dead in

the water. Aurora was unable to render assistance as she was already down to 10 knots (19 km/h) and needed to

turn back to Malta. Penelope was also unable to assist.



The destroyers Kandahar and Lively were sent into the minefield to attempt a tow. Kandahar struck a mine and began

drifting. Neptune then signalled for Lively to keep clear. (Kandahar was later evacuated and torpedoed by the

destroyer Jaguar, to prevent her capture.)



Neptune hit a fourth mine and quickly capsized. Only 30 seamen, out of her complement of 767, initially survived

the sinking, and only one was still alive when their lifeboat was picked up five days later by an Italian torpedo boat.



Concealed within the memorial is a roll of honour of the 837 men who died and a painting of the sky as it was on

the night of the sinking.

name: CASTLE CLASS CORVETTES
description:
To the left is a plaque to the Flower Class Corvettes (all named after flowers) - they were the predecessor of the

Castles



The ships of this class were named after castles.

The stones laid across the top are taken from various castles and are placed to resemble the battlements on top of



a castle wall.

name: HUNT CLASS DESTROYERS
description:
The Hunt Class Destroyers were designed as convoy escorts with anti-aircraft capabilities. They were completed

between 1940 and 1942; of the 86 completed 14 were transferred to other Allied Navies. Between them they sank

5 Italian submarines and 16 German U-boats.



The plaque on the memorial lists all ships by name with a separate list for the 25 sunk in date of loss order: details

of the circumstances and location of the loss are also given.

name: HMS CHARYBDIS AND HMS LIMBOURNE
description:
The HMS Charybdis and HMS Limbourne Memorial remembers the 502 sailors, marines and crew who lost their lives

when both ships were torpedoed by German destroyers and sunk in the English Channel in October 1943 during

Operation Tunnel.



Operation Tunnel was mounted when the Royal Navy gained intelligence the Germans would be moving a convoy

along the Brittany coast on the night of 22nd/23rd October 1943. The cruiser HMS Charybdis accompanied six

destroyers should have been a formidable force for the engagement, but it is thought that the German shore-based

radar gave the enemy advance warning of the movements of the British ships. Although the Charybdis picked up the

approach of enemy ships on her radar, it was too late to anticipate a joint torpedo attack by a group of German

destroyers.



The Charybdis was hit by a torpedo first, and the destroyer HMS Limbourne soon afterwards, both ships sank, and

the German ships withdrew, undetected.



The HMS Charybdis and HMS Limbourne Memorial remembers the 502 sailors, marines and crew who lost their lives when

both ships were torpedoed by German destroyers and sunk in the English Channel near Guernsey on 23rd October 1943

during Operation Tunnel.



Operation Tunnel was mounted when the Royal Navy gained intelligence the Germans would be moving a convoy along the

Brittany coast on the night of the 22nd/23rd October 1943. The cruiser HMS Charybdis accompanied six destroyers should

have been a formidable force for the engagement, but it is thought that the German shore-based radar gave the enemy

advance warning of the movements of the British ships. Although the Charybdis picked up the approach of enemy ships on

her radar, it was too late to anticipate a joint torpedo attack by a group of German destroyers.



The Charybdis was hit by a torpedo first, and the destroyer HMS Limbourne soon afterwards, both ships sank, and the German

ships withdrew, undetected.

name: LOCH CLASS FRIGATES CAIRN
description:
The memorial is dedicated to the men of the Ship’s Companies who served the Loch Class Frigates and their variants in the

North Atlantic, Artic, India (Burma) and Pacific Oceans during the Second World War and in all spheres until 1970.



The circular stone memorial, resembling a cairn, is finished with stones from each of the 28 named Scottish Lochs.

The ships remembered here were named after Scottish Lochs. A stone brought from each of the named lochs has been built



into the cairn next to the stone for the ship that was named after it.

A frigate is a small warship; in WW2 mainly used against submarines. A Corvette is rather smaller and was used mainly to



protect merchant ship convoys.

name: HMS PRINCE OF WALES AND REPULSE
description:
The Destruction of Force Z – The Sinking of HMS Prince of Wales and HMS Repulse in the South China Sea by the Japanese 22nd Air

Flotilla.



HMS Prince of Wales was a George V Class Battleship built by Cammell Laird, Birkenhead and commissioned in March 1941. She

displaced 35,000 tons and had a main armament of 10 14 inch guns.



She participated in the pursuit of the German Battleship Bismark and was struck 7 times during the battle resulting in the loss of 14

men. In August 1941, HMS Prince of Wales transported Sir Winston Churchill to meet Franklin D Roosevelt at Placenta Bay,

Newfoundland where they created the Atlantic Charter.



HMS Repulse was a Renown Class Battle Cruiser built by John Browns, Clydebank. She displaced 30,370 tons and had a main armament

of 6 15-inch guns.



She was commissioned in August 1916. She took part in the Battle of Heligoland Bight, was involved in refugee work at the outbreak

of the Spanish War and in 1940 operated out of Norway and was on convoy duties until July 1941.



The Destruction of Force Z



Force Z was formed when HMS Prince of Wales joined HMS Repulse at Ceylon on 29th November and on 2nd December Force Z arrived

in Singapore. On 8th December Force Z left Singapore to disrupt Japanese landings on the coast of Malaya. During the course of the

voyage thaey saw no Japanese ships but on the 10th they were spotted in the South China Sea by the Japanese.



Force Z was attacked by the Japanese 22nd Air Flotilla based in Vietnam. HMS Prince of Wales was disabled early in the attack by

torpedoes that damaged her propellors; while HMS Repulse was able to comb torpedo attacks until she was attacked from two

directions at once and was sunk.



Casualties were severe.



HMS Repulse: 512 men lost and 796 saved but 3 died later of wounds



HMS Prince of Wales: 330 men lost, 1285 survivors of whom 3 died of wounds.



The Japanese lost just 8 aircraft.



The three senior officers at the site of the sinking were: -



Admiral Sir Tom S Phillips (Flag HMS Prince of Wales) KIA.



Captain John Leach DSO – CO of HMS Prince of Wales KIA



Captain William George Tennant CB - CO of HMS Repulse



The escorts for Force Z were the destroyers HMS Electra (Commander Cecil W May), HMS Express (Lieutenant Commander Francis J

Cartwright), HMS Tenedos (Lieutenant Richard Dyer) & RANS Vampire (Commander W T A Moran RAN).



The naval historian Captain Stephen Roskill reported a conversation with Vice Admiral Tom Phillips in 1940 and noted that “Ph illips

would not accept that it was suicidal to operate off an enemy held coast without air cover”.



The memorial is dedicated to all who served on HMS Repulse and HMS Prince of Wales. During the action a total 838 died in battle

off the Malayan coast, but many more died later as Japanese Prisoners of War (captured when Singapore fell). The memorial is made

of black granite, with images of HMS Repulse and HMS Prince of Wales engraved on it. Brief details of the history of both vessels are

also engraved on the memorial.



HMS Prince of Wales (1939) was a King George V-class battleship of the Royal Navy. She was involved in several key

actions of the Second World War, including the battle of Denmark Strait against the Bismarck, operations escorting

convoys in the Mediterranean, also took Churchill to meet Roosevelt. Dispatched to the Far east as part of Force Z,

her final action and sinking in the Pacific in 1941.



HMS Repulse (1916) was a Renown-class battlecruiser of the Royal Navy built during the First World War. Part of sink

the Bismark group. She was dispatched in November 1941 to Force Z which was supposed to deter Japanese

aggression against British possessions in the Far East. Repulse and her consort Prince of Wales were eventually sunk

by Japanese aircraft on 10 December 1941 when they attempted to intercept landings in British Malaya.

name: ROYAL NAVAL PATROL SERVICE (Harry Tate’s Navy)
description:
As part of its preparation for WW2, the Admiralty requisitioned fishing boats and their crews and named them the

Royal Naval Patrol Service, which came under the auspices of HMS Europa.



They were trained to use sonar for mine clearance and locating German U -Boats. Over the course of the war, the

number of boats rose to 6,000, crewed by 70,000 men.



HMS Europa was a Royal Navy Shore establishment active during World War 2 as the central depot for the Royal

Naval Patrol Service (RNPS) It was established after the commandeering of Sparrows Nest Gardens, a private

residence in Lowestoft



In the 1920s and 30s there was a comedian, Harry Tate, whose act portrayed a man who could not cope with the

technology of the day; the fishermen initially could not cope with the technicalities of mine sweeping etc., so the

general Navy christened them "Harry Tate’s Navy',



Whilst proficient at their job, they kept the title "Harry Tate's Navy". The memorial carries the inscription; "From the

frozen Arctic to the South Pacific", and the motto, "ln the depths we searched".



The NNPS was disbanded in 1946.

name: HMS BARHAM MEMORIAL
description:
HMS Barham was a Queen Elizabeth Class Battleship armed with 8 15-inch guns: she was launched on 31st

December 1914 and entered service the following year. Most notably she was part of the 5th Battle Squadron at

the Battle of Jutland in 1916, when it was attached to Vice Admiral Beaty's Battle Cruiser Squadron.



She saw extensive service in the first half of WW2 and took part in the Battle of Matapan in March 1941 when the

Italian Fleet was defeated.



On 25th November 1941 she was sunk off the Libyan coast by U-331

The memorial is dedicated to all crew members of HMS Barham from entering service in 1915 until sinking on 25th



November 1941: she served in both world wars.

She was the fourth ship to be named HMS Barham after Charles Middleton, 1st Lord Barham (1726-1813). He was the 1st



Lord of the Admiralty who gave Lord Nelson his orders when he sailed to join the fleet prior to the Battle of Trafalgar.

HMS Barham was a Queen Elizabeth Class Battleship (27,500 tons) armed with 8 15-inch guns: she was launched on 31st



December 1914 and entered service the following year. Most notably she was was part of the 5th Battle Squadron at the

Battle of Jutland in 1916, when it was attached to Vice Admiral Beaty's Battle Cruiser Squadron.



She saw extensive service in the first half of WW2 particularly with the Mediterranean Fleet under the command of Admiral

Andrew B Cunningham and took part in the Battle of Matapan on 28th March 1941 when the Italian Fleet was defeated.



On 25th November 1941 she was sunk off the Libyan coast by U-331: her commanding officer Captain Geoffrey Clement Cooke,

55 officers and 806 ratings were killed. There is a famous sequence of the sinking filmed by a Pathe cameraman aboard HMS

Valiant: it is available on the internet.

name: WOMEN'S ROYAL NAVAL SERVTCE (WRNS)
description:
The installation of the AOW Centenary Stone took place on Wednesday 23rd September 2020 in the WRNS Garden.



The memorial represents one hundred years since the Association was formed and it is very fitting that installation was able to go

ahead in what should have been a year of celebration when so many planned events had to be cancelled.



The stone was constructed by Robyn Golden-Hann. It represents not only former wrens but also the Women of the Royal Naval Services

as they are today.



The WRNS were founded in l9l7 to support the men of the Royal Navy, but were disbanded in 1919.

In 1939, at the outbreak of WW2, they were re-established and remained in service until 1993 when they were fully



integrated into the Royal Navy. Women now carry out exactly the same duties as their male counterparts, both at

sea and ashore.



The garden is dedicated to all who served in the service and is designed to encourage birds, insects and butterflies.

The pathways form the shape of an anchor.



The wren, which was carved by the Essex Woodcarvers, forms part of a memorial for the 21 WRNS and a Naval

Nursing Sister who lost their lives when their ship, SS Aguila, was torpedoed inl94l.



One of the first WRNS to see active service was Wendy Clayin, who in 1990, served on board HMS Brilliant.

The Women’s Royal Naval Service (WRNS), known as the Wrens, was formed in 1917 to release Royal Navy men for sea



service during the First World War. It was disbanded after the war.

On 11th April 1939 Vera Laughton Matthews was appointed Director of the newly reformed Women’s Royal Naval



Service WRNS: she had previously been a member during World War 1. It was originally envisaged that there would be about

3000 women in the WRNS, however at its peak the number was more than 65,000. Around 75,000 Wrens carried out highly

confidential and responsible roles in Britain and overseas. The WRNS was fully integrated into the Royal Navy in 1993.



This charming garden at the far end of the Royal Naval Review is dedicated to the WRNS and has been designed to encourage

birds, insects and butterflies. The paths are in the shape of an anchor. Buddleia shrubs provide a haven for butterflies in

summer. The two rose beds are planted with “Wren” roses to celebrate the 90th anniversary of the Association of Wrens

1917 – 2007. Notcutts Nurseries developed this rose for the 2007 Chelsea Flower Show and donated plants to the Wrens

Garden at the NMA. In the rose beds and against the trees may be found dedications to individual Wrens.



Located in the garden is the Aguila Memorial, a beautifully carved wren which commemorates the 21 WRNS and one Naval

Nursing Sister who were lost when SS Aguila was torpedoed in 1941 (see M-152 Aguilla Memorial).

name: HMS Li Wo
description:
Opposite the entrance to the WREN’s garden is a tree with a plaque to Temporary Lieutenant Thomas Wilkinson

RNR, the captain of HMS Li Wo.



The Li Wo was a passenger riverboat built for the Indo-China Steam Navigation Company Ltd. for service on the

Yangtze River. In 1940 she was requisitioned and commissioned into the Royal Navy at Singapore.



Shortly before the British surrender, Li Wo was ordered to head for the safety of Batavia in the Dutch East Indies.

Her crew consisted of 84 men, mostly naval reservists, but also several survivors from the Prince of Wales and

Repulse, five men from the Army, two from the RAF, ten Malayans, and six Chinese.



She left Singapore at dawn on 13 February 1942, and was attacked several times from the air, suffering some

damage. The next day, while passing north of the Bangka Strait, she encountered a convoy of Japanese transport

ships accompanied by a squadron of warships launching "Operation L", the invasion of Sumatra. The commander of

Li Wo, Temporary Lieutenant Thomas Wilkinson RNR, informed the ship's company that he intended to close and

attack the enemy.



Li Wo altered course towards the leading transport ship of the convoy at full speed, unfurling her battle ensign, and

opening fire with her four-inch gun. She scored a number of direct hits on the transport, starting fires aboard, and

causing the troops aboard to abandon ship. She then attacked another transport ship with machine gun fire.



Li Wo was then heavily shelled by a Japanese light cruiser and 2 Destroyers. Out of ammunition and now sinking,

she rammed the first enemy transport, which later sank, before finally sinking herself. Of the 84 crew, only 7 survived

to be taken prisoner. Lieutenant Thomas Wilkinson went down with the ship; he was awarded the VC.

name: ROYAL NAVY MEDICAL BRANCH
description:
The Royal Naval Medical Service memorial commemorates the dedication that generations of 'medics', from all the constituent parts

of the RNMS, have given to the care of patients and the advancement of naval medicine.



The memorial was unveiled on 23 September 2016 by Surgeon Commodore P J Buxton OBE QHP FRCR RN Medical Director General

(Naval).



There have been medical personnel on HM Ships throughout history; initially referred to as "Saw - bones" because

their main task treating sailors injured in battle usually meant limb amputations!



In 1833, the Admiralty established the Medical Branch and deemed that all naval vessels should carry a "Sick Berth

Attendant".



Medical ratings both work and train alongside the QARNNS both at sea and in hospitals.

They serve in all Naval establishments both at home and abroad and are present on board most Naval vessels and



as field medics in the Royal Marines

name: SUBMARINE SERVICE
description:
The Submariner Memorial



In 1921 the sum of £2130 was raised by public subscription to create a “Memorial tablet to the Officers and Men of the Submarine

Service R.N.” on the Embankment. It was dedicated in June 1922 and remains a very important place in the hearts and minds of all

submariners. Yet the Embankment is not the most peaceful nor easiest place to meet for collective or private acts of remembrance or

for quiet reflection. Moreover, the Embankment Memorial recognises submarines lost in the two world wars but not the submariners

lost since then.



In the years since its opening the National Memorial Arboretum has grown into the centre of national remembrance and all armed

and public services and many of their units and branches have placed memorials on this site. Indeed, the Submariners Associat ion

placed a small plaque here to submarines lost in the wars and another to our VC winners when the Arboretum opened.



In recent years, however, there has been a growing call for a more fitting memorial for the nearly 6000 submariners who have given

their lives in service and, for the first time, to have a memorial which recognises the sacrifice of their families. This was acknowledged

in July 2019 when a group of retired submariners came together to form a charity - The Submariner Memorial Appeal.



The aim was not only to raise funds, plan and install a new memorial, but in the process to bring the disparate elements of the

submarine community together. The appeal was launched by the then Second Sea Lord in front of HMS ANSON in Devonshire Dock

Hall at BAES Barrow-in-Furness on 28 February 2020 and a public competition to find ideas to inspire a professional designer

announced.



From over 600 entries, three age category winners and one overall winner were chosen and their designs given to three carefully

selected professional sculptors. The sculptors were given wide latitude to be inspired by the winning entries but not to have to

reproduce them. The resulting designs were all very different but all impressive, however, Paul Day’s entry immediately engaged the

Board’s emotions and caught the spirit of the submarine service.



Whilst Paul progressed the detailed design and casting of the memorial, fundraising ramped up. Around £500,000 would be needed.

The appeal was very lucky to receive two particularly significant donations from the Gosling Foundation and from an anonymous

donor. Submarine Industries were also very generous with 21 separate companies contributing. Livery companies, the Freemasons,

the Royal Naval Royal Marine Charity, the RN Association and our submarine charities all supported the appeal and many individual

contributions were made through crowd funding and a wealth of individual fundraising activities. These included running, rowing,

cycling, painting, drawing, printing, coining (selling commemorative coins), writing, merchandising and more. The standout individual

effort was Mr Graham Bishop who completed the London Marathon dressed as a model of a submarine.The money was raised in time

for the turf to be cut by Diana Mayes, 100yr old widow of Lt Gordon Noll, CO of HMS UNTAMED and a young submariner from HMS

VIGILANT on 6 September 2021.



The memorial itself is 3500kg of bronze sculpted into a divided fin of a submarine with the lone figure of a submariner standing

between the two halves looking to the surface. On one outer side of the fin is a frieze of families waiting for the return of their loved

ones and on the other fin the Churchill quote:



“Of all the branches of men in the forces there is none which shows more devotion and faces grimmer perils than the submariners.”



The memorial is on a long low mound to give the idea that the rest of the boat is just below the water. An interpretation board is sited

by its ‘port bow’. On this is a QR code which links to a new Online Book of Remembrance gifted to the Appeal by the Friends of the

RN Submarine Museum.



This is a very significant piece of work in it is own right, it features the most detailed and well researched list of those who gave their

lives in service in submarines. It will allow people to add stories and photographs of those whom they have lost and the QR code will

be shared with all the other submarine memorials (over 60) around the country. Funds have been set aside to add it to the

Embankment Memorial as well.



The Submarine Service was formed in 1901 when 6 officers and a number of ratings started submarine training.

That same year the British Government placed an order for 5 American Holland class submarines to be built under

licence by Vickers Sons and Maxim Ltd at Barrow-in-Furness. HMS Holland 1 launched in January 1902.



Although some senior personnel within the Admiralty saw little point in submarines, Britain pursued an energetic

submarine programme and by 1910 had 61 operational submarines.



Submarines played a major role in both world Wars and a total of 14 VCs were awarded to submariners.

From the start of the submarine programme, a total of 174 submarines have been lost - the majority during the two



World Wars. The last submarine to sink was in 1971 when HMS Artemis sank alongside the jetty at HMS Dolphin

during refuelling.



Until the 1950s, submarines were propelled by conventional means, a diesel engine driving a generator and, in some

cases, propelling the submarine on the surface and an electric motor drawing power from a battery to propel the

submarine when dived.



In the 1950s, the US developed submarine nuclear propulsion and in 1958, with Cold War tensions increasing,

agreed to transfer the technology and one nuclear propulsion plant complete with its nuclear fuel to the UK. The

nuclear propulsion plant was installed in the UK’s first nuclear submarine, HMS Dreadnought.



In 1994 the decision was taken by the government that the UK submarine force would become all nuclear.

Currently the UK operates 2 main classes of submarine, the Vanguard and Astute.The UK’s Vanguard class of



submarine currently provides the strategic nuclear deterrent force, armed with Trident nuclear missiles and will be

replaced by new Dreadnought class submarines.

name: FLEET AIR ARM
description:
British naval flying started in 1909, with the construction of an airship for naval duties. In 1911 the Royal Navy

graduated its first aeroplane pilots at the Royal Aero Club flying ground at RAF Eastchurch.



In 1912, naval and army aviation were combined to become the Royal Flying Corps (RFC). The Naval Wing of the RFC

lasted until July 1914 when the Royal Navy reformed its air branch, under the Air Department of the Admiralty,

naming it the Royal Naval Air Service (RNAS).



By the outbreak of the First World War, in August 1914, the RNAS had more aircraft under its control than the

remaining RFC. The roles of the RNAS were fleet reconnaissance, patrolling coasts for enemy ships and submarines

and attacking enemy coastal territory.



In April 1918 the RNAS, which at this time had 67,000 officers and men, 2,949 aircraft, 103 airships and 126 coastal

stations, merged with the RFC to form the Royal Air Force.



In 1924, the Fleet Air Arm of the Royal Air Force was formed, encompassing those RAF units that normally embarked

on aircraft carriers and fighting ships. The year was significant for British naval aviation as only weeks before the

founding of the Fleet Air Arm, the Royal Navy had commissioned HMS Hermes, the world's first ship to be designed

and built as an aircraft carrier.



In 2009 the Royal Navy celebrated the centenary of Naval Aviation, and the memorial honours the sacrifice made by 6,749

men and women who gave their lives in the service of naval aviation over those 100 years.



Over 80% of front-line Fleet Air Arm Squadrons are currently deployed on operations round the world.

The memorial is a sculptured plinth of Portland Stone supporting a granite aircraft carrier. The inscription on the base is taken



from Psalm 139 in the Bible. Inscribed in the border surrounding the memorial are the names of various organisations that are

part of the Fleet Air Arm.

name: THE ROYAL MARINES
description:
The Corps was established in 1755 but their origins can be traced back to 1664

The Marines were formed as the Royal Navy's infantry troops and were granted the "Royal" prefix by King George III



in 1802, symbolised by the Lion and Crown of their badge.

Their motto is 'Per Mare, Per Terram", which translates as "By Sea, By Land". They have been involved in every



conflict since WW2.

Ships’ Captains would always refer to the Royal Marines as "My Marines"; this is because, unlike the Royal Navy, the



Marines have never mutinied.

This memorial is of Dartmoor granite to represent the one part of the country that most Royal Marines will associate with



their training.

The Corps was established in 1755 but their origins can be traced back to 28 October 1664 when they were initially created



as the Duke of York and Albany’s Maritime Regiment of Foot.

The Marines became the Royal Marines in 1802, an honour conferred by King George III, symbolised by the Lion and Crown



on their badge. Many brave men and their families are remembered in this reflective place.

Any family that wishes to place a brass plaque on the benches, so that a loved one is remembered by name, can do so



through the Royal Marines Association.

name: WOODEN MINESWEEPERS
description:
As with all minesweeping vessels including the RNPS trawlers; these small warships were made from wood because many

WW2 mines were magnetic and, therefore, attracted to metal.



The memorial plaque is dedicated to the men who served on the wooden minesweepers built to sweep the mines laid close to shore

between 1941 – 1959. The memorial acknowledges the people of Shelburne, Lunenburg and Metaghan for their hospitality to the

British Crews who joined 122 MSF built in Nova Scotia.

name: TON CLASS MINESWEEPERS
description:
116 of these little ships were built and were known as the "Ton" class because they were all named after a town or

village finishing in the word 'Ton", e.g. Castleton, Kirkliston.



Although their superstructure was made from aluminium and other non-ferromagnetic materials, yet again, their

hulls were made from wood, in this case mahogany planking; however, the final one, HMS Wilton, built in 1971, was

made completely of fibre glass.



Their role was to detect and destroy surface and seabed mines in shallow coastal waters, rivers, ports and harbours

and they were deployed all over the globe.



The Ton Class Memorial Plaque was dedicated in proud and affectionate memory of the 117 Minehunters of the Ton Class,

and the generations of young officers and men who served in all corners of the globe between 1953 and 1993. The plaque

also commemorates the men of HMS Fittleton who lost their lives on 20 September 1976.



HM King Charles, while Prince of Wales, served as CO of HMS Bronington during the 1970s.

An additional a plaque commemorates an oak tree grown by Bryan Player in Solihull who picked up an acorn on the Meridian



Line at Greenwich Royal Park in 1987 at the founding of The Ton Class Association. It was planted at the Arboretum on 10

September 2000.



CAPTAIN SIR TOM MOORE WAY (FAR EAST) Knowledge Pack

name: THE SIKH MEMORIAL
description:
The bust on our right commemorates the 124,245 Sikh soldiers who fought with the British forces during the 4 years of

WW1.



Although only about 1% of the Indian population at that time were Sikhs, they made up about 20% of the British Indian

Army and were highly regarded for their fighting abilities.



Sikhs also fought alongside the Allies in WW2 of course.



The medals are - 8-pointed star is the Indian Order of Merit; then The 1914 Star; The British War Medal; The Victory

Medal. The last 3 came to be known as Pip, Squeak and Wilfred after the newspaper cartoon characters.

name: OVERSEAS MILITARY AND POLICE FORCES’ MEMORIALS
description:
On the corner here, we have memorials for a number of overseas Police and Military Forces with British involvement.

We have memorials to the Hong Kong Police and Kenya Police and on the opposite side of Yeomanry Avenue we have

Northern Rhodesia (now Zambia), British South Africa and Nyasaland



On our right, the memorial for Rhodesian African Rifles and Rhodesia Native Regiment is built to resemble a section of

the Great Zimbabwe Ruins, an abandoned city which was probably the capital of the Kingdom of Zimbabwe in the 14th

Century.



It is now a World Heritage site and of course Southern Rhodesia became Zimbabwe again in 1980.

name: SULTAN OF OMAN’S ARMED FORCES MEMORIAL
description:
The truncated pyramid-shaped plinth with its map, inscription and badge, form a memorial in recognition of all who served

in or supported the Armed Forces of the Sultanate of Oman.



Since their formal establishment in the early 1950s,with British assistance, these forces have twice overcome insurgencies

which have threatened the integrity or social structure of the state and, more recently, have contributed contingents or

facilities to coalitions formed to protect the Persian Gulf states. They still have a close relationship with the British Military.

name: BALUCH REGIMENT
description:
Raised in 1820 as a Regiment of Indian Native Infantry, they served in both the First and Second World Wars. Planted in

2002, the grove commemorates all those who served the Crown with the Baluch Regiment.

name: ROYAL MALAYSIA POLICE MEMORIAL
description:
The memorial is dedicated to all ranks of the former Malayan, Singaporean and Bornean Police Forces, subsequently united

into the Royal Malaysia Police.



All these forces served in the Second World War and subsequent counterinsurgency campaigns fighting alongside

Commonwealth military forces between 1948 and 1989.



In the ‘Malayan Emergency’, the Royal Malaysia Police suffered 1,300 fatalities.

name: MALAY VOLUNTEER FORCE MEMORIAL
description:
The Malayan Volunteers Group, mostly children of volunteers with some veterans, was formed in 2005 to commemorate

and raise awareness of the Malayan volunteers in the Malayan Campaign and captivity 1941 – 1945.



Some 18,000 volunteers of different races and creeds served in the Malayan Volunteer Forces, Medical Auxiliary Service

and Observer Corps, receiving 100 Campaign Awards.



In captivity, they contributed practical and medical skills, knowledge of local languages and secret radios, saving lives and

giving hope of victory. Others taught in ‘Changi University’.

name: MALAYA AND BORNEO VETERANS’ MEMORIAL
description:
This memorial is dedicated to the many thousands of men who fought in Malaysia, Borneo, Singapore and Brunei.



The large granite stone is expected to last 2000 years, providing a lasting memorial to the estimated 30,000 men who fought

in the Second World War, the Malayan Emergency, the Confrontation and further conflicts in southeast Asia.



It is intended as a place of quiet reflection for thousands of men and their families, remembering those who made the

ultimate sacrifice and those who have departed subsequent to the end of hostilities.

name: 17th DOGRA REGIMENT MEMORIAL
description:
The Dogra Regiment was raised in 1887 from the foothills of the Himalayas and earned laurels for valour in both World

Wars, including Nunshigam, Imphal and Kota Bharu in the Second World War Burma campaign.

name: THE BRIGADE OF GURKHAS’ MEMORIAL
description:
Gurkhas have served the British Crown for over 200 years. It is a rich heritage marked by excellence and sacrifice. The

names of over 400 Gurkhas appear on the Armed Forces Memorial.



The history of the Brigade from its inception in 1815 during the early wars between the Honourable East India Company

and city-state of Gorkha, through the early Afghan wars, the two World Wars, the almost continuous post-war conflicts to

modern day Afghanistan, is forged from the deep feeling of mutual respect and admiration developed between the British

and their Gurkha adversaries.



Following the Nepal Wars, and under the terms of the Sugauli Peace Treaty in 1816, Gurkhas were permitted to volunteer

for service in the East India Company’s Army. From these volunteers were formed the first regiments of the Gurkha

Brigade,and from this time stems Britain’s friendship with Nepal, a country which has proved a staunch ally ever since and

has become our ‘oldest ally’ in Asia.



Since 1997, the Brigade of Gurkhas has been operationally and battle proven in Bosnia, Kosovo, East Timor, Sierra Leone,

Macedonia and Iraq.



With 11 years of continuous Gurkha deployments in Afghanistan, the human cost and sacrifice in Afghanistan has been

high. Fifty four officers and soldiers of the Brigade have been wounded in action and 15 have died.



The memorial takes the form of a traditional chautara, a traditional resting place for travellers on hillside trails in Nepal. The

plaque incorporates the badges of the units of the Brigade, past and present.

name: BRITISH KOREAN VETERANS’ MEMORIAL
description:
There is still great interest in this site as many of those who took part are still alive. The conflict between North and South

Korea is of course still ongoing and newsworthy.



In 1950, 22 member nations of the United Nations (UN) joined South Korean forces to repel the North Korean and communist

Chinese aggression.



During the three years of the conflict, some four million people died. Over 100,000 British Service personnel served during

the war, of whom over 2,000 were killed or taken prisoner. Among the many decorations awarded were four Victoria Crosses

and two George Crosses.



In 1952, the Commonwealth units from Australia, Canada, India, New Zealand and South Africa combined to form the 1st

Commonwealth Division.



The memorial garden, originally laid out and maintained by members of the British Korean Veterans Association (BKVA), is

designed to create a living memorial to all British Service Personnel who served and gave their lives. It is an arboretum

within an arboretum, planted with more than 100 trees of some 27 different species, mostly of Korean or Asian origin.



The bronze plaques on the large boulders give a brief history of the Service Units involved together with the dates and

locations of the various battles and actions.



An arboretum within an arboretum to form a living memorial to all British servicemen and women who served in the Korean

War. It represents the continuing friendship between ourselves and South Korea, but also reminds us that this conflict was



fought under the flag of the United Nations. Originally planted with over 150 trees of 27 different varieties, mostly of Korean

or Asian origin. Five boulders of rock in a semi-circle have brass plaques attached giving a time-line of events during this



conflict and the armed forces involved. There are 3. flagpoles, which normally fly the standards of the UK, South Korea and

the United Nations. An information board explains the conflict in more detail, together with an illustrated map.

name: SUEZ VETERANS
description:
The Armed Forces Veterans who served in the Suez Canal Zone during the 1950’s are remembered on the corner of the

avenue here. We have this lovely pyramid, palm trees and the Suez Canal itself is represented by the blue channel.



You will see from the board that many of the bases were RAF and although we generally regard 1956 as the year of the

‘Suez Crisis’, the troubles actually began as early as 1951, when an Egyptian policy of non-cooperation with the British

began.



This led to acts of sabotage and guerrilla attacks on British personnel and their families.



The information board half-way down gives a timeline of British involvement in Egypt.



Being posted to Egypt was generally regarded by members of our Armed Forces as ‘The worst posting in the world!’



Dedicated in 2004



It is rich in symbolism from the Suez Canal region



This includes palm trees, a thin blue line of glass representing the canal and a pyramid shaped monument



The Suez Emergency was from 16 October 1951 to 19 October 1954 and servicemen were deemed to be on “active service”



This service was not recognised by the award of a General Service Medal until 2003

name: LISBON MARU
description:
