The Lisbon Maru Memorial was erected in memory of the 828 victims who died in one of the worst war crimes perpetrated

by the Japanese during World War Two. British prisoners of war captured at the fall of Hong Kong were being transported

to Japan to work as slaves. After their ship was torpedoed the Japanese rescued their own troops but locked the POWs in

the holds leaving them to drown, and shot at those who managed to break out.



In 1942 the Japanese began sending POWs from their captured territories to Japan to work as slave labour in various

industries so as to free up the workforce to be enlisted into the armed forces. The second shipment of POWs from Hong

Kong was on the Lisbon Maru.



On 27 September 1942 the Lisbon Maru, a Japanese armed freighter with Japanese troops on board, sailed from Hong

Kong bound for Japan. It also carried 1,816 British prisoners of war held in atrocious conditions. Cramped, airless, and in

unimaginable squalor they were incarcerated below deck in three cargo holds. The freighter bore no markings to indicate

their presence.



On 1 October an American submarine, the USS Grouper, on patrol off the Zhoushan archipelago in the East China Sea,

engaged the Lisbon Maru holing it below the waterline with a torpedo. Although initially taken under tow, the line snapped

and the ship drifted and foundered. The Japanese evacuated their troops, battened down the hatches over the holds and

left a guard force to prevent the prisoners from escaping. For 24 hours the prisoners were held in sub-human conditions in

darkness with no food, water, fresh air or sanitation; and dysentery was rife.



There was a breakout before the ship sank the next day and many of the prisoners of war escaped from the two forward

holds, some of whom were cut down by machine-gun fire. Most of those in the third hold, by then below the waterline,

tragically drowned.



Those who did escape were shot at in the water as they attempted to swim to the shore; many were killed or wounded but

local Chinese fishermen courageously rescued 384 of the survivors. Later, the Japanese recaptured all but three.



Of the original 1,816 men on board 828 died in this terrible atrocity and a further 200 or more succumbed from their sufferings

within a few months.

name: CHANGI LYCHGATE
description:
This is the original Lych Gate from Changi Jail, Singapore, designed by Captain C.D. Pickersgill and built in 1942 by Royal

Engineers from the 18th Division who were prisoners of war.



The gate was first erected at the entrance to the camp cemetery to mark the graves of those who had died and to give

their funerals some dignity. In 1952, the graves were moved to Kranji War Memorial Cemetery and the Lych Gate to the

British Garrison Church, St George’s, in Singapore.



When British troops withdrew completely from Singapore in 1971, the Lych Gate was dismantled and brought back to

England where it was erected at the Queen’s Division Depot, Bassingbourn Barracks in Royston, Hertfordshire.



In 2003, the refurbished Lych Gate was reconstructed at the Arboretum by the 39th Engineering Regiment and the re dedication took place on 8 February 2004.



In the structure of the Lych Gate was carved the national emblems of the British Isles. Inside the eaves, in Gothic lettering,

is an inscription:



‘To the Glory of God



And in memory of those



Who laid down their lives



For their King and Country’.



The idea of a Lych Gate, familiar to prisoners from churchyards back in England, gave some feeling of dignity and respect

for those who had died in appalling conditions. The Lych Gate is set in an area heavy with symbolism. It is the entrance now

to the Far East Prisoners of War Grove. Most of the trees here are dedicated to individual FEPOWs, with some mentioning

groups, such as the civilian and military women and children who perished and all the FEPOWs lost at sea while being

transported.

name: SUMATRA/BURMA RAILWAYS
description:
The reason that the Japanese built the Burma and Sumatra railways is because many of their merchant ships were being

sunk by American submarines. The Japanese therefore needed a supply route across land.

name: SUMATRA RAILWAY
description:
Sumatra connected Muaro with Pekanbaru



Like the Burma railway, the Sumatra Railway was built in extremely unhealthy, brutal conditions. About 5,000 Allied

POW’s and 30,000 local people were forced to take part in the construction and many thousands lost their lives.



It took 9 months to construct; was 140 miles long; 700 POWs and 25,000 local slaves died (known as Romusha).



This display shows the methods used in its construction.



The railway was finished on the day the war ended, August 15th, 1945 which is now known as VJ Day and was only ever

used to transport the prisoners out of Sumatra on their way home.

name: BURMA RAILWAY
description:
This 30-metre stretch of track was bought back from Burma to form the memorial here at the National Memorial

Arboretum.



Construction started in June 1942 and after 18 months the 415km (257 miles) of railway was finished. The POW’s and

Asian labourers, many of whom were Indians who had gone to Burma to work for the British, had to work long hours in

extreme conditions and with little food.



Over 330,000 men worked on the railway. Around 16,000 POW’s and 100,000 labourers lost their lives. It has been said

that one person died for each sleeper that was laid.



Burma railway actually took 16 months to build, 2 months faster than engineers estimated. This was because the

Japanese pushed the workers to the absolute limit.



The railway ran between Bangkok in Thailand to Rangoon in Burma, 600 bridges had to be constructed and bridge

number 277 was the infamous bridge over the River Kwai.



When this piece of track arrived here one of our Volunteers traced its origins only to find that it was actually

manufactured in Middlesbrough! (There are embossed markings on the inside of the left-hand rail, just past the 9th

sleeper).

name: ROYAL NORFOLK Regt; SUFFOLK Regt; CAMBRIDGESHIRE Regt;
description:
The Norfolk and Suffolk Regiments can both trace their history back to 1685, when they were formed to suppress a

rebellion.



They underwent a number of re-organisations and changes of role over the years, but eventually came together in 1959

as the 1st East Anglian Regiment. They were finally disbanded in 1967.



The Cambridgeshire Regiment was more of a Territorial Army or volunteers’ regiment, dating back to 1860 but was also

disbanded in 1967.



Many of them were in Singapore at the time of its surrender in 1942 and spent the rest of the war as prisoners of the

Japanese, with the awful conditions and experiences that we now know about.



Their lineage is carried on today in the Royal Anglian Regiment.

name: THE CHINDITS
description:
An obelisk in memory of the multi-national force which became known as ‘The Chindits’. On top it has a bronze Chinthe,

a mythical beast which guarded Burmese temples, from which derived the name Chindits.



The Chindits were the largest of the allied Special Forces of WW2. They were formed and led by Major General Orde

Wingate DSO.



The Chindits operated deep behind enemy lines in North Burma in the War against Japan with the intention of preventing

supplies being transported to the battlefront.



For many months they lived in and fought the enemy in the jungles, totally relying on airdrops for their supplies. They

had some successes but suffered greatly from the climate and constant shortage of supplies. Few of them were fit for

further service after emerging from the jungle. Listed on brass plaques affixed to the sides are those regiments and units

from which the Chindits drew personnel.

name: BURMA STAR MEMORIAL
description:
The 15ft tall monolith is a copy of the one that stands at the Commonwealth War Grave Cemetery in Kohima, on the

border of India with Burma, which saw some of the fiercest fighting of the Burma campaign, but is where the Japanese

advance was finally halted.



It is intended to pay tribute to ALL organisations, armed forces and individuals who hold either the Burma Campaign Star

or the Pacific Star with Burma Clasp.



On the memorial is the famous Kohima Epitaph that has been used around the world on memorials and at remembrance

services:



‘WHEN YOU GO HOME



TELL THEM OF US AND SAY



FOR YOUR TOMORROW



WE GAVE OUR TODAY’



The words are attributed to John Maxwell Edmonds (1875 -1958), an English Classicist, who had put

them together among a collection of 12 epitaphs for World War One, in 1916.

According to the Burma Star Association the words were used for the Kohima Memorial as a suggestion

by Major John Etty-Leal, the GSO II of the 2nd Division, another classical scholar

The verse is thought to have been inspired by the Greek lyric poet Simonides of Ceos (556-468 BC) who

wrote after the Battle of Thermopylae in 480 BC:



"Go tell the Spartans, thou that passest by,

That faithful to their precepts here we lie."



ROTARY INTERNATIONAL & ROTARY RIDGE

name: ROTARY INTERNATIONAL MEMORIAL
description:
Founded in 1905, the Rotary International is a movement of Men and Women who come together to create positive lasting

change in our communities around the world. The organisation is currently present in over 200 countries.

name: ROTARY RIDGE
description:
The hedge of golden Castlewellan cypress that acts as a windbreak and backdrop to the Arboretum, was first sponsored by

local clubs in Rotary District 1060 as a tribute to the Rotary Clubs in Great Britain and Ireland and Rotary International,

whose motto is “Service above Self”.



Trees are also dedicated to individual clubs and Rotarians.



Local Rotary Clubs have enthusiastically supported the Arboretum from the early years with individual Rotarians

volunteering their skills, business contacts and expertise in many fields.

name: THE CHINTHE WOMEN
description:
The plaque here remembers a group of Ladies known as the Women's Auxiliary Service (Burma) who operated static

and mobile canteens for our troops during WW2 in Burma, supplying tea, cakes and cigarettes.



These women had been working in the Far East when war broke out but opted to stay there. They set up mobile

canteens close to the front line.



The image on the plaque is of a 'Chinthe', a mythical beast which guards Burmese Temples, from which the Ladies took

their nickname.

name: HONG KONG VOLUNTEER DEFENCE CORPS
description:
The light grey plaque belongs to the Hong Kong Volunteer Defence Corps, formed in 1854 and consisting of infantry,

artillery, engineers, medical and other trades.



During WW2 the corps numbered over 2,000 volunteers. They stood down in 1945.

name: SUEZ MARU MEMORIAL
description:
Here we have the brick memorial for those who died in 1943 when the Suez Maru, a Japanese transport ship carrying

British and Dutch prisoners of war, was torpedoed by an American submarine. Some prisoners escaped the sinking but

were then shot in the water by the Japanese.



The pillar consists of 414 limestone cubes, one for each of the British prisoners who died.



‘Maru’ means merchant ship.



The second cairn lists the names of the 26 Japanese merchant ships carrying prisoners of war and/or civilians on what

became known as ‘HELL SHIPS’, that were sunk by Allied action with the loss of more than 19,000 lives. It includes the

Suez Maru, giving a figure of 546 casualties which includes those who were other than British (mostly Dutch).



The wooden crosses around the edge give the location of military cemeteries. The top name is the country or island

where it is situated and the lower name that of the cemetery itself.

name: THE FEPOW MEMORIAL BUILDING
description:
Fundraising for the museum started on the 15th February 2002, the 60 th anniversary of the surrender of Singapore to the

Japanese, which is when the majority of FEPOWs were captured. The majority of funding was raised by an organisation

called COFEPOW (Children of Far East Prisoners of War).



COFEPOW came about after a lady named Carol Cooper, from Norfolk, read an article in a newspaper in 1994,

concerning the diary of a former prisoner-of-war of the Japanese. She realised that this was the diary of her father who

went to fight in the Far East when she was only 2 years old but had died working on the Burma railway.



After receiving a transcript of the diary, she went to Burma in an attempt to find his grave. Her journey was made into a

documentary by the BBC.



Many other children and relatives of such prisoners then contacted Carol and COFEPOW was formed in 1997.



It took 3½ years to raise the funds, the same amount of time that the FEPOWs spent in the horrendous conditions of the

prison camps.



The building was officially opened on VJ Day 2005 the 60th anniversary of the end of the war in South East Asia.



It is designed to take the shape of a prison hut. Inside there are exhibits and artefacts covering the experiences of the

servicemen and civilians who were taken prisoner.



In the far right-hand corner of the museum is a copy of the Java Windows. These are replicas of the two made by a

British Naval officer whilst a prisoner]and were situated in a small chapel that the Japanese allowed them to have, mainly

for propaganda purposes.



A close inspection of the British coat of arms will reveal that the lion has the face of Winston Churchill. Knowing that their

captors had not discovered this helped to keep up morale.



The original windows still survive today and can be found in All Saints Church in Jakarta, Indonesia.



Also, look for the names being projected onto the wall at the end of the museum. This is a list of all those who were

imprisoned, including the survivors and you can search for individual names using the touch screen.



On another touch screen, data held by the Commonwealth War Graves Commission can be accessed.

name: RAF
description:
The Battle of Britain in 1940 started on 10 July till 31 October (3 months and 3weeks).



In 1940 Hitler ordered his armed forces to prepare for an invasion of Britain (code name Operation 'Sealion'), but he had to take

control of the skies over southern England for his plan to succeed.



The RAF were determined to defeat the German Luftwaffe, although the Luftwaffe had more planes. We managed to win the battle

in the air, our secret weapon was Radio Direction Finding which we had developed since 1930, better known as Radar, which saw

Hitler’s Germany abandoning their invasion plan.



Aircraft used against the Luftwaffe - the iconic fighter planes the Spitfire and the Hurricane. Around 3,000 men of the RAF took part

and men came from all over the Commonwealth and Europe to support the RAF in securing Victory.



But Victory could not have been achieved without the support of The Observer Corp, Women's Auxiliary Air Force (WAAF), Civil

Defence, Ack Ack girls and the Home Guard.



Unfortunately, Victory came at a cost of around 1500 air crew killed and in excess of 1100 aircraft destroyed. (numbers vary); Average

age of pilots 20 years.



Referred to by Winston Churchill as "The Few".



The 3-armed bushes represent the propeller blades of a Spitfire, with a walnut tree nearby as the centre boss and blades of an early

Spitfire propeller were made of walnut wood. The Aircrew Association memorial is in memory of the Air Crews of WW2.



The two groups of silver birch trees represent the wings of aircraft – one wing for Bomber Command and one for Fighter Command.



The blue circular plaque next to it lists 60 trades, such as mechanics, welders, fitters etc., performed by ladies of the Women’s

Auxiliary Air Force.

name: No. 30 Squadron (transport - the black bell shaped one);
The Aircrew association
description:
memorial is in memory of the Air Crews of WW2. The 3-armed bushes represent the propeller blades of a

Spitfire, with a walnut tree nearby as the centre boss and blades of an early Spitfire propeller was made of

walnut wood.

name: Royal Air Forces Association
description:
An organization offering friendship, help and support to past & present members of the RAF,Commonwealth Air

Forces and their families.



Of particular note is ‘Winston’ the eagle, Winston is made from over 1,000 stainless steel feathers and is

surrounded by a segmented RAF roundel.

name: RAF Police
description: Known as Snowdrops because of their white caps

name: WAAF memorial
description:
The blue circular plaque next to it lists 60 trades, such as mechanics, welders, fitters etc., performed by ladies



of the Women’s Auxiliary Air Force.

name: No. 31 Squadron
description:
Which has been in existence now for over 100 years. They are currently based at RAF Marham in Norfolk, flying



Tornado aircraft.

name: Flt. Lt J W Lucas DFC
The Royal auxiliary Air force
description:
Similar to the Territorial Army, whose members receive payment for keeping up to date with training and may



be called up for active service.

name: Royal Canadian Air Force
description:
It is made of three pieces of granite in the colours of their national flag, red, white, red. With their national



emblem of a maple leaf on the top, it is designed that on the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month, if the



sun is shining, the leaf on the top of the memorial casts a shadow on a corresponding maple leaf set into the



grass.



High Flight - Pilot officer John Gillespie Magee, Jr



"Oh! I have slipped the surly bonds of Earth

And danced the skies on laughter-silvered wings;

Sunward I’ve climbed, and joined the tumbling mirth

of sun-split clouds, — and done a hundred things

You have not dreamed of — wheeled and soared and swung

High in the sunlit silence. Hov’ring there,

I’ve chased the shouting wind along, and flung

My eager craft through footless halls of air....



Up, up the long, delirious, burning blue

I’ve topped the wind-swept heights with easy grace.

Where never lark, or even eagle flew —

And, while with silent, lifting mind I've trod

The high untrespassed sanctity of space,

Put out my hand, and touched the face of God."



This poem is to be found on the Royal Canadian Air Force Memorial.



John Gillespie Magee, Jr was born in Shanghai on 9th June 1922 to an American father and British mother.

He joined the RCAF in October 1940 and was killed at the age of 19 in a mid air collision while flying a

Spitfire of 412 Squadron on 11th December 1941. He is buried in Holy Cross Cemetery, Scopwick in

Lincolnshire. The poem High Flight is the official poem of the RCAF and is displayed on panels at the

Canadian War Museum in Ottawa.

ARMY PARADE KNOWLEDGE PACK 2023

name: ROYAL SCOTS (THE ROYAL REGIMENT)
description:
The memorial commemorates the Royal Scots Regiment formed in 1633. The oldest and senior infantry regiment in the British



Army until its amalgamation in 2006, with the other Scottish Infantry Regiments to form The Royal Regiment of Scotland. As the



senior line infantry Regiment, the memorial was a significant commemorative event for the Arboretum supported by the Regiment’s



Trustees. Designed by Lt Col (Retired) Gordon Vevers. The design statement is ‘strong, powerful and dignified’, personified by



the Scottish Granite from which the memorial is made. The memorial was dedicated in October 2021.

name: LONDON SCOTTISH REGIMENT
description:
Founded in 1859 as a volunteer force sponsored by the Highland Society of London and now part of the London Regiment. One



of their nicknames is ‘The Cockney Jocks’. They were the first Territorial infantry to see action in WW I at Messines Ridge



31/10/1914. In its final incarnation it was A (The London Scottish) Company, the London Regiment, until on 1 April 2022, soldiers



in the company transferred to foot guards regiments and the company became G (Messines) Company, Scots Guards. Three



members of the Regiment have been awarded a VC. The memorial was dedicated in March 2019.

name: THE GORDON HIGHLANDERS
description:
The Gordon Highlanders have existed for 113 years: 1794-1994, their motto is ‘Byband’ meaning steadfast. The regiment took



part in the attempt to relieve Major Charles Gordon at Khartoum. They were amalgamated with The Queens' Own Highlanders



(Seaforth and Camerons) on 17 September 1994 to form the Highlanders (Seaforth, Gordons and Camerons). The Speyside



sculptor – Stuart Murdoch, carved the design from granite local to the regiments home intending to make a clearly identifiable



statement of strength and durability. The memorial was installed on 26th June 2020.

name: THE LIVERPOOL SCOTTISH
description:
Founded in 1859 as a volunteer force sponsored by the Highland Society of London. They have seen action in both WWs and conflicts since. They



now form part of The London Regiment, one of their nicknames "Cockney Jocks". Interestingly from 1953-2002 the Pipe Major of The London Scottish



held the prestigious position of "Piper to the Queen Mother".



Known as ‘The Scottish’, the regiment was raised in 1900 as an infantry battalion of the King’s (Liverpool Regiment) and later affiliated with the



Queens own Cameron Highlanders, hence the name 'Liverpool Scottish'. The most decorated member was Captain NG Chavasse VC & Bar,



who was awarded a VC for saving the lives of some twenty badly wounded men in no-mans land at Guillemont in WW I, his plaque can be



seen in the RAMC Avenue. The Liverpool Scottish lineage came to an end, on 30 April 2014, when the last surviving platoon was disbanded,



and personnel re-affiliated entirely to the Duke of Lancaster's Regiment. The memorial was dedicated in July 2022.

name: THE CHESHIRE REGIMENT EVER GLORIOUS’
description:
The Regiment was formed in 1689 by Henry Howard, 7th Duke of Norfolk as the ‘Duke of Norfolk's Regiment of Foot.’



During the intervening 300 years, it spent much time on garrison duty in the Empire (Europe and the Americas).. At Dettingen

(1743) it won the distinction of wearing the oak leaf whilst parading for Royalty and also on certain Regimental days. The story is

that the 22nd protected the king, who was commanding the field, from being taken prisoner by the French. The king picked a sprig

of oak from a nearby tree and presented it to them.



In 1751 the Regimental was renamed, The 22nd Regiment of Foot.



In 1782 all British Regiments without Royal titles were assigned a county title in order to aid recruitment, therefore the Regiment

became the 22nd (Cheshire) Regiment of Foot and later in 1881 re – titled The Cheshire Regiment



During the course of the First World War, The Regiment was awarded 75 Battle Honours and 2 Victoria Crosses losing 8,413

men.



In WW2 the 1st the Battalion served in North Africa, Malta and North West Europe . The 2nd Battalion was evacuated



from Dunkirk before fighting in North Africa, Sicily and Italy. It then landed on D-Day and fought in the North West Europe



campaign.



Following WW2 the 1st Battalion has served in numerous operational areas: Malaya, Cyprus, Northern Ireland, Bosnia under the

United Nations and Iraq.



In 2007 the Regiment was amalgamated in with the Staffordshire and Worcestershire & Sherwood Regiments to form the Mercian

Regiment the 1st Battalion, The Mercian Regiment (Cheshire).



The memorial consists of a 2 foot plinth displaying the 138 battle honours and holds a large stone cut from a Sycamore quarry in

Cheshire. The stone is flanked on both sides by steel cut-outs of soldiers representing the Regiments formation in1689 and

amalgamation in 2007. It was dedicated in October 2022.

name: 14TH / 20TH KINGS HUSSARS (THE HAWKS) MEMORIAL
description:
Regiment is involved in tank training, armoured cars and tank destroyers.



The ex-member’s club of the regiment is nicknamed ‘Noah’s Arc.’ (National Old and Ancient Hawks Annual Reunion Club).



Sculpture / artist Alan Williams (who specialises in re-purposing scrap metal).



Memorial is the regimental Hawk (‘also known as the Prussian Eagle’), made using items from the scrap bins of Tidworth Camp

army barracks (tools, cogs, gears, nuts & bolts), set within a stone obelisk. The oval hole was cut through black granite by hand

and has a 4cm glass rod running through the hole.



The Prussian Eagle is the insignia of the Royal House of Prussia and was awarded to the 14th Light Dragoons in 1798 by the

Crown Princess Frederica of Prussia.



Princess Royal is the Colonel-in-Chief; the regiment forms part of the Royal Armoured Corp.



Memorial was dedicated October 2022, almost exactly 100 years to the day since the formation of the regiment.

name: ULSTER SPECIAL CONSTABULARY
description:
The black marble monolith pays tribute to those who served, but especially those who lost their lives during the period of

‘the troubles’.



The Ulster Special Constabulary was formed originally in 1920 and was intended to be a reserve, or ‘back up’ service for

the Royal Ulster Constabulary, whose memorial we will see shortly.



The Special Constabulary was stood down in 1970.

name: ROYAL ULSTER CONSTABULARY AND PSNI
description:
The Royal Ulster Constabulary was renamed The Police Service Northern Ireland in 2001 and the PSNI memorial is the

tall black tablet on our right.



The 6 blocks of stone to our front were quarried from the 6 counties and are placed to form a symbolic map of Northern

Ireland (Ulster). They commemorate, in particular, the 312 Police Officers who lost their lives to terrorist action, and many

thousands who were injured or maimed during the period from 1922 - 2001.



The RUC was awarded a collective George Cross and the pathway is known as the RUC George Cross Way. It is lined

with 38 Yew trees, representing 38 police subdivisions in the Province, as named on the stone plaques as you walk along.



.The George Cross (GC) is the highest award bestowed by the British government for non-operational gallantry or gallantry

not in the presence of an enemy.



The first stone bench on the left was placed by the RUC Widows Association.

name: ULSTER ASH GROVE
description:
The grove of ash trees has been planted as a living tribute to those members of the RUC, the RUC Reserve, the Armed

Forces and other organisations who lost their lives during the period of ‘the troubles’ between 1969 - 2001.



Many of the names appearing on dedication plaques in the Grove will also be found engraved on the walls of our Armed

Forces Memorial.



Further inside the Grove is a small memorial for the 29 Prison Officers murdered in Ulster during that time.

name: ULSTER DEFENCE REGIMENT
description:
The standing stone to the right commemorates members of this regiment, a branch of the British Army, which was formed

in 1970 and whose official role was the ‘defence of life or property in Northern Ireland against armed attack or sabotage’.



193 men and 4 women from the regiment were killed during ‘the troubles’, many of them in their own homes o r at work.



63 former members of the regiment were also killed.



The UDR was merged into the Royal Irish Regiment in 1992.



In 2006 the Queen awarded the regiment a collective Conspicuous Gallantry Cross (CGC).

name: The Ulster Defence Regiment Conspicuous Gallantry Cross (CGC)
description:
In 2007 the CGC was awarded to the Ulster Defence Regiment for its service in Northern Ireland.



The CGC is a second level military decoration of the British Armed Forces. Created in 1993 and first awarded in 1995, it

was instituted after a review of the British honours system to remove distinctions of rank in the awarding of gallantry

decorations. The Victoria Cross is the only higher combat gallantry award presented by the United Kingdom

name: SCOUT MEMORIAL
description:
The memorial on our left is to the Scout Movement and was funded by the members themselves. Badges were sold to

members, profits from which funded it. All sections of the Scout movement were involved in the funding, from 6-year-old

Beaver Scouts to 80 years plus Leaders and supporters.



The memorial itself is in the form of a camp fire circle which is synonymous with Scouting. Around the base of the memorial

is the story of the first Scout camp held in 1907 at Brownsea Island with the founder of the movement, Lord Baden-Powell.

Also, around the base is a list showing hundreds of countries where Scouting takes place today. Around the memorial is a

circle of stones with the campfire in the middle, designed so when viewed from above it forms the shape of a trail symbol,

"Gone Home" which appears on the gravestone of Lord Baden-Powell.



One of the youngest ever recipients of the Victoria Cross was a lad named John Cornwell. He was a boy seaman aged 16

on HMS Chester at the battle of Jutland in 1916. Before he joined the Navy, he was a Boy Scout in a troop near his home

in London and was known by all as Jack. Baden-Powell was so impressed by this young ex-Scouts courage that he

introduced a badge for valour / courage for young people in Scouting and named it The Jack Cornwell Scout Badge.

name: CHILDREN’S WOOD
description:
The owl and cockerel features relate to raising awareness of cardiac risk to young people and the need for families/carers

to bear in mind that problems of heart diseaguarse are not confined to older people and can occur at any time of day or

night.



The sculpture of a post-box, with birds in flight above it, was made by children of British armed forces personnel at their

school in Germany and represents the transient lifestyle of such families.



With the reduction in numbers of our armed forces abroad, the school was closed and the sculpture brought here.



The idea is that ‘the birds are dispersing and then finding someone they know in the next flock’, like so many children of

Service personnel over previous years/decades/centuries.

name: EDWARD’S TRUST GARDEN
description:
This wooden structure is for the Edward’s Trust, a charity which provides bereavement services, mainly for parents who

have lost a child, or children affected by a death.



The Trust was set up in 1989 by the parents of Edward Dent, who died aged just 7yrs, and is how it came to be called

‘Edward’s Trust’.



At its centre is a ‘Tree of Hope’, where parents can hang a copper leaf bearing the name of their child as an act of

remembrance.



We are now entering the children’s activity and family picnic area, where we have some features relating mainly to children

and young people:

name: DONOR FAMILY NETWORK
description:
The Memorial honours those who have donated organs and tissue to save or improve the lives of others.



It also recognises their families and patients who have received an organ transplant or whose lives have been transformed

by tissue donation.



Currently there are around 6,500 people waiting for a transplant in the UK and on average three people die every day

because of the shortage of donor organs.



The memorial was designed and created by sculptor Julia Hennessy-Priest. The Birmingham artist has spent years

perfecting the work, which is inspired by the DFN logo, a colourful mosaic butterfly representing hope and new life, on top

of a forget-me-not flower, as no organ or tissue donor will ever be forgotten.

name: EVACUEES (EVERY WHICH WAY)
description:
During WW2, the decision was taken to move a number of vulnerable people, mostly children, away from the dangers of

German bombing raids into safer areas. This was necessary as the country was at total war and later statistics showed that

more civilians than military personnel were actually killed during the conflict.



Some 3.5 million people were evacuated, and the design of this memorial conveys some of the anxiety and confusion of

the child evacuees through deliberate distortion of the figures - some hands are reversed and torsos twisted through 180

degrees.



The split open luggage represents how families were torn apart by the evacuation process.



The memorial was unveiled in the presence of the Duke of Gloucester by Michael Aspel, who was evacuated during WW2

from London to Somerset, aged 7.



The memorial remembers over 3 million evacuees, mostly young children,who were evacuated from cities to the

countryside to keep them safe from the bombing.



But it wasn't only children evacuated - Over 100,000 teachers, around 500,000 mothers with children under 5 years, 13,000

pregnant women and 70,000 people with disabilities.



The evacuation started on 1st September 1939 (code name Operation Pied Piper).



Many were billeted with families in rural communities, but also large buildings were requisitioned and some specially built

to house 200 children and teachers; lots of such buildings sprang up over the course of the war.Symbolism of the memorial

itself



Made of cast bronze, the Artist is Maurice Blik, who is a survivor of the infamous German concentration camp Bergen-

Belsen, which is the camp where Ann Frank died.



On the black granite plinth there are nine children of all ages but all carrying bags,



suitcases, boxes with gas masks and all wearing luggage labels with names on as they did all those years ago.



The names of the children on the memorial are: Prudence, Ernest, Hope, Faith, Will and Constance, the qualities and

attributes these children hopefully would develop.



The other three names are Valour, Resolute, and Defiance.



If you look at the children closely, it first appears they are holding hands, but they aren't; the hands do not touch,

symbolising the lack of human contact.



You will also notice that some hands are back to front and clothing also is back to front, again symbolising being torn away

from their families, pulled in different directions, as in the name of the memorial Every Which Way.

name: HOME FRONT MEMORIAL
description:
The term "home front" covers the activities of the civilians in a nation at war. World War II was a total war; homeland

production and sustainability became even more invaluable.



Life on the home front during World War II was a significant part of the war effort for all participants and had a major impact

on the outcome of the war. Governments became involved with new issues such as rationing, manpower allocation, home

defence, evacuation in the face of air raids, and response to occupation by an enemy power.

name: NATIONAL EX-PRISONER OF WAR ASSOCIATION
description:
The gates here remember those who were detained as prisoners of war by German forces during WW2.



They are an exact replica of the memorial built by British Army engineers near Falling bostel, Germany, where two large

‘stalags’ were located, not only to remember the POWs who finally gained their freedom in April 1945, but also to mark the

beginnings of a new friendship with the local German population.

name: RAF Benevolent Fund
description:
The RAF BF offer support to all Serving and Former Members Of The RAF, Their Partners and Dependent Children. They are

the RAF's Leading Welfare Charity With A Proud Tradition Of Looking After Our Own.

name: MILITARY MEDALLISTS’ MEMORIAL
description:
The Military Medal was first established by King George V on 25 March 1916 to award Warrant Officers and other ranks

for bravery in battle on land.



It was awarded to members of the British Army and related services such as QAIMNS when the medal could be awarded

to women after a ruling in 1916.



The Military Medal was awarded for acts of bravery that were not deemed high enough for the DSM.



In WW1 over 115,000 MMs were awarded with around 6000 bars. WW2 saw some 15,000 MMs along with 177 bars.



The medal ceased to be awarded in 1993 and was replaced by the Military Cross.



The final MMs were awarded for service in the last round of troubles in Northern Ireland between 1969-1993. (1969-2007)



The memorial recognises all who were awarded the Military Medal since its inception in 1916.



Tangent



The National Association of Tangent Clubs is one of the largest women's organisations in the UK, with around 500 Clubs

and 10,000 members. Tangent members usually meet once a month, though this varies from Club to Club. Tangent offers

a varied programme of events and activities which are unique to each individual Club, but all include a mixture of fellowship,

friendship, fun and fundraising.



The National Association of Tangent Clubs (Tangent) is part of the Round Table Family which is made up of Ladies Circle

(aged 18-45)

name: RBL Women’s Section
description:
The British Legion Women’s Section was formed in 1921 to safeguard the interests of widows and families of ex-Servicemen.



It was also to provide a way for women to be a part of the British Legion and widen its activities. The Women’s Section is

autonomous, self-funding, and also comes under the Royal Charter with Her Royal Highness the Princess Royal as the

National President.

name: SSAFA MEMORIAL
description:
SSAFA was originally formed in 1885 as the Soldiers, Sailors and Families Association. Within days of the outbreak of

WW1, SSAFA was called upon to assist the Government to ensure that families didn’t suffer hardship when the men were

called up. It was brought in to provide some of the structures and service which would automatically be provided by the

State today. It was the only national Service charity in existence at that time and was already a well-respected organisation.



The name changed in 1919 after the formation of the RAF to become Soldiers, Sailors, Airmen and Families Association

SSAFA.



Today the charity has professional staff supported by around 7,000 volunteers they help around 90,000 people every year.

name: CHELTENHAM COLLEGE
description:
The light-coloured pedestal to the left honours former students of Cheltenham College. Some 6,000 former students have

served in the armed forces and over 1,500 lost their lives.



14 Victoria Crosses have been awarded to former students, and it is one of only two non-military schools allowed to parade

the Queens Colour, the other school is Eton.

name: DUKE OF YORK'S ROYAL MILITARY SCHOOL
description:
Memorial was unveiled 18 September 2017. It commemorates all pupils of the school known as 'Dukies' who gave their

lives in service of their country. The school was founded in 1803 to provide educational opportunities to orphans and children

of soldiers made destitute as a result of the Napoleonic Wars.



Emblems associated with the school are depicted on the memorial, including The White Rose of York together with the

school colours.



It is only one of 3 schools in England that has been awarded colours in recognition of a large number of pupils who have

joined the Armed Forces.

name: THE RAILWAY INDUSTRY MEMORIAL
description:
This memorial is the celebration of the magnificent achievements of the railway family which has served the United

Kingdom with great distinction. On top of the memorial is a class F locomotive carved from matt black granite. The locomotive

was designed in 1935 by William Stanier for the London Midland and Scottish Railway Company. They were built between

1935-46.



On the rear of the memorial is a display of artwork depicting a series of railway activities.

name: THE ODDFELLOWS MEMORIAL
description:
The Oddfellows were first formed in this country in 1810, over 200 years ago. Today they have a network of 121 branches

and 309,000 members in the UK. Their aim is to improve the quality of people's lives through friendship, care and charitable

support. Like the Masons, they have their own traditions exclusive to them. Many members of the Oddfellows served in both

WWs.



After WW1 they set up the Orphan Gift Fund to care for orphaned children of their members and the fund still exists today.

Part of their insignia is a three linked chain symbolising friendship, love and truth.

name: SHACKLETON ASSOCIATION
description:
The Shackleton Association was conceived and founded in 1987 by John Botwood, who quickly assembled a dedicated

group of mainly ex RAF members who had been associated with the Avro Shackleton during their service career and who

were determined that the memory of this great aircraft should never be forgotten.

name: THE ROYAL ANTEDILUVIAN ORDER OF BUFFALOES
description:
The order was started in 1822 and is commonly known as "The Buffs". They claim to be the largest fraternal organisation

in the UK. It is now a global organisation.



RAOB aid their members, their families and dependants of former members and charitable organisations. As with all the

other fraternal organisations e.g The Free Masons, Oddfellows, they also saw service in both WWs.



In WW1 they raised money and supplied ambulances to aid the war effort and the ambulances were often driven by

volunteer Buffs. In total 22 members of this organisation were awarded Victoria Crosses.



The key values are justice, truth and philanthropy and their principle aims are friendship, charitable works, social activity,

mutual support and care.

name: CAMP BASTION MEMORIAL
description:
We start at the Camp Bastion Memorial, in remembrance of the 456 service men and women who lost their lives in

Afghanistan. It is based on the same design as the former Camp Bastion Memorial Wall in Helmand Province, Afghanistan,

which was dismantled in late 2014 following the end of combat operations



It contains elements of the original wall, such as the cross made of shell cases placed on top of the cairn, material from

the original wall in the foundations and the original memorial plaques engraved with names of the fallen, which have been

placed inside the structure to preserve them for all time.



On the reverse side is an engraved map of Afghanistan marking the locations where UK forces served during the 13-year

campaign (with a stone from each actual location).



The rededication service in June 2015 was attended by Prince Harry and the then Prime Minister, David Cameron.

name: DUNKIRK MEMORIAL
description:
The Dunkirk evacuation code name Operation Dynamo (also known as the Miracle of Dunkirk), was the evacuation of Allied soldiers

during WW2 from the beaches and harbour of Dunkirk in northern France, between 26 May and 4 June 1940.



The operation started after a large number of British, Belgium and French troops were cut off and surrounded by German troops

during the six-week battle of France.



Royal Navy ships were involved, and hundreds of small vessels went out to help in the evacuation including merchant ships, fishing

boats, pleasure craft and yachts.



On the first day of the evacuation over 7,600 were evacuated and by the last day of the operation around 338,000 had been rescued.

name: THE ROYAL WELSH
description:
The Regiment was first raised in 1689 in Wales and is therefore one of our oldest. This also explains the ancient spelling

of WELCH, which is sometimes still used.



This slate monolith weighs over 9 tons and has a time capsule buried in its top left corner giving the history of the Regiment.



The main insignia on the front of the monolith is the cap badge of the Regiment itself, while those displayed on the curved

slate wall are those of antecedent Regiments:



Royal Welch Fusiliers



South Wales Borderers



Welch Regiment



Monmouthshire Regiment



Royal Regiment of Wales



The Royal Welsh



The inscription is taken from a poem called ‘War’ by the Welsh Language poet Ellis Evans (later known as Hedd Wyn),

who was killed near Ypres on the first day of the Battle of Passchendaele in 1917.



The slate path is in the shape of the "flash", unique to this Regiment, consisting of five overlapping black silk ribbons (9

inches for Officers and 7 inches for other Ranks) on the back of the uniform jacket at neck level. This goes back to the time

when ‘pigtails’ were common, and a piece of cloth was intended to protect the uniform from greasy hair.



Each Spring the memorial is surrounded by daffodils which is the second emblem of Wales, the first being the leek.

name: BERLIN AIRLIFT MEMORIAL
description:
The Berlin blockade was one of the first major international crises of the Cold War; the Soviet Union blocked access to West Berlin

and the Soviets had control of East Berlin.



The Soviet action was in response to the American and British officials not allowing Russia more say in the economic future of

Germany.



The two million people of West Berlin could not get any food or other essential supplies when the blockade started on 24 June 1948

and it eventually finished on 12 May 1949.



So on 24 June 1948, Operation Vittles was launched; around 8,000 tons of supplies were airlifted and delivered. Every day for the

next 323 days, around 2.3 million tons of cargo were flown in by the American and British and Commonwealth Air Forces, together

with allied Air Forces.



Around 300 aircraft took part in the airlift, around 300,000 flights in all.



Eventually the Russians conceded the blockade was a failure and withdrew the blockade.



The theme of the memorial is three air corridors which created what was known as the "Air Bridge". It is symbolised by the three

elements standing proud of the main structure, and by the Berlin Airlift motif depicted on the terrace in front of the memorial

incorporating Paviours representing the 39 British and Commonwealth who died in air accidents during the operation.

name: DAVID CHILDS TREES
description:
The Founders Tree can be found in the Neville Barry Grove where you will find David Childs Tree. Neville Barry was one of the first

Groundsman to work on the site.



These two trees are dedicated to the founder of the NMA, David Childs CBE. In the late 80's David met with an old military friend,

the late Group Captain Sir Leonard Cheshire VC, and they were concerned that we, as a nation, were beginning to forget to remember

those who sacrificed so much for our freedom. David went away feeling some type of National Memorial was needed.



A few years later while in America on business for the Royal Navy, he found he had a spare day before returning home, and as he

was in Washington DC, David spent a few hours at Arlington Military Cemetery and some time at the American National Arboretum.

That's when the idea came to him of combining concepts of both those places to create a living memorial to Service and Sacrifice back

home in the UK.



And as we say the rest is history.

name: NORMANDY LANDINGS
description:
As early as 1942, the Allies had started thinking about an invasion whittled down to either the Pas-de-Calais or the bay of the Seine.



Sg Maj Stanley Hollis Green Howards awarded only VC on D- Day itself although 4 other VCs were awarded during the campaign 6 June

to 22 August..



On the surface, the Pas-de-Calais was the more attractive option - the Germans were convinced of this.



In a short window given by the weather and tides, the operation was launched on 6 June 1944 with the Normandy Landings.



Almost 7,000 vessels were involved in the huge naval effort, Operation Neptune.



Over 11,500 aircraft took part in the landings.



i. Throughout the night, RAF bombers pounded German batteries along the French coast.



ii. At daybreak 1,300 heavy bombers of the USAF took over the attack.



iii. The Royal Engineers are combat soldiers with a technical edge and have a role in every area of the battlefield. At the

front they support the rest of the Army, bridging rivers, using explosives to destroy bridges or clearing routes through

minefields. Aircraft dropped 7.2 million pounds of bombs on D Day.



Around 156,000 Allied troops landed the first day



Nearly 62,00 British soldiers -73,000 American and 21,400 Canadian



Within five days, almost 330,000 troops and over 100,000 tons of supplies had been landed



More than two million Allied troops were in France by the end of August.



This memorial is for the Normandy Landings, also known as D-Day, which started on the 6th June 1944, code named

Overlord/Neptune.



This assault was the beginning of the end of WW2 and Hitler's tyranny.



5,300 British ships and landing craft carrying 150,000 troops and 1,500 tanks landed on the first day, supported by 10,000 aircraft.



For the following 11 weeks, the battle progressed through Normandy with 60,000 allied troops killed and 200,000 wounded. A total

of about 500,000 allied troops took part.



The five large stones represent the beaches where the allied troops landed. Code named Sword, Gold (British landings) Utah, Omaha

(American landings), Juno (Canadian landings).



ASKARI MEMORIAL



Askari is a warrior of East Africa. They were formed in 1888 and served until 1964.



350,000 served the British Crown in 6 former administered territories. The statue depicts a soldier from the 1st Kings African Rifles,

wearing WW1 combat dress of 1914.

name: KING’S AFRICAN RIFLES
description:
To its left is the memorial for the KING’s AFRICAN RIFLES, whose origins date back to the 1890s. Their first major battle was against

the ‘MAD MULLAH’ in Somaliland, which lasted from 1900 – 1920. They also fought the British side in both World Wars but were

disbanded in 1964 as their home African countries had by that time gained independence from Britain.

name: ROYAL ENGINEER
description:
The garden to its left honour’s members of the ROYAL ENGINEERS. The blocks of stone are set on metal supports in a very technically

challenging way, to demonstrate the Engineers’ skills. The stones came from the Falkland Islands.



The Royal Engineers are combat soldiers with a technical edge and have a role in every area of the battlefield. At the front they support

the rest of the Army, bridging rivers, using explosives to destroy bridges or clearing routes through minefields.



The Royal Engineers trace their origins back to the military engineers brought to England by William the Conqueror and claim 900 years

of unbroken service to the Crown. However, the origins of the modern corps along with the Royal Artillery lie in the Board Of Ordnance

established in the 15th century, In1716 the board formed the Royal Regiment of Artillery and established a corps of engineers consisting

entirely of Officers



The corps has no battle honours their motto is Ubique and Quo Fas et Gloria Ducunt (Everywhere & where Right and Glory lead us)

the same as the Royal Artillery. The Motto signifies that the corps has seen action in all the major conflicts of the British army and most

of the minor ones.



In 1911 the corps formed its Air battalion the forerunner of the RFC and the RAF.



Several corps have been formed from the Royal Engineers



Royal Flying Corps



Royal Corps of Signals



REME



Royal Corps of Transport



Royal Logistic Corps



The Royal Albert Hall was designed by Captain Francis Fowke and Major-General Henry Y D Scott, Captain (later Major-General sir

Joshua Jebb) designed Pentonville prison.



55 British and Commonwealth Sappers have been awarded the Victoria Cross



Notable VC winners were:



John Merriott Rouse Chard. Officer commanding at Rorkes Drift Jan 1879



Thomas Frank Durrant. Operation chariot St Nazaire 28 March 1942 unique in that it is the only award given to a soldier in a Naval

action, and unusual in have been suggested by a German Officer.



Phillip Neave 1914 at Neuve Chapelle the only man to hold a VC and an Olympic Gold Medal.(Studied at Cheltenham College)

name: FREEMASONS
description:
Freemasonry is an ancient tradition dating back several hundred years. The garden contains much symbolism the main points being:



Chequered pavement represents the lights and darks, joys and sorrows of life.



The rough ashlar (stone) represents man passing over the chequered pavement adopting the principles of love, relief and truth

becoming much improved, represented by the smooth ashlar.



Square & compasses within circle. Square – desire to fulfil life by square and honest conduct – compass that this desire should be

exercised throughout the circle of our lives.



Round balls and pillars – celestial and celestial globes which symbolises that freemasonry has no boundaries. Walls acknowledge

ancient art of stonemasons.



ROYAL TREE COLLECTION



Just here is a WEDDING CAKE TREE which comes from the Far East, planted in 2011 to mark the marriage of Prince William and

Catherine Middleton. (Now the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge.)



Next to it is this flowering crab apple tree, planted to commemorate the Queen’s Diamond Jubilee in 2012. There is also a Golden

Beech tree the other side of the Chapel which the Queen herself planted during her Golden Jubilee year in 2002. A little further down

is another Golden Beech tree planted by the Duke of Edinburgh at the same time.



Also, part of our ‘Royal Collection’ is the white wisteria you can see growing up the Chapel wall. This was part of the display at

Westminster Abbey for the wedding of William and Catherine, and they have kindly presented it to us to look after.

name: MELLENIUM AVENUE
description:
Millennium Avenue is often referred to as Shrievalty Avenue due to the trees and plaques lining the dedicated to High Sheriffs of this

country.



They are small leaf lime trees which were propagated at the Westonbirt Arboretum in Gloucestershire from a single tree believed to

be 2000 years and are, therefore, genetically the oldest trees in the National Memorial Arboretum.



Lime wood does not warp and is often used to make keys and sounding boards in pianos and organs. It is also often used by

woodcarvers, for example, the beautiful carving of ‘The Storyteller’ in our very own Chapel.

name: NATIONAL SERVICE VETERANS
description:
This is dedicated to all those who served their country as National Servicemen between 1939 and 1960. Young men were called up

to serve in the Army, Navy or Air Force for two years.



The green granite sculpture has four wings which represent the four points of the compass as National Service was performed around

the world, while the Crown indicates that they were in the service of ‘The Crown’.



Many thousands of those named on the Armed Forces Memorial were National Service men.



Veterans hold an annual parade here each June and are usually joined in the march-past by a few former Bevin Boys, whose memorial

we will see shortly.



A number of National Service Personnel served in the Korean Conflict 1950 to 1953

name: BEVIN BOYS
description:
Nearly 48,000 young men, all of them conscripts, joined regular miners in their work from 1943 - 1948. They were pressed into action

because many miners had gone to war and at one stage coal reserves fell to less than three weeks' supply.



Ernest Bevin was the Minister of Labour at that time and decreed that every 10th man called up for war service would instead be

sent down the coal mines.



. The Bevin Boys were chosen out of a hat. Every month, for 20 months, Bevin's secretary drew numbers from his distinctive Homburg

hat. If the number drawn matched the last digit of a man's National Service number, he was sent to the mines



Comedian Eric Morecambe was a Bevin Boy (as was Brian Rix and Nat Lofthouse).



The work was unfamiliar and dangerous; resulting in many injuries and lives lost. They were also often unfairly accused of be ing

‘Conscientious Objectors’, which they most certainly were not, although some Conscientious Objectors HAD been sent to work in the

mines as an alternative to imprisonment.



The plinths are made of Kilkenny limestone which will eventually turn black, like coal.



During the Second World War 48,000 men were conscripted, via a lottery, to work in coal mines



They were called “Bevin Boys” after Ernest Bevin, the Minister of Labour and National Service in the wartime coalition



government



The Bevin Boys joined regular miners in their dirty, dangerous but essential work to keep the coal supplies of Britain flowing



The badge awarded to Bevin Boys can be seen on the face of the main memorial



The smaller of the two blocks is carved with the tools and equipment used by the Bevin Boys



There are also two mice carved on the memorial as Bevin Boys said that there were always mice in the mines. Can you spot



them?

name: WOMEN’S LAND ARMY & WOMEN’S TIMBER CORPS
description:
This is a tribute to those ladies, some as young as 17, who went to serve on our farms during both World Wars and in the forests

during WW2.



We were importing about 70% of our food and the impact of U-Boats, a poor harvest and so many farm workers away fighting meant

a real shortage of food. That is where these women came to the nation’s rescue.



Shown around the plinth are some of the trades they had to learn (Snedding is cleaning the side branches from a tree trunk and

Snigging is moving a felled tree trunk by means of a chain wrapped round it, usually pulled by a horse).



The dead rat shows how important it was to control pests, known as ‘Hitler’s little helpers’, from eating the stored food.



The Timber Corps (known as ‘Lumber Jills’, as opposed to ‘Lumberjacks’) was formed in 1942, with the girls taking on the same work

as the men and working to keep us supplied with timber.



The model for the Land Girl was Isobel Wright, whose grandmother Mary had been a Land Girl herself.



Many former Land Army and Timber Corps women came to the dedication ceremony for this memorial in October 2014, the youngest

being 84yrs old and the oldest 101!



The Timber Corps was disbanded in 1946 and the Land Army in 1950. Turn from the Naval Review and move to the Royal Air Force

Wing

name: ASSOCIATION OF JEWISH EX-SERVICEMEN (AJEX)
description:
Made from Chinese granite, The Star of David is designed to give you a different perspective when viewed from different angles.



The small stones on the memorial are there as it is traditional for a Jewish person who visits any memorial to place a stone onto it to

mark their visit.



The Hebrew characters at the top right say ‘Remember’.



The bench in the left corner has been dedicated by family members to a Polish couple who were killed in the Warsaw uprising against

German occupation towards the end of World War 2.

name: GALLIPOLI
description:
This memorial is to the many thousands of lives lost in the First World War at Gallipoli in Turkey between April 1915 and Jan uary

1916, when the Allies were attempting to open a supply route into the Black Sea for Russia and to enable them to attack Germany

from a different direction.



It is estimated that the Allies lost 265,000 men through battle fatalities, injuries and sickness.



ANZAC (Australia & New Zealand Army Corps) day is 25th April each year, the day the Australian & New Zealand forces landed on the

beaches at Gallipoli.



The memorial includes a tree sculpture of 9 dead Oak trees which have been pollarded. This gives the effect of the outstretched arms

and hands of the soldiers appealing for help as they lay injured.



The arched displays include a map of the area created in a glass mosaic, and a moving poem.



(9 trees because combatants from 9 main countries were involved at Gallipoli – Great Britain, France, Australia, New Zealand,

Newfoundland, India; against Germany, Austria Hungary and the Ottoman empire [Turkey])

name: RAF Dentists
description:
The RAF Dental Branch was formed in 1930 as the importance of air power grew. By 1935 it was clear that the RAF needed to expand

rapidly in response to developments in Europe. At the time, the RAF was served by 16 dental officers with permanent commissions,

29 with non-permanent/reserve commissions and 51 civilian practitioners.



The need for improvements in oral health led to the creation of a course for dental hygienists at RAF Sidmouth in 1943. Each 16-week

course trained selected Dental Surgery Attendants to scale and polish teeth, and to educate patients.

name: RAF MOUNTAIN RESCUE
description:
Was first organised during World War II to rescue aircrew from the large number of aircraft crashes then occurring due to

minor navigational errors in conjunction with bad weather and resulting poor visibility when flying in the vicinity of high ground.



PRINCESS MARY'S ROYAL AIR FORCE NURSING SERVICE (PMRAFNS) Map This nursing service started as a temporary service in

1918 when the RAF was founded on 1st April, the service became permanent in 1921.



It was a female only nursing service until 1980 when men were allowed to join.



There are around 500 nurses serving today.



There is a Plaque to Nurse Joyce Kathleen Atkin to the left behind the main memorial who was killed in the sinking of the Ship Khedive

Ismall along side 52 other nurses a total of 77 female lives lost the largest loss of female lives. Torpedoed by Japanese submarine in

the Indian ocean 12th February 1944.

name: WOMANS RAF
description:
It existed in two separate incarnations: the Women's Royal Air Force from 1918 to 1920 and the Women's Royal Air Force from 1949

to 1994. On 1 February 1949, the name of the First World War organisation was revived when the Women's Auxiliary Air Force, which

had been founded in 1939, was re-established on a regular footing as the Women's Royal Air Force. The RAF and WRAF merged in

name: ROYAL AIR FORCES ASSOCIATION
description:
The rather striking Eagle of the Royal Air Forces Association is next. The eagle and globe form the badge of the Association whose

purpose is to look after the welfare of both serving and former members of the RAF and Commonwealth Air Forces.



The Eagle, known as Winston, consists of over 1000 hand-made stainless-steel feathers and is surrounded by an RAF Roundel to

symbolise the RAF Association being at the heart of the RAF family.

name: RAF SERVICING COMMANDO AND TACTICAL SUPPLY WING
description:
Tactical Supply Wing (TSW) is a helicopter support unit of the RAF. TSW's primary role is supporting

the deployment of helicopter operations, specialising in providing rotors-turning refuelling to helicopters and field refuelling of fixedwing aircraft; this can done from the back of a transport aircraft, or deploy-able storage facilities, such as bowsers or pillow tanks,

often in the field or at austere temporary sites.



RAF Servicing Commando. Formed during WW2, served in the European and Far Eastern theatres of war before being disbanded in

1946. These units, called Servicing Commandos, would accompany the Allied Armies when they invaded Europe, either to make

German airfields serviceable or to make operational the new airstrips built by the Army Airfield Construction Units. Eventually 12

Servicing Commandos were formed in the United Kingdom and three in the Middle East. The force consisted of 2,400 officers and men

skilled in aircraft maintenance, armaments, communications and airfield activation skills and were capable of working on all types of

aircraft to keep them flying under all kinds of conditions.

name: ROYAL AIR FORCE MEDICAL SERVICES
description:
This is the branch of the Royal Air Force that provides health care at home and on deployed operations to RAF service

personnel. Medical officers are the doctors of the RAF and have specialist expertise in aviation medicine to support aircrew and their

protective equipment. Medical officers also carry out Aeromedical evacuations, providing vital assistance on search-andrescue missions or emergency relief flights

name: ROYAL OBSERVER CORPS
description:
The Royal Observer Corps was a Civil Defence organisation operating between October 1925 - December 1995 which was tasked with

spotting, identifying and tracking enemy aircraft.



Composed mainly of civilian spare-time volunteers, ROC personnel wore a Royal Air Force style uniform. They were originally called

the Observer Corps but were awarded the title Royal by King George VI in April 1941, in recognition of service carried out by Observer

Corps personnel during the Battle of Britain.



The Corps was disbanded in 1995 following the end of the ‘Cold War’.

name: ROYAL AIR FORCE WING
description:
The area in front consists of memorials for the Royal Air Force and the Air Forces of Commonwealth countries.



The 3-armed bushes represent the propeller blades of a Spitfire, with a walnut tree nearby as the centre boss and blades of an early

Spitfire propeller were made of walnut wood. The Aircrew Association memorial is in memory of the Air Crews of WW2.



There are also memorials here for 30 Squadron (transport - the black bell shaped one); RAF Police (known as Snowdrops because of

their white caps); IX Squadron, 101 Squadron, II Squadron (the oldest Squadron in the RAF), RAF Medical Services; Princess Mary Royal

Air Force Nursing Service(PMRAFNS); Search & Rescue;

name: GUINEA PIG CLUB
description:
The Guinea Pig Club, established in July 1941, was a social club and mutual support network for British and allied aircrew

injured during the Second World War.



Its membership was made up of patients of Sir Archibold McIndoe at Queen Victoria Hospital, East Grinstead, Sussex, who

had undergone pioneering reconstructive surgery, generally after receiving burns injuries in aircraft.



By the end of the Second World War the club had 649 members.



The memorial, which stands over 2 metres high, is carved from green Cumbrian slate and resembles the shape of a Spitfire

wing.



The design features a crashed Hurricane at the bottom with its vapour trail weaving down from the top. The logo of the

Guinea Pig Club is also carved at the top of the memorial. On the left hand side of the design, the meandering vapour trail

of the falling Hurricane outlines the strong facial profile of the pioneering plastic surgeon, Sir Archibald McIndoe.



Along the memorial’s right edge is an inscription “Out of the flames came inspiration” provided by Guinea Pig Dr. Sandy

Saunders. The memorial was unveiled by HRH The Duke of Edinburgh, president of the Guinea Pig Club, on 2 November



The Guinea Pig Club was established in 1941. Its membership was made up of patients of Archibald McIndoe at Queen

Victoria Hospital, East Grinstead, Sussex, who had carried out experimental reconstructive plastic surgery on airmen who

had received burn injuries in aircraft. The club remained active after the end of the war, and its annual reunion meetings

continued until 2007.



The outline of Archibald McIndoe’s face forms the left side of this memorial.



The memorial was unveiled in 2016 by the Duke of Edinburgh.

name: NUMBER 2 SQUADRON
description:
Number 2 Squadron is the most senior squadron of the RAF, formed on 13th may 1912 0n the founding day of the RFC as one of the

first three squadrons formed.



Numbers 2 and 3 were equipped with fixed wing aircraft while number one with airships.



Number 2 was the first squadron to fly the English Channel into France at the start of WW1.



Its principal role was not Air – Air combat but army co-operation but it still had a flying Ace in its ranks (five enemy A/C shot down)

Arthur William Hammond it also had the first Aviation VC's first was 2nd Lieutenant William Rhodes Moorhouse and Lieutenant Alan

Arnett “babe” Mcleod (see paving slab on causeway to McLeod).



Number 2 nicknamed the shiny two Motto Hereward Guardian of the Army. The Squadron's tail badge is the wake knot derived from

the coat of arms of Hereward the wake.



The Squadron is now equipped with Eurofighter Typhoon FGR4's at RAF Lossiemouth.

name: FLIGHT ENGINEERS MEMORIAL
description:
Flight Engineers were introduced into the RAF in 1941, their primary role was to assist pilots in the flying of large multi-engined

aircraft that had become too technically complex to be operated by a single pilot. By taking over the management of the aircraft's

various systems, the Flight Engineer released the pilot to concentrate on the actual flying of the aircraft.



The insignia of a Flight Engineer is a single wing. The single wing is known as a half brevet (which was given to increase rank without

increasing pay).

name: 9 SQUADRON
description:
The Final British attack on the Tirpitz to place on the 12th November1944by a mixed force of 32 Lancasters from 9 Sqd and 617 Sqd they

dropped 29 tallboy bombs on the ship landing two direct hits and one near miss. Several bombs landed within the torpedo nets which

removed much of the sandbank that had been constructed to prevent the ship capsizing. To his day members of both squadrons claim

that it was their Bomb that sank the Tirpitz.



The 9 Squadron Memorial is dedicated to all those who have served in the Squadron since its formation in 1914. The memorial bears

the inscription "The oldest bomber Squadron in the world".



The Squadron crests are engraved on the faces of the memorial, including the IX Squadron (B) badge depicting a bat accompanied by

the motto,"Per noctum volamus" which translates "Throughout the night we fly", reflecting the Squadron's night bombing duties.



The Final British attack on the Tirpitz to place on the 12th November1944by a mixed force of 32 Lancaster Bombers from 9 Sqd and

617 Sqd they dropped 29 tallboy bombs on the ship landing two direct hits and one near miss. Several bombs landed within the

torpedo nets which removed much of the sandbank that had been constructed to prevent the ship capsizing. To his day members of

both squadrons claim that it was their Bomb that sank the Tirpitz.



The Squadron is still in operation today.

name: 101 SQUADRON
description:
101 Squadron is one of the Royal Air Force's oldest and most prestigious squadrons. It is still active today, flying out of RAF Brize

Norton, Oxfordshire.



In WW1 they flew bi-planes and pioneered night bombing over the Western Front.



In WW2 the Squadron served in Bomber Command and participated in the greatest air battles the world has ever witnessed.



In more recent times they have seen operational service in, amongst others, Falklands, Iraq, Syria and Afghanistan.



The Squadron's Latin motto "Mens agitat molem" translates to "mind over matter".

name: RAF PHYSICAL TRAINING
description:
The RAF School of physical training was formed on the 1st of April 1918.



The school's motto translates as 'Bold in Strength' which is symbolised in the Roebuck on the school's crest. The Roebuck was chosen

because of its extraordinary alertness, energy, and physical fitness, qualities needed to be a PTI today.

name: STAFFORDSHIRE REGIMENT
description:
Originally there were two regiments, The North Staffs and The South Staffs. They amalgamated in 1959 to become The Staffordshire

Regiment and in 2007 they became part of the Mercian Regiment.



The memorial itself is made of Staffordshire stone, and is the only memorial on the site that has been designed and constructed by

former members of the regiment.



And a good example of one of our tree dedications is the single oak behind the obelisk, dedicated to Lance Corporal William

COLTMAN, the most decorated NCO (non-commissioned officer) of WW1.



Lance Corporal Coltman was awarded the Victoria Cross, the Distinguished Conduct Medal and Bar (meaning it was awarded twice),

and the Military Medal and Bar, and was also mentioned in despatches. But he did not kill any Germans, for he was a stretcher bearer.



Mr Coltman was wounded a couple of times but nothing serious. He survived the war and then worked as a park keeper in Burtonon-Trent. He died in 1974, aged 82.



His medals are on display at Staffordshire Regimental Museum, just outside Lichfield.

name: THE QUEEN'S LANCASHIRE REGIMENT MEMORIAL
description:
The Queen's Lancashire Regiment was formed on 25 March 1970 until 2006 when it was amalgamated with The King's Own Royal

Border Regiment and The King's Regiment to create The Duke of Lancaster's Regiment.



The new regiment took the golden thread of the Rose of Lancashire as the cap badge from The Queen's Lancs.



A box containing artefacts is entombed in the 5x5 metre base of the memorial. Amongst the items in the box is a photograph of the

presentation of the Colours, a list of battle honours, a short history of the regiment, a regimental shield and regimental drumsticks.

The final part of the memorial, a coloured glass panel displaying the Regimental Flag is yet to be added.



The memorial will honour the 2 regiments that came together in 1970 to form The Queens Lancs. They are The Lancashire Regiment

and The Loyal Regiment.



25 March 2020 was 50th anniversary of the founding of the regiment.

name: POLAR BEAR (49th WEST RIDING INFANTRY DIVISION)
description:
This was our first major memorial and was erected in 1998. The 49th saw active service in France and Flanders during Deleted: to be

WW1. They got their name from seeing active service in Norway and Iceland where they had to contend with very heavy

snow drifts. Not thinking that they would survive, their commanding officer called them his Polar Bears. The Polar Bear

was adopted as their shoulder flash and remains so today.



Peter Benson and his team of Essex woodcarvers took a year to create the structure. The bear was recently restored.



The traffic bulletin on Radio 5 kept including information ‘Motorists heading north along the M1/M6 should take care, there

is a slow moving Polar Bear on the inside lane.’



This memorial has two poems by Jodie Johnson; the first written when she was aged 9 and the second

at age 11.



50 Years Late



I am Only a Child



And it’s hard to explain,



The feelings I have,



as I sit in the rain



And I think of the men



who went off to war,



Knowing they would not



come home anymore.



I cannot say thank you



To the men left in France,



Who laid down their lives



To give me a chance



I cannot say thank you



To the ones who returned,



For thank you is not



What those brave men earned.



I owe them my life,



As I live it today,



A life lived in freedom



because of that day.



I owe them much more



Than I can ever repay,



I owe them the lives



That they gave up that day.



They will live in my heart



For as long as I live,



And my children will learn



Of the gift that they give.



Who Are These Men?



Who are these men



Who march so proud



Who quietly weep



Eyes closed, head bowed?



These are the men



Who once were boys



Who missed out on youth



And all of its joys



Who are these men



With aged faces



Who silently count



The empty spaces?



These are the men



Who gave their all



Who fought for their country



For freedom for all.



Who are these men



With sorrowful look



Who still can remember



The lives that were took?



These are the men



Who saw young men die



The price of peace



Is always high.



Who are these men



Who in the midst of pain



Whispered comfort to those



They would not see again?



These are the men



Whose hands held tomorrow



Who brought back our future



With blood tears and sorrow.



Who are these men



Who promise to keep



Alive in their hearts



The ones God holds asleep?



These are the men



To whom I promise again



Veterans, my friends,



I WILL REMEMBER THEM.

name: MEDITERRANEAN CAMPAIGNS OF WW2 GARDEN
description:
The Mediterranean Grove is laid out geographically, at the far side we have the North African coastline where we

remember the 1st and 8th Armies. A stone memorial for the famous Rats of Tobruk, who endured one of the longest Deleted: r

sieges in British and Commonwealth military history. Palestine, Malta, Cyprus, Palestinian Police and Monte Cassino. Italy

giving the boot to Sicily is planted with Black Pines, each one linked to a major battle of the Italian Campaign.

name: THE BEAT
description:
The Beat was originally lined with horse chestnut trees, one for each police force in the UK. Horse Chestnut is symbolic as

one was grown from a conker picked up at Drayton Manor where the founder of the Police Force lived, Sir Robert Peel.

He named his force the Peelers or Bobbies. The first truncheons were made of the wood as it was a dense wood and

would give a knock to remember.



If we look back to the top of The Beat we can see a traditional Blue Police lamp, they used to be situated outside most

Police Stations. This one originates from Hitchin, Hertfordshire, Police Station, it was placed here in memory of Mandy

Raynor, the youngest Policewoman to lose her life whilst on duty.

name: ROYAL LOGISTIC CORPS
description:
Comprising different Corps and Units, all of whom supply services, food, ammunition, stores, transport, postal and courier Deleted: pay, education,

service. The memorial, surrounded by edible plants symbolising the Catering Corps, was dedicated in 2000.



Deleted: etc.



A Mulberry Tree, Morus, is dedicated to Captain Lisa Jade Head. Lisa was an army officer and the first female bomb

disposal officer to be killed on operations. She was mortally injured in Helmand Province on 18 April 2011, 22 days after

arriving in Afghanistan for the second time, while attempting to disable a cluster of improvised explosive devices. She

disabled one device, but was hit when a second device in the chain went off. She was flown back to the Queen Elizabeth

hospital in Birmingham. She died the following day.



The RLC was formed in April 1993 by merging the Royal Corps of Transport, the Royal Army Ordnance Corps, the

Royal Pioneer Corps, the Army Catering Corps and the Royal Engineers Postal and Courier Service.



The RLC is the British Army’s largest Corps. From storing and moving equipment, fuel, ammunitions and supplies to

cooking meals and fixing IT equipment and delivering mail, it supports Army operations around the world, by land

sea and air



The corps is responsible for thousands of motor vehicles as well as the Army’s storage, ordnance and fuel depots.

It also operates the Army's air dispatch service, and maritime and rail transport. It provides pioneer labour and cooks,

and is involved in explosive ordnance disposal.



Members of the corps help manage and maintain IT systems that aid logistics, and fix problems with network

infrastructures and operating systems. They ensure the secure delivery of mail for all three-armed services and also

serve as photographers.



In recent years, the corps has deployed units to Northern Ireland during the final years of ‘the Troubles’, served with

the British Army of the Rhine in Germany, and undertaken peace-keeping duties in Cyprus, Bosnia and Kosovo

(1999). It also served in the recent conflicts in Afghanistan (2001-14) and Iraq (2003-11).

name: ROYAL TANK REGIMENT
description:
The tank was developed simultaneously in Britain and France. The idea for the caterpillar tracks came from British agriculture.



Because of the stalemate in WW1 where both sides were dug into trenches and unable to advance more than a few yards at a time,

it was thought that the tank would break the stalemate. Because of its design, it could travel and crush the barbed wire fences, drive

across the trenches and could turn the guns onto the enemy.



The tank when being moved around the country for trials was packed in large wooden cases and as a security measure it was marked

"water tank". The name on the drawing board was originally "land ship" but when it came to be named, they decided to drop the

water and call it a tank, on the premise that you put things in a tank i.e. men and munitions. (there are other versions of how this came

about).



On the plinth is a scale model of a Mark 5 tank from WWI, of which there were 2 main types - the ‘female’ tank armed with machine

guns and the ‘male’ armed with cannons. There were a few ‘hermaphrodites’, armed with both.
