The trees on the plot are largely of Ash to correspond with the Ash ‘swagger sticks’ of the officers. These came about after an officer

cut a branch from an ash tree to measure the depth of mud before sending his tanks into it, a clever idea which became general

practice.



The oak tree, surrounded by the seat, was grown from an acorn collected from Delville Wood, on the Somme battlefield, where the

tanks were used in larger numbers. Other trees are from the Cambrai battlefield, Flesquieres and Bourlon Wood, where the Battle of

Cambrai took place in November 1917.



At the sides of the plot in spring, daffodils flower in the pattern of a tank’s caterpillar tracks.



The flag of the Tank Regiment is 3 horizontal stripes, from the bottom upwards, brown to red to green. Stands for, “from the mud

through the blood to the green fields beyond”. The Moto of the RTD is “Fear Naught”



4 Members of the RTG have been awarded the VC, one being awarded to 2nd Lieutenant Clement Robertson who walked in front of

his tanks to mark the way over heavily ploughed fields so as they not lose their way.



The first successful tank battle took place at Cambrai in 1917 with about 300 Mark IV tanks. Horrendous conditions inside

the tank, temperature of up to 45 degrees, crew of 8, noise from shells, engine and tracks. 3-4 mph over shell craters, the Deleted: 4 or 5

smell. They needed a strong stomach. The tank on the plinth is a Mark V (male).



In the centre of the circular seat is an oak tree, the acorn was brought back from Delville Wood. Ash trees are significant

as the Officers would walk in front of the tanks with sticks made of ash, they prodded the ground to see how firm it was as

tanks used to get bogged down. Officers of the Regiment carry ‘swagger’, sticks.



In the early 2000s 2 coach loads of recruits were brought to the Grove. They planted daffodil bulbs in straight lines to

resemble the tank tracks.



Their flag is brown, red and green, ‘through mud and blood to pastures new’.



In WW2 37% of tank casualties were reported to be soldiers leaving the tank to brew up. Since 1945 all tanks have been

fitted with a boiling vessel to make tea.



In WW2, tanks played a major part in the war - there were 46 variants, tanks of all shapes and sizes. There were:



o Tankettes, about the size of a large car, mainly used for reconnaissance.



o Medium size tanks, but not very successful, under gunned and armoured.



o Light tanks, used mainly for training



o Cruiser tanks, used mainly against enemy tanks



o Infantry tanks, designed and heavily armoured, used to give close support to infantry unit. The most popular of these tanks appears

to be the Churchill tank of which around 5,600 were manufactured.

name: IRISH INFANTRY GROVE
description:
Large oak tree is from a stand of oaks which was one of the few species in Ireland to survive the Ice Age.



During WW1 over 250,000 Irishmen volunteered to fight for the British Army. Thousands lost their lives, on the Menin

Gate alone hundreds are recorded.



The garden itself was consecrated in 2000 and commemorates all who have served and continue to serve. The original

idea for this garden was to create an acre of Ireland in the heart of the British Isles. The paved map of Ireland

commemorates each of the Irish regiments.



In WW1 37 VCs were awarded. In WW2 8 VCs were awarded.



The youngest ever recorded British soldier to have died was an Irish lad named John Condon, aged 14yrs. He died on

24 May 1915 at the 2nd battle of Ypres and is buried at the Commonwealth War Graves Commission cemetery at

Poelkapelle. On his stone it clearly states his age as 14 years.



All the trees and shrubs in the garden are of Irish origin. The tree in the corner is taken from a stand of oak in Northern

Ireland, one of the few trees said to have survived through the ice age 10,000 years ago.

name: SHOT AT DAWN
description:
309 posts one for each soldier shot at dawn for deserting, attacking an officer, throwing away his gun, sleeping on watch.

It is situated here as it is the furthest east on the site. When the sun rises it falls on the statue. He is Herbert Burden,

serving with the Northumberland fusiliers, aged 17 when shot. The 6 juniper trees opposite represent the riflemen. The

firing squad was picked from the prisoner’s own platoon, a lesson should they every consider doing anything similar.



Jimmy Smith had seen active service in Gallipoli, badly wounded on the Somme, he was sent back to England. When he

had recovered he returned to the frontline in time for the Battle of Ypres in Belgium in 1917 He could take no more, he Deleted: was sent over to France.

deserted. He was sentenced to be shot. The riflemen fired wide but had wounded Jimmy. The officer in charge went over



Deleted: at the third battle of Ypres in Belgium.

to Richard Blundell in the firing squad and told him to carry out the ‘coup de grâce’. Richard was Jimmy’s best friend. On

visiting his father in the nursing home many years later, Richard’s son asked his father why he kept saying ‘what a way,

what a way’. Richard said ‘what a way to get compassionate leave to kill your best friend’. Post 255



Today we live in a more enlightened age and we recognise PTSD



Rudyard Kipling wrote an epitaph:



I could not look on death

And being known

Men led me to him

Blindfold and alone.

name: POLICE MEMORIAL
description:
More than 4000 men and women have given their lives in the service of their communities while wearing the uniform.



On entering there is descriptive text and a ‘Sillitoe’ tartan, evoking the Police uniform. The space is entered through a tall

doorway supporting a brass screen. The doorway represents a ‘threshold’ - the threshold to a different space and ‘the

dangerous places where police go’.



Leaf-shaped apertures represent service, sacrifice and particularly lives lost: Absence. The brass will weather while the

gilt edges remain bright, and as the sun shines the paved surface will be lit by this gilded absence. The leaf-shaped

‘stage’ with two further low screens, creates a more intimate space - like a Lady Chapel within a church.



Lawn space for more than 1500 people enables ceremonies and services. Occasional bench seating provides intimate,

reflective spaces, tucked onto and backed by the slopes and ring of trees. Raised edges to the sunny circular glade

surrounded by a bold and simple ring of trees impart a sense of enclosure and protection, the glade itself edged and

embraced by the wilder more natural wooded part of the Arboretum.

name: 216 SQUADRON ROYAL AIR FORCE
description:
In 1918 ‘A’ Squadron, Royal Naval Air Service was renumbered as No 216 (two-sixteen) Squadron Royal Air Force. It was

designated a bomber-transport squadron for strategic bombing during the latter stages of WW1 and during the inter war

years in the Middle East. On the outbreak of war with Italy in June 1940 the units’ aircraft undertook bombing sorties, then

concentrated on transport flying, moving squadrons around the Middle East and Greece and keeping open the supply and

reinforcement routes. In 1941 the Squadron agreed to provide a Bristol Bombay aircraft for the newly formed SAS for its

first real parachute jump into the North African Desert. . 1955, the Squadron returned to the United Kingdom and received

the Comet 2 aircraft and continued to operate these aircraft in the transport role, particularly for Royal and VIP flights.

During the Falklands War the Squadron assumed the task off a refuelling Unit including the twice weekly schedule to the

Falklands Islands At the end of July 1990, Iraq invaded Kuwait. No 216 Squadron with eight Tri star aircraft made a

significant contribution including air-to-air refuelling and troop-carrying in support of both the RAF and US Navy, as it did

later in Iraq and Afghanistan In 2020 No. 216 Squadron reformed to become an experimental unit that will test future

drone swarm technology. Based at RAF Waddington. The memorial was dedicated in April 2022.

name: RAF PATH FINDER FORCE MEMORIAL (NO. 8 GROUP)
description:
Path Finder Force formed August 1942, part of Bomber Command (they were used for target-marking to increase

accuracy of bombing raids). Mainly RAF but also personnel from other Commonwealth countries. It was steadily

transformed from a token ‘hit & miss’ Force to one that could deliver anything from a single Bomb to 100’s of tonnes of

bombs accurately onto a target anywhere in Western Europe. ‘Cherry-picking’ crews from other areas of the RAF was

frowned upon at the time but it would have been the Crème de la Crème of crews that had the skills and experience

needed. The airmen committed to doing another 60 operations, later reduced to 45 (and the more you did, the less the

chance of surviving). Crews for specific missions were hand-picked. Aircraft used included Halifax, Lancaster, Wellington

and Mosquito and Stirling. Project to get a memorial started in 2014. It was originally unveiled at the PFF Reunion at RAF

Wyton (August 2017), 75 years after No.8 Group was formed. Memorial weighs 5 tonnes – logistically difficult getting it

transferred to the NMA - eventually installed in July 2020

name: POPPY MEMORIAL
description:
The memorial, provided by The Royal British Legion (began in 1921), features a giant wreath around which poppies, inscribed



with individual names and dates, can be planted as a permanent tribute. It’s a place where everyday heroes, as well as those



killed in conflict, can be honoured. (Became ‘Royal’ in 1971).



It has 12 segments representing the 12 months of the year, and those wishing to place a poppy can select the most appropriate



segment.



Leaflets are available in Reception explaining how a poppy can be placed, which is via the Royal British Legion, not the NMA.

name: POPPY MEMORIAL BENCH'S
description:
The plaque behind the memorial remembers Lt-Col John Alexander McCrae, a Canadian doctor serving during WW1. He wrote



the poem ‘In Flanders Fields’ shortly after a good friend of his had been killed in the Battle of Ypres.



(‘In Flanders Fields the poppies blow; between the crosses row on row…).



The plaque by the bench to the right of the memorial remembers an American Lady, Moina Michael, affectionately known as



‘The first poppy lady’. It was she who campaigned for the red poppy to be adopted as the symbol of remembrance after having



read the poem ‘In Flanders Fields’.



The third plaque, on the left, remembers a French lady, Madame Anna Guerin, who was the first to sell poppies in order to



raise money which was then given to ex-servicemen and poor children in the war-torn areas of Europe.



Opposite on the right corner of the pathway is our memorial for the Royal National Lifeboat Institution. The lifeboat man,



wearing an old-style cork life preserver, stands looking out over the water, where those needing help might be seen.

name: BURIAL MOUND
description:
The area with no trees, benches or memorials is the site of a Bronze Age Burial Mound approximately 3,500 years old and



because of its historical significance it remains largely untouched, though we do sometimes plant a number of wildflower plugs



in there to make it more attractive to wildlife.



The grass is left uncut during spring and summer months, providing cover for brown hares and home to nesting skylarks.

name: Royal Air Force Association Remembrance Garden (RAFA)
description:
The first national Remembrance Garden in memory of those that have served in the commonwealth air forces. The Eagle,



named Winston, is made up of over 1000 hand forged feathers.



The RAF Mountain Rescue, RAF Search and Rescue, RAF Medical, Dental and RAF Nurses (Princesses Marys) are all in a line and



front the RAF area.

name: ADJUTANT GENERAL’S CORPS
description:
(In front of the Staffords) They have responsibility for administration, pay, education, legal and policing matters relating to Army



personnel.



It doesn’t sound exciting, but they are often required to fight alongside frontline troops, and of course the British Army would



quickly grind to a halt without them.

name: TOC H
description:
The lamp on your right is the symbol of the Toc H movement, a Christian organisation that has its roots in a large house called



Talbot House at Poperinge (pronounced Pope-a-ringa) in Belgium, about 6 miles from the YPRES battlefield. The lamp itself is



a low-burning oil lamp that was used in the Chapel at the top of the house.



The town of Poperinge, known as Pops, became very popular with British troops. Being so close to the front line, lots of officers'



bars sprang up and bars for other ranks. Brothels also appeared. Talbot House was an alternative place for soldiers who wanted



a quiet refuge.



Talbot House was set up in 1915 by a jovial clergyman, the Rev. ‘Tubby’ Clayton providing basic comforts and a chapel for young



men going to and from the Western Front. It was a ‘home from home’ where rank had no place.



The name ‘Talbot House’ was shortened to Toc H by use of the phonetic alphabet of that time. (We now say T tango, not T toc).



The house was closed when WW1 ended, but a number of men who had made use of it, especially the chapel, got together to



form a charitable organisation which they called TocH.



TocH developed greatly from that time to become an international organisation that tries to improve the lives of those who



need help.



Talbot House still exists today as a museum/hotel. (The house was named after Lieutenant Gilbert Talbot, who was the brother



of Padre Neville Talbot and had been killed at Ypres in 1915, aged 23yrs.)

name: National Nursing Memorial
description:
The National Nursing Memorial honours all nurses who died in the First and Second World Wars, providing care to the

Armed Forces of the Crown wherever it was needed. There are various memorials to individual and collective heroines,

but none has recognised them all.



The memorial, located within a secluded spot of the Royal Army Medical Corps’ woodland, comprises a large stone

globe etched with the names of all nurses lost on active service during the First and Second World Wars. The globe,

created by stonemason Nick Johnson, is supported by a pair of sculpted bronze hands made by artist Georgie Welch.

They rise from a circular stone base plinth inscribed on the surface with further names. The inscription - As Stars In A

Dark Sky They Lit Up Our World appears around its edge.



Adjacent to the memorial is a stone plinth displaying the following description:



The memorial was erected at the behest of the New Cavendish Club, previously the Voluntary Aid Detachment (VAD)

Ladies’ Club in commemoration of all the VAD and professional nurses who lost their lives in the 1st and 2nd World

Wars.



The memorial marking the sacrifice and loss of the VADs and nurses was dedicated on 4th June 2018 by HRH The



Countess of Wessex GCVO.



This memorial honours all nurses who died in WW1 and WW2 providing care to members of the armed services.



Memorial comprises of a large stone globe etched with the names of 1265 nurses who lost their lives in active service during both

World Wars. It includes nurses from QAIMNS, VAD Nurses, Red Cross, FANY, Order of Saint Johns, TFNS, TANS, PMRAFNS, QARNNS

and FNN.



o QAIMNS - Queen Alexandra's Imperial Military Nursing Service



o VAD. - Voluntary Aid Detachment



o FANY. - First Aid Nursing Yeomanry



o TFNS. - Territorial Force Nursing Service



o TANS. - Territorial Army Nursing Service



o PMRAFNS. - Princess Mary's Royal Air Force Nursing Service



o QARNNS. - Queen Alexandra's Royal Naval Nursing Service



o FNN - Flying Nightingale Nurses



The globe was created by stonemason Nick Johnson and is supported by a pair of sculpted bronze hands created by artist Georgie

Welch.

name: Royal Army Dental Corps
description:
The Army Dental Corps was formed on 11 January 1921. In recognition of their past services His Majesty King George VI

granted the prefix ‘Royal’ on 28 November 1946, thus forming the Royal Army Dental Corps.



The memorial was originally placed outside the old Connaught Hospital Building Aldershot. The sole member of the RADC

remembered as an individual is Sergeant “Geordie” Muldoon who was killed in Northern Ireland on 23 March 1973. He is

also remembered in the Ulster Grove.



The memorial was originally placed in 1948 at the Corps Depot and Training Establishment at Connaught Hospital,

Aldershot. On closure of the establishment in 1973, the memorial was moved to the new Training Centre in Evelyn Woods

Road, Aldershot. It remained there until 2011, when it was relocated to the Arboretum, as the Corps’ centre of gravity was



no longer in Aldershot. However, the Corps Standard and Book of Remembrance remain in the Corps Chapel in the Royal

Garrison Church of All Saints in Aldershot. The memorial moved to the Arboretum in the Corps’ 90th anniversary year.

The Army Dental Corps was formed in 1921 and granted the ‘Royal’ prefix in 1946. The Corps’ motto is ‘Ex Dentibus

Ensis’, which means ‘from the teeth a sword’. This is taken from the legend of Cadmus who, in Greek mythology, slew a

dragon that had killed his companions. On instructions from Athena, he sowed the dragon’s teeth in the ground and a race of

fierce men sprang up called Sparti. The RADC provides dental services to members of the British Army. Those in the Corps

are themselves soldiers.



This memorial was refurbished in 2021 and a new dedication stone was unveiled by the Duchess of Gloucester, Colonel in

Chief, on 8th September 2021.

name: Royal Army Medical Corp
description:
This large woodland has red and gold leaved trees individually dedicated to members of the Royal Army Medical Corps

(RAMC), which was formed in 1898.



There are memorial plinths at both ends of the avenue of purple leaved trees planted as a tribute to the 29 members who were

awarded the Victoria Cross, two of them gaining the award twice (and one George Cross). In the centre stands a magnificent

statue by Alan Beattie Herriot depicting a member of the Corps bringing a wounded soldier back from the battlefield.



The second memorial (which was installed earlier) shown above relates to the history of the rod and serpent goes back to

ancient Greece. Aesculapius lived about 1265BC and was a doctor famous for bringing the dead back to life. Pluto, the God

of the Underworld, appalled at not gaining the souls of the dead, complained to Jupiter, the head of all Gods, who obliged by

slaying Aesculapius with a thunderbolt, represented by the rod. After his death, Aesculapius became a God worshiped in

hundreds of temples, which became places of healing and had a pit containing a harmless snake with a forked tongue believed

to have healing properties. Ever since, the rod and the serpent have become a symbol of medicine throughout the world.

(NB Different spellings depending on whether the Greek or Latin names are used. The RAMC internet site uses Roman

names.)



Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother was Colonel in Chief of the Corps and the RAMC planted a tree in the

grove to commemorate her 100th birthday.



The following RAMC holders of the Victoria Cross are recorded by plaques at this memorial:



Crimean War

o Assistant Surgeon (later Lieutenant Colonel) Thomas Edgerton Hale VC

o Surgeon (later Surgeon General Sir) James Mouat VC, KCB

o Assistant Surgeon (later Surgeon Major) Henry Thomas Sylvester VC



Indian Mutiny

o Assistant Surgeon William Bradshaw VC

o Captain (later Major) Thomas Joseph Crean VC, DSO

o Surgeon (later Surgeon General Sir) Anthony Dickson Home VC, KCB

o Surgeon (later Deputy Surgeon General) Joseph Jee VC, CB

o Assistant Surgeon Valentine Munbee McMaster VC

o Staff Surgeon (later Surgeon General) Herbert Taylor Reade VC, CB



1st Boer War

o L Corporal (later Corporal) John Joseph Farmer VC



2nd Boer War

o Major (Later Surgeon General Sir) William Babtie VC

o Lieutenant Henry Edward Manning Douglas VC, DSO

o Lieutenant (later Colonel) Edgar Thomas Edgar Inkson VC

o Lieutenant William Henry (later Major General) Snyder Nickerson VC, CB, CMG



World War 1

o Captain Harold Ackroyd VC, MC

o Lieutenant William Barnsley Allen VC, MC

o Captain Noel Geoffrey Chavasse VC & bar

o Captain John Fox-Russell VC, MC

o Captain John Leslie Green VC



o Captain George Allan Maling VC

o Captain (later Lieutenant Colonel) Arthur Martin-Leake VC & bar

o Captain Henry Sherwood Ranken VC



World War 2

o L Corporal Henry Eric Harden VC



Other Wars

o Assistant Surgeon (later Lieutenant Colonel) Campbell Mills Douglas VC

o Surgeon Major (later Major General Sir) Owen Edward Pennefather Lloyd VC, KCB

o Surgeon William George Nicholas Manley VC, CB

o Surgeon Captain (later Lieutenant Colonel) Ferdinand Simeon le Quesne VC

o Surgeon (later Lieutenant Colonel) James Henry Reynolds VC

o Assistant Surgeon William Temple VC



In addition there is a tree for Captain Jenkin Robert Oswald Thompson GC.



We now see the ROYAL ARMY MEDICAL CORPS wood, with its most striking sculpture of an injured soldier being carried from the

field of battle by a member of the Medical Corps.



The sculptor here was Alan Beattie HERRIOTT, who also designed the Durham Light Infantry sculpture, near the Parachute Regiment

memorial.



The wood itself contains trees dedicated to the 29 members of the Corps who were awarded the Victoria Cross, plus one awarded

the George Cross, each tree marked with a plaque.



They include two of the only 3 people who have been awarded the VC twice:-



o Captain Noel CHAVASSE was awarded his first VC in 1916 at the battle of the Somme, his second was awarded posthumously in 1917

when he lost his life at the battle of Passchendaele. He was also awarded the Military Cross and Mentioned in Dispatches. He is buried

in Brandhoek Commonwealth War Graves Commission Cemetery in Belgium. His medals are on display at the Imperial War Museum

in London. Noel had three brothers and three sisters who all distinguished themselves in WW1;



o Lt-Colonel (Captain) Arthur Martin-Leake who earned his 1st during the Boer War in 1902 when he was badly wounded, and his 2nd

in 1914 during WW1 in Belgium. He lived to the age of 79yrs.



o The 3rd was a New Zealand soldier, Charles Upham, who was awarded the VC in 1941 and again in 1942.



There is also a blue plaque at the far end left hand side of the RAMC remembering a selfless member of the RAMC from WW2. His

name is Captain Jenkin Robert Oswald Thomas GC



On 23rd/24th January 1944 at Anzio, Italy, HMHS St David was hit by bombs and started to sink. Thomas organised parties to carry

the seriously wounded to safety in the boats and by his efforts the lives of all the patients except one were saved. When the ship was

about to founder, and all were ordered to save themselves, he did nothing of the sort, but returned alone in an endeavour to save the

one remaining patient who was still lying trapped below decks. He could not save this man, so he remained with him and they went

down with the ship together.



Captain Thomas was posthumously awarded the George Cross. (The blue plaque symbolises the colour of the ribbon of the GC).



World War Two, 1939-1945



During World War Two technology enabled the RAMC greater access to mechanised land and air transport, allowing specialists and

operating teams to get right to the front-line in an increasingly mobile war.



There were major medical developments pioneered by the army, such as the use of penicillin for the first time in the North African

campaign, and also the development of blood transfusion, which was so crucial in wartime.



Many medical personnel were taken prisoner during the war, as they often remained with the wounded.



29 of the RAMC have been awarded Victoria Crosses since its inception in 1856.



It is the highest award in our armed forces for valour



As you look down this avenue of Norwegian Maples which have a crimson leaf which symbolises the colour of the ribbon of the VC,

underneath each tree there is a crimson plaque with the recipient’s name and details.



Since the introduction of the VC in 1856 only 1368 have been awarded, from the Crimean War, through the Boer War, 2 World Wars

and 47 conflicts to date.



Out of those only three have been awarded it twice and two of those are from the RAMC.



There is also a blue plaque just to the left here under this giant redwood tree remembering selfless member of the RAMC from WW2.

His name is Captain Jenkin Robert Oswald Thomas GC



On 23rd/24th January 1944 at Anzio, Italy, HMHS St David was hit by bombs and started to sink. Thomas organised parties to carry

the seriously wounded to safety in the boats and by his efforts the lives of all the patients except one were saved. When the ship was

about to founder, and all were ordered to save themselves, he did nothing of the sort, but returned alone in an endeavour to save the

one remaining patient who was still lying trapped below decks. He could not save this man, so he remained with him and they went

down with the ship together.



Captain Thomas was posthumously awarded the George Cross. (The blue plaque symbolises the colour of the ribbon of the GC).



There are many extraordinary stories of incredible acts of bravery during WW2.



Thousands of the RAMC served in WW2 and many died trying to save others.

name: Royal Army Veterinary Corps
description:
This black granite memorial was dedicated in May 2014 in the presence of HRH The Princess Royal, Princess Anne. The engravings

depict the work of the Corps with horses and dogs, from WW1 up to the present day.



It is interesting to note that the first veterinary surgeon joined in 1796, when their primary aim was to ensure that animals were

properly cared for, so maximizing their fitness for duty. That founding principle still applies today.



Note the three red plaques behind, honouring three members of the RAVC killed in action during recent times:



o Corporal Bryan CRIDDLE killed in 1973 by a remotely detonated ‘milk churn’ bomb in Northern Ireland. His dog, Jason, was blown 30

yards away by the explosion, but survived and attended his handler’s funeral at Blockley, nr Chipping Campden



o Lance Corporal Ken ROWE killed with his sniffer dog Sasha, during a Taliban ambush in Afghanistan in July 2008



o Lance Corporal Liam TASKER killed by small arms fire in March 2011 in Afghanistan. His dog Theo suffered a seizure and died on

returning to Camp Bastion. Theo was awarded a posthumous Dickin Medal



Other famous animal winners of the Dickin Medal were:



Gustave (Pigeon) - Brought the first Commercial news of the D-Day to the UK



Paddy (Pigeon) – Quickest time to bring news from Normandy back to UK



Duke of Normandy (Pigeon) -,Brought news of the capture of a gun battery at Merville by Paras of the 21st Army Group



Bing (Dog) - Bing was trained to locate the enemy and protect military personnel,



The Royal Army Veterinary Corps is responsible for the provision, training and care of animals and is part of the British

Army.



The Army Veterinary Service was established by public demand in 1796 to address the welfare of army horses. It became

the Army Veterinary Corps in 1903 and the Royal Army Veterinary Corps in 1918. In 1942 it amalgamated with the Remount

Service and from 1946 became responsible for managing the Army’s dog resources.



The memorial commemorates the service and sacrifice of officers and soldiers of the Royal Army Veterinary Corps and its

historical predecessors.



It was unveiled by HRH The Princess Royal (The Honorary Colonel-in-Chief) on 2 May 2016.



The memorial incorporates the badges of the Corps before and after 1919 and has two engravings showing the Corps work

with horses and dogs. The base on which the 3 one metre high black granite panels stand incorporates a ‘V’. In 1796, John

Shipp was the first veterinary surgeon commissioned into the Army. He joined the 11th Light Dragoons on 25 June 1796, a

date now recognised as the Foundation Day of the RAVC – John Shipp Day. The Army Veterinary Corps was formed in

1903 to unite veterinary officers under one badge. At the outbreak of WW1 there were 180 officers and 208 other ranks in

the Army Veterinary Corps. By 1918 this had increased to 1700 officers and 28,000 other ranks. King George V accorded

the Corps its Royal Warrant in 1919. Primarily concerned with horses, the Army Veterinary and Remount Service

amalgamated in 1942 and became responsible for managing the Army’s dog resources in 1946. During WW2 the use of dogs

for military purposes grew. Dogs are an invaluable aid to ground troops and since WW2 have been used in most operational

theatres

name: Royal Air Force Medical Services
description:
The Royal Air Force Medical Services is a branch of the Royal Air Force providing health care to RAF service personnel at

home and on deployed operations. The medical officers have specialist skills and provide essential support to aircrew, search

and rescue missions and emergency relief operations around the world.



The memorial to the Royal Air Force Medical Services is carved from an eight-foot (2.43 m) slab of Welsh slate and was

created by Martin Cook.



Its unusual position represents the angle of a scalpel blade, indicating the different angle the service takes from the rest of

the RAF. A glass disc, inset at the top of the memorial, displays the Caduceus symbol - a winged staff entwined with two

serpents. This symbol has its origin in Greek mythology and has since become associated with medicine

name: ROYAL MILITARY POLICE
description:
This memorial was originally sited at the RMP headquarters in Chichester and was unveiled by the Queen in 1982.



The model for the statue was Corporal Fox, and it has since been known as Foxy. Punishment for a minor offence was to polish the

brass plaque on Foxy. He is sculptured in a resin which gives a cast bronze appearance.



Formed in 1877 and known as Red Caps, they became part of the Adjutant General Corps in 1992. There are around 2,500 MP's in

the British Army today.

name: BLUES & ROYALS
description:
This memorial is in the shape of a horseshoe for the Household Cavalry, which was formed in 1969 from the merger of the Royal

Horse Guards (the Blues) and the Royal Dragoons (the Royals). The trees are blue and gold conifers. The Blues and Royals became part

of the Mercian Regiment in 2007.



Prince Harry, after passing out from Officer Training at Sandhurst in 2006, joined the B&R as a Second Lieutenant. He served in the

British Army for 10 years, attaining the rank of Captain and saw active service in Afghanistan 2007-8.



In the garden there is a raised section with the names of members of the B&R who lost their lives, including four who were killed in

1982 in Hyde Park in an IRA bomb attack. Seven horses also died in the attack.



A recent addition is a memorial to the other Cavalry Regiment that is part of the Household Division, The Lifeguards, who were

formed in 1660.



The Blues and Royals won 2 VCs in WW1.



The regiment lost 8 soldiers in the Droppinwell pub bombing at Ballykelly Northern IrelandI in December 1982.

name: GOLDEN GROVE
description:
This is one of our many non-military sites. The trees, which have golden bark, leaves or fruit have been sponsored for people who

have celebrated Golden Wedding Anniversaries.



The banks have been raised like an Iron Age fort, and Girl Guides from Staffordshire planted masses of yellow daffodils around the

inside of the banks.

name: POLISH MEMORIAL
description:
The elements to this memorial were made in Poland and brought here for construction.



The four figures represent the Polish army, navy, air force & underground movement. During WW2 the Polish were the 4th largest

fighting force on the Allied side, and note they are wearing British uniforms, which is all they had available.



They were also instrumental in helping to crack the Enigma Code as explained in one of the wall panels. Even before the war there

were Polish mathematicians working on the code, with considerable success.



Apparently, a German man who was helping to build the Enigma machine was badly in need of money, so in 1932 he sold some of

the paperwork to the French, who copied it to Poland. When Poland was invaded by Germany in 1939, the Polish underground people

made sure all the mathematicians’ work came to the UK, giving our own code breakers at Bletchley Park something to begin their own

work with.

name: THE SAPPER SUPPORT MEMORIAL
description:
Sapper support is a charity run by former soldiers, many of whom were Sappers (Royal Engineers). The man who started the charity

is an exSapper, Tim Evers, who set up the charity in 2014 after he learned one of his friends, himself a Sapper, had been suffering from

PTSD and had committed suicide.



The charity aims to help and support all service men and women suffering from PTSD and also our 999 emergency services. In 2017

it was voted the best new charity in the UK.



The beautiful cast bronze memorial here at the Arboretum is designed to give families and friends a place to reflect and remember

those who have left us battling with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder and other associated mental health illnesses.



The inscription encourages people to hold the hand of the statue, to reach out and remember those who are no longer with us.

name: AMBULANCE SERVICE
description:
The green granite memorial reflecting the medical green of the Ambulance Services was dedicated in 2004.



It is a lasting tribute to those ambulance staff who lost their lives whilst serving in the ambulance services of England, Scotland, Wales, Northern

Ireland, Republic of Ireland, Guernsey and Jersey.



The garden is in the shape of a large letter ‘A’ – being both the initial letter of the service and to stand for ‘Asclepius’, the Greek God of healing

and medicine.



On the memorial stone itself is the blue 6-pointed ‘Star of Life’ with the ‘Rod of Asclepius’ at its centre. This is now the internationally recognised

symbol for emergency medical service units and personnel.

name: IRISH INFANTRY
description:
During WW1 over 250,000 Irishmen volunteered to fight for the British Army. Thousands lost their lives, on the Menin Gate alone hundreds are

recorded.



The garden itself was consecrated in 2000 and commemorates all who have served and continue to serve. The original idea for this garden was to

create an acre of Ireland in the heart of the British Isles. The paved map of Ireland commemorates each of the Irish regiments.



In WW1 37 VCs were awarded. In WW2 8 VCs were awarded.



The youngest ever recorded British soldier to have died was an Irish lad named John Condon, aged 14yrs. He died on 24 May 191 5 at the 2nd

battle of Ypres and is buried at the Commonwealth War Graves Commission cemetery at Poelkapelle. On his stone it clearly states his age as 14

years.



All the trees and shrubs in the garden are of Irish origin. The tree in the corner is taken from a stand of oak in Northern Ireland, one of the few

trees said to have survived through the ice age 10,000 years ago.

name: QARANCS
description:
The history of this Corps dates back over 100 years to the time of Florence Nightingale. She could see the need for nurses to be part

of the British Army



She, along with others, was instrumental in lobbying for support of female military nurses.



In 1902 Queen Alexandra's Imperial Military Nursing Service (QAIMNS) was established. In 1949 the name changed to Queen

Alexandra's Royal Army Nursing Corps (QARANC) and in 1992 men were allowed to join the Corps.



The QA's of today train and nurse in a small number of military hospitals around the UK, also where the UK has a military presence

around the world, in such places as Germany, Poland, Cyprus, Canada, Afghanistan.



They are also attached to NHS hospitals in the UK.



They are always ready to be deployed anywhere in the world to support our troops unfortunately a number lost their lives.



Sister Joyce Kathleen Atkin, Queen Alexandra’s Imperial Military Nursing Service was killed at sea on the 12th February 1944,

when the SS Khedive Ismail was torpedoed by a Japanese submarine in the Indian Ocean whilst on route from Mombasa to

Colombo.



Nellie Spindler was a staff nurse; she was killed during the Battle of Passchendaele

name: ARMY AIR CORPS
description:
On our left we have a striking brass eagle memorial for the Army Air Corps. The plinth is made of Portland stone and the darker stone

in the circular base represents helicopter rotor blades. The Corps supplies air support to the Army in the form of an attack helicopter,

the Apache, or reconnaissance & transportation of troops or supplies, in the form of the Wildcat helicopter.



They also use the Gazelle for observation and reconnaissance, and the Bell 212 which is used predominantly in jungle areas.

name: BOMB DISPOSAL
description:
One can only describe these people as ‘The bravest of the brave’ for what they do.



This memorial shows a soldier on what they call ‘The Long Walk’ towards an IED – an improvised explosive device, which he must

make safe.



He is wearing a suit which gives some protection from blast and fragmentation and is carrying what they call a ‘disruptor’. Beside him

is a piece of electronic counter measure equipment.



The cartoon cat on the base relates to ‘Felix’, the unofficial mascot of the British Army counter-terrorism bomb disposal units,

probably because cats have always been associated with luck and their ability to land on their feet.



The Bomb Disposal Charity, which provides assistance to personnel and their families, is also known as ‘The Felix Fund’.



Lisa Head was was the first female bomb disposal officer to be killed on operations.[2] She died on 19 April 2011 at the age of 29,

having sustained serious injuries on active service in Afghanistan,

name: SMALL ARMS SCHOOL MEMORIAL
description:
Founded in 1853 by Lord Hardinge, it is a small Corp of the British Army. Its personnel provide advice and instruction to infantry

weapon trainers throughout the army in order to maintain the proficiency in the use of small arms and support weapons and range

management.



The memorial shows a soldier from around the 1800s holding a land Pattern Musket, known as "Brown Bess". This musket first saw

service in 1704.

name: THE ROYAL REGIMENT OF FUSILIERS
description:
There have been Fusilier Regiments in the British Army for over 400 years. This memorial shows the Regimental Colour of the 1st

Battalion and the Queen’s Colour. The Royal Regiment was formed from the amalgamation of 4 other Fusilier Regiments in 1968.



(Drummer Lee Rigby, who was murdered outside an Army barracks in London in May 2013, belonged to this Regiment. His name is

now engraved on the AFM wall, Panel #227B).

name: GIFFARD AVENUE
description:
The Avenue is named after Peter Giffard, a former President of the Country Landowners’ Association who was a keen supporter of

the NMA in its early days. He lost a leg during WW2 in Italy and became an active member of BLESMA (British Limbless Ex-

Servicemen’s Association).

name: “Y” LISTENING GROUP
description:
The paths in this garden are laid out in the form of a letter ‘Y’.



“Y” comes from the initials for “Wireless Interception”…….”WI” sound like “Y”



Inspiration for the memorial came from a group of ATS (Auxiliary Territorial Service) ladies who served in the War Office ‘Y’



Group at Beaumanor Hall, near Loughborough and other such stations.



During WW2 men and women who were found to have the required skills and passed intensive Morse code training were



recruited to serve at secret listening stations around the UK to monitor German radio transmissions which had been



encoded using Enigma machines.



Once intercepted the enemy's military messages, still in code, were sent to Bletchley Park - also known as Station X - to be



decrypted by its talented, ingenious and often eccentric code-breakers.



The Germans did not believe that radio messages sent over short distances in occupied Europe could be picked up in



England. They could! In short, without the Y Service, Bletchley would not have had the coded Enigma messages to decipher,



and the work of these combined teams of many thousands of secret and silent heroes is now widely acknowledged as having



shortened WW2 by at least two years.



Winston Churchill called those involved his "geese that laid the golden eggs but never cackled".



In the right-hand corner is a bench in memory of the 3 Royal Navy men from the warship HMS Petard - Colin Grazier, Tony



Fasson and Tommy Brown - who were instrumental in recovering code books from a sinking German submarine in 1942,



which helped considerably in breaking the German Enigma code.



Unfortunately, Colin Grazier (a native of Tamworth) and Tony Fasson drowned when the submarine sank. Both were



awarded the George Cross.

name: GENERAL POST OFFICE MEMORIAL GARDEN
description:
In the first half of the 20th Century, the Post Office was the largest peacetime state employer in the United Kingdom,



responsible for operating the postal, telephone and telegraph services. In wartime its staff had to rise to the immense



challenge of meeting both civil and military communication requirements. Many transferred to the armed services where



they often applied their experience and skills to communication work.



In 1939 73,000 GPO workers were called into the services, just when mobilisation and evacuation caused millions of people



to change address, so increasing the amount of mail posted and the problems of delivering it during the blackout. Post



Offices played a key role by distributing millions of ration books, public information leaflets, and paying out allowances.



GPO staff served in all arms of the fighting forces and 3,800 of them died.



The path is laid out in the shape of the Royal Mail insignia.



The older EIIR pillar boxes are from the period 1952 - 1991 and ‘Royal Mail’ appeared on them first in 1991. All have the



crowns of the relevant Sovereign at the time. There are boxes for Edward VII and George VI.



The green Victorian wall post box was blown out of its wall in Deptford, London during the blitz - note the damage - but the



local people rebuilt the wall and replaced the box to keep the service running.



2023: The memorial garden is due to be redeveloped

name: HALTON GROVE
description:
The memorial garden to the Halton Apprentices and its centrepiece, the RAF Apprentice wheel badge, remembers the



association between Halton House in Buckinghamshire and the RAF which began in 1912, when the de Rothschild family



allowed its use for training.



Halton House was purchased by the Government from the de Rothschild family in 1919.



The apprentices were known as 'Trenchard’s Brats', after Lord Trenchard the founder of the RAF (which was formed on 1st



April 1918).



The grove is a tribute to all those who passed through the training establishment learning various skilled trades.



Usually the young men completed a 3-year apprenticeship with intakes from 1920 until 1993 and during those 73 years



some 40,000 young men and women were trained.



Frank Whittle, inventor of the jet engine, was a Halton apprentice. Here you will see a paviour dedicated to him and a larger



one to Don Finlay the Olympic athlete who was also an apprentice.



Another example of how people or organisations can be remembered the plaque and tree in honour of Sergeant Thomas



GRAY, a former Halton Apprentice, who lost his life in 1940 when the plane in which he was navigator was shot down after a



bombing raid to destroy a bridge in Belgium.



He was awarded the Victoria Cross for bravery and his skill in navigating to the correct target, which they bombed



successfully.



Sergeant Gray had 6 brothers, 3 of whom were also killed in action during WW2.



By pushing the buttons on the information board, you can hear audio presentations about some of the events and people



involved at RAF Halton over the years.



RAF Halton is still operational and nowadays provides training for most new recruits to the RAF, plus highly specialised



training for members of all 3 armed services.

name: BLESMA
description:
BLESMA stands for British Limbless Ex-Service Men’s Association



BLESMA was formed in 1932



BELSMA works to assist those who have lost limbs as a result of service in any branch of Her Majesty's Armed Forces.



The garden is planted mostly with fruit trees which are kept purposely at a low height to allow easy access for those in



wheelchairs both to smell the blossom in spring and harvest the fruit in autumn.



An apple or pear, of course, does not need to be peeled for eating (requiring two hands)



The circular benches do not have any arm rests. A service person may have lost their arms.

name: THE INNER WHEEL GARDEN
description:
The Inner wheel was founded in Manchester on 10 January 1924. This date is now celebrated as World Inner Wheel Day



Many of its members are female spouses, partners and relatives of Rotary International Members



The design of the grove is based on the Inner Wheel badge



The entrance to the grove was enhanced by the erection of wrought iron gates, which were dedicated in March 2009.



The motto of the Inner Wheel is “Service and Friendship”



The Inner Wheel is one of the largest women’s international voluntary organisations in the world

name: THE SANDS GARDEN
description:
Stillbirth and Neonatal Death Charity



The aims of the SANDS organisation aim is to save babies lives and to support bereaved families



SANDS was founded in 1978 and aims to support anyone affected by the death of a baby, providing services to parents and



their families, promoting changes in antenatal practice and funding research that could help to reduce infant mortality rates.



The garden has been designed to reflect the emotional journey that many parents face when coming to terms with their



bereavement, starting with harsh foliage which becomes progressively softer as you move along the path.



It is a very quiet and tranquil place for people to remember.



At the heart of the garden is the Portland stone sculpture of a baby and the SANDS logo which represents an eye and a glass



teardrop set into the ground.

name: FIRE AND RESCUE SERVICE
description:
This impressive red granite memorial acknowledges the service and courage of past, present and future fire fighters.



The 8 points of the star attached to the memorial represents the qualities needed to be a fire-fighter - Tact, Gallantry,



Dexterity, Observation, Perseverance, Loyalty, Explicitness, and Sympathy.



On the back the memorial bears the inscription ‘Firefighters Serving Humanity’ and the Latin motto ‘Flammas Oppugnantes



Fidimus Deo’. This translates as ‘Fighting Fire Our Trust in God’ and is the motto of the Worshipful Company of Firefighters.



The red stone of the memorial represents flame



The grey paving stones and memorial plinth represents ash



The memorial was unveiled on 20 May 2008 by HRH The Princess Royal, patron of the Firefighters Memorial Trust

name: CIVIL DEFENCE
description:
This memorial remembers the efforts of those who served their country by looking after the people here at home during the



Second World War. These men and women served in many roles such as wardens, rescuers, firewatchers, and welfare



workers. Many lives were lost.



ARP stands for Air Raid Precautions (Warden Hodges in Dad’s Army)



1.9 million people served in the Civil Defence during the Second World War



Nearly 7000 were killed carrying out their role with the Civil Defence in the Second World War



The large stone is a memorial to the humans while the small stone represents the animals that helped in the rescues. If you



look closely at the large stone, there are drill marks on its side to signify the importance of mechanical help during a rescue.



The stone to the right remembers those who were awarded the George Cross for Civil Defence duties



The large memorial at the back of the garden honours members of Civil Defence during the ‘Cold War’ period 1949 - 1968.

name: ROYAL AIR FORCE REGIMENT
description:
The Royal Air Force Regiment was formed in 1942 to provide specialist ground force protection for military airbases, without



having to call upon the Army.



The large black granite memorial remembers all those who have lost their lives while serving in the Regiment, while



inscribed on the reverse are listed the countries in which the Regiment had served up until the memorial’s dedication in



2001.



The pathway is shaped like an airport runway.



The Corps motto is “Per Ardua” which means “Through Adversity”



Peter Alliss, “The Voice of Golf” has a memorial stone in the garden as he served in the RFA Regiment

name: WOMEN’s ROYAL ARMY CORPS
description:
Women served in both World Wars in various units and by the end of the Second World War it was acknowledged that



women would be a valuable asset to a peace-time army, so the Women’s Royal Army Corps was formed.



They served all over the world in over 35 trades and over 1200 died in service.



The WRAC was disbanded in 1992



The raised beds form the letter ‘W’, while the trees and bushes either have ladies’ names or their foliage/flowers are the



colours of the women’s uniforms.



Also in the garden is are two statues dedicated to all the women who served in the Auxiliary Territorial Service (ATS).



When the ATS was formed in 1938 there were 5 main trades: Cook, Clerk, Orderly, Store woman and Driver but as time



passed, more and more trades were taken over, including highly-skilled and technical work and tasks which the organisation



of the army depended upon, such as equipment and ammunition



The Queen served in the ATS as 2nd Lieutenant Elizabeth Windsor as did Mary Churchill, the youngest daughter of Winston.



The ATS and WRAC memorials were both designed by Andy de Comyn



Andy de Comyn also designed the Shot at Dawn, Mercian Volunteers, Women’s RAF and National Miners memorials at the



NMA



The ATS ACK- ACK memorial was relocated into this garden when the National Miners Memorial was erected at the NMA



During WW1 the code for the letter A in the phonetic alphabet was ‘Ack’, so the AA of Anti-Aircraft became ‘Ack-Ack’.



These girls had a strong link with the Royal Artillery, especially working alongside them in the anti-aircraft batteries. Officially



the girls did everything apart from firing the guns (this was a political decision rather than a physical one), but we have had



former ‘Ack-Ack’ ladies here who tell us they most certainly DID fire the guns, saying there is no way they would let their



homes be bombed just because there wasn’t a man there to pull the lever

name: NATIONAL MINERS MEMORIAL
description:
The memorial commemorates the men, women and children who worked in the UK coal mining industry and served or died



in the service of their country



The artist for the memorial was Andy de Comyn



Andy de Comyn was the artist for the ATS, WRAF, WRAC, Mercian Volunteers and Shot at Dawn memorials at the NMA



Francesca de Comyn was the illustrator



47 miners were awarded the Victoria Cross in the 2 world wars (45 during 1914-18 and 2 during 1939-45)



Sapper William Hackett, Royal Engineers, is the only miner to be awarded a VC for his work in tunnels underground. He



refused to leave a wounded fellow miner in a tunnel after a collapse.

name: ROYAL ARTILLERY
description:
The Royal Artillery dates back to the 18th century and grew to become larger than the Royal Navy after the Second World



War.



The garden has two seats designed in the shape of gun carriages



Charcoal from the alder was used in early gunpowder and the village name of Alrewas, just down the road, is believed to



derive from the ancient English name of Alder Wash meaning “alder trees at the water” (the River Trent runs at the side of



Alrewas).



UBIQUE is a Latin word meaning ‘everywhere’ (The Royal Artillery served “everywhere “ that the British armed forces go)



Also remembered in this garden are the Royal Artillery Horse.

name: CHILDRENS SENSORY GARDEN
description:
Even the Children's garden has symbolism within it. You can see a circle of red posts for jumping and balancing on with a



central black post symbolising a poppy. The boards under the climbing frame symbolise the duck boards used in the trenches



in WWI, and the large circular climbing net represents a globe and hope for world peace.



The large wooden figures at the entrance are characters from Wind in the Willows. They were carved by the Essex



Woodcarvers.



Dogs are not allowed into the garden

name: FAULD EXPLOSION
description:
This was one of the largest non-nuclear explosions in history, and the largest to occur on UK soil.



Fauld is located about 10 miles from the Arboretum, between Burton on Trent and Uttoxeter.



The large boulder forms a memorial to those who died in an explosion at the underground bomb and ammunition dump.



In November 1944, bombs and ammunition stored in the Gypsum mine in were accidentally detonated killing 70 people



It is believed that a quantity of undetonated explosive still lies below ground.



The crater is still clearly visible to walkers today and is best seen walking from Hanbury village

name: SIR LEONARD CHESHIRE AMPHITHEATRE
description:
Group Captain Sir Leonard Cheshire was a WW2 ace and was awarded the VC, OM, DSO & two Bars, DFC and Mentioned in



Despatches.



He was Group Captain when he joined 617 Squadron, famously known as the Dambusters, as its Commander



After the war he was heavily involved in charity work and set up a charity with his wife Sue Ryder, called The Ryder-Cheshire



Foundation.



Sir Leonard was instrumental in starting a germ of an idea for the NMA. A conversation took place in the late 80's between



Sir Leonard and Commander David Childs and both were concerned that we, as a country were beginning to forget to



remember the sacrifice that so many made for us.



From that conversation came a germ of an idea for some kind of a National Centre of Remembrance, which David Childs saw



through to fruition.

name: THE BELL
description:
Donated by NMA volunteer Les Wills MBE in memory of his wife, Betty who served in the WRNS



The bell is from one of the Bedford Fire Appliances used in Birmingham between 1960-70.



The bell was presented to Les on his retirement from the fire service

name: LICHFIELD AND DISTRICT GARDEN
description:
The seat with a canopy represents the three spires of Lichfield Cathedral



Arranged around the seat is a planting of trees, one for each parish with the Lichfield District



The trees were sponsored by each parish

name: The Western Front Association Memorial
description:
On the side of the memorial shown is the second verse of ‘For the Fallen’ used on many occasions of

remembrance. On the reverse are the two final lines from the poem ‘Aftermath’ by Siegfried Sassoon.



For the Fallen - Robert Lawrence Binyon CH (1869-1943)



They went with songs to the battle, they were young.

Straight of limb, true of eye, steady and aglow.

They were staunch to the end against odds uncounted,

They fell with their faces to the foe.



They shall grow not old, as we that are left grow old:

Age shall not weary them, nor the years condemn.

At the going down of the sun and in the morning,

We will remember them.



They mingle not with their laughing comrades again;

They sit no more at familiar tables of home;

They have no lot in our labour of the day-time;

They sleep beyond England's foam



Laurence Binyon came from a Quaker family and after graduating at Trinity College, Oxford worked in the

Department of printed Books at the British Museum. He wrote this poem in 1914 and in 1915 being too

old to fight volunteered at a British hospital for French Soldiers.



Note the error on the memorial.

name: ROYAL GLOUCESTERSHIRE, BERKSHIRE AND WILTSHIRE REGIMENT
description:
This amalgamated regiment was formed in 1994 and became part of the Rifles in 2007.



It was the only regiment in the British Army allowed to wear cap badges on the front and rear of their headdress. The second



badge was awarded to their forebears (28th Regiment of Foot) for fighting ‘back-to-back’ against Napoleon's French Army in Egypt



at the Battle of Alexandria in 1801. The rear rank was given the order to ‘about turn’ so the front and rear rank fought back-to-



back.

name: SHOWMEN’S GUILD OF GREAT BRITAIN
description:
The memorial is dedicated to those members of the Guild who lost their lives serving their country in the two World Wars. It



includes James, the carousel horse, reminding us that the Showmen moved around with travelling fairs.



It was a tradition that the first son of the family would become a showman himself, while the second son would join the



military.



During the two World Wars, more than 3,000 showmen volunteered to fight. Of these, about a quarter were killed in the line



of duty.



On the home front during WW2, show people raised money to pay for a fleet of 19 ambulances and £5,000 for a Spitfire in



1943. This was named ‘The Fun of the Fair’ and was allocated to a Polish squadron, seeing extensive action until it was shot



down over France in 1945.

name: DEVONSHIRE AND DORSET REGIMENT
description:
The Devonshire Regiment was first raised in 1685 and served under various names, until 1881 when it officially became The



Devonshire Regiment. The Dorset Regiment was formed in 1881. The two regiments were amalgamated in 1958, ultimately



being merged with various other regiments (represented by several memorials on this walk) to form the Rifles in 2007.



Three soldiers sculptured in cast bronze are depicted on this Portland stone memorial:



On the left is a soldier of the Devonshire Regiment in 1916 at the Somme.



On the right is a soldier from the Dorset Regiment in 1944 in Kohima, as part of the Burma Campaign.



In the middle is a soldier from the Devonshire and Dorset Regiment on patrol in Northern Ireland in the 1970s.



In 1960 a newly commissioned officer, Herbert Jones joined the Devonshire and Dorset Regiment as a Second Lieutenant and



served with them until he transferred to the Parachute Regiment in 1979, attaining the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. In 1982, H



Jones, as he was known, was part of the task force in the Falklands conflict. At the battle of Goose Green, he was killed after



displaying great leadership and courage. For this, he was posthumously awarded the VC

name: ROYAL CORPS OF SIGNALS
description:
The statue is of Mercury, messenger to the Gods, which is also the cap badge of the Royal Corps of Signals. He is affectionately



known as Jimmy, possibly after Jimmy Emblem, who was a member of the Corps and Army Boxing Champion in 1924, though



this is not certain. Take note of ‘the wind’ on which Mercury is standing.



The Royal Signals was formed in 1920. It was formerly The Royal Engineers Signal Service.



The Signals provide communications and ensure the passage of information, which is vital to successful military operations.



The motto is ‘Certa Cito’, which translates to ‘sure and swift’.



Colonel-in-Chief is the Princess Royal.

name: ESSEX REGIMENT
description:
This 4m high Portland stone obelisk, with Essex flints around the base, is the memorial for the Essex Regiment. It stands on



paving in the shape of Gibraltar Fort, reflecting the regiment’s service there, with a bronze and gold Salamanca Eagle



(created by Ian Rank-Broadley) on top.



The original eagle was taken from the French at the battle of Salamanca in 1812. The Royal Anglian Regiment, successor of



the Essex Regiment, still have the Eagle as a shoulder patch on their uniforms.



On the side panels are a map of Essex and the regiment’s battle honours, including winners of the Victoria Cross. (Spelling of



serjeant is correct here - some regiments used ‘j’ instead of ‘g’ at that time).

name: PARACHUTE SQUADRON (ROYAL ARMOURED CORPS)
description:
Formed in 1965 (the Cold War era), the Squadron had specialist roles of reconnaissance and long-range anti-tank capability. All

their equipment and vehicles could be delivered by parachute.



The squadron saw service in Aden; Cyprus with a UN Peacekeeping Force; and Northern Ireland.

The unit was disbanded in 1976.

name: PARACHUTE REGIMENT AND AIRBORNE FORCES
description:
Features the emblem of the Airborne Forces – the winged horse Pegasus with rider Bellerophon on a Portland stone plinth. In



Greek mythology they flew to the lair of, and killed, the monster Chimera (pronounced Ky-meera).



Beneath is a parachutist recovering his Bergen (pack), which would have been attached to his waist belt and hang below him



as he came down. It would hit the ground first, making the soldier aware that he was about to contact the ground himself.



The inscription around the top edge beginning “What manner of men are these….” is part of a quotation by Field Marshall



the Viscount Montgomery.



The establishment of airborne forces was instigated by Winston Churchill in 1940. It had its first operation in 1941 in



southern Italy, code named Operation Colossus.

name: QUEEN’S DRAGOON GUARDS
description:
The memorial features a stone monolith, remembering those who served in:



1st Queen’s Dragoon Guards



1st King’s Dragoon Guards



The Queen’s Bays (2nd Dragoon Guards)



Cavalry regiments converted to armoured cars and tanks in the 1930s.

name: DURHAM LIGHT INFANTRY
description:
The memorial depicts a statue of a Durham Light Infantry bugler dressed in combat uniform of the Korean War. An identical



statue stands in Durham city centre.



The DLI amalgamated with other regiments to form the Light Infantry in 1968 (refer to the neighbouring memorial).



The bugle is the symbol of all Light Infantry Regiments and is present on their badges – dating from the days when they were



the lightest and most mobile units in the British Army, and the bugle was essential for issuing orders.

name: LIGHT INFANTRY
description:
This Portland stone monolith and adjacent benches are ‘In proud memory of all who served in the Light Infantry’. The 8 regiments



represented on the two benches formed the Light Infantry in 1968 (refer to the neighbouring DLI and KSLI memorials). At one time,



the Light Infantry was the largest infantry regiment in the British Army.



In 2007, the Light Infantry became part of a new larger regiment, The Rifles, which still retains the bugle cap badge featured on the



stone monolith.



The Colonels-in-Chief of the Rifles, the Paras, the Intelligence Corps, and REME are the Queen Consort, King Charles lll, the Princess



Royal, and the Countess of Wessex respectively.

name: KING’S SHROPSHIRE LIGHT INFANTRY
description:
The KSLI was officially formed in 1881, although the regiment can trace its roots back to 1755. The colourful memorial



depicts the Regiment’s colours and battle honours, along with the bugle cap badge.

name: THE MALL
description:
This avenue is referred to as The Mall. Whilst not as wide and straight as The Mall in London, it is lined with London Plane trees (which



also line the Mall in London). Between these trees are some flowering cherry trees, the blossom representing the red tunics of the



guardsmen lining the route on state occasions.

name: Guardsmen of the Sky
description:
The memorial, created by Jemma Pearson and unveiled on 8 October 2021, takes the form of a Guards Parachute Company



NCO in full battle order striding off a drop-zone. The figure in bronze stands on a Scoutmore Yorkstone plinth and a stone base



displaying engraved Household Division cap badges, the Household Division star, and Airborne Forces Pegasus.



At the end of WW2 the 1st Guards Parachute Battalion was created, and later the elite 1st Guards Independent Company ( the



Pathfinder Company ).



The Company then served at Suez and in Borneo and at the end of that campaign in 1966 formed the third squadron of the



SAS ( G Squadron ).



In 1975 the Company was disbanded but guards continue to serve in airborne forces; the Household Division were represented



in the Brigade Pathfinder Platoon during the 1980 / 90's. Today those links continue through the 6th ( Guards ) Platoon in 3



Para. The Platoon can count among its number L/Cpl James Ashworth, posthumously awarded the VC in 2012 during service



in Afghanistan

name: ROYAL ELECTRICAL AND MECHANICAL ENGINEERS (REME)
description:
The Corps of Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers maintains the equipment used by the British Army. They serve wherever



in the world the Army is deployed.



The memorial is dedicated to past and present members of the Corps and depicts both their former and current badges.



During WW2 the Army had difficulty providing training in maintenance and repair of its increasingly sophisticated vehicles and



weapons. REME was established in 1942 to meet these technological challenges.



The corps has the rare distinction of being granted the Royal prefix on the day of its formation.



Its motto is ‘Arte et Marte’ which translates to ‘By skill and fighting’.



Major Ivan Hirst of REME took on the Volkswagen plant in Wolfsburg in 1945, initially to make and repair cars for the British



Army. Eventually, he helped turn VW into today’s well-known brand.

name: ARMY APPRENTICE NATIONAL MEMORIAL
description:
This memorial is dedicated to all the young soldiers who undertook technical apprenticeship training, usually lasting 3 years,



at one of the four main schools named (Chepstow, Arborfield, Harrogate and Carlisle), and in memory of those who gave their



lives for it.



More than 70,000 apprentices (aged 14-17) were trained between 1923 and 2004, before passing out to serve in the Regular



Army as soldier/tradesmen.



The memorial consists of an engraved and polished granite monolith, carrying the Army Apprentices School badge, set on a



circular granite base. The granite paviours were sponsored by former apprentices and/or their families and give the dates of



their apprenticeships.

name: THE HOUSEHOLD DIVISION
description:
The Household Division collectively includes the five Foot Guards (Grenadier; Scots; Welsh; Irish; Coldstream – in the order of the



badges mounted on the replica railings of Chelsea Barracks) and the two Mounted Guards (Life Guards; Blues and Royals – with their



badges carved into the plinth on the left and right respectively).



The badges of the Household Cavalry are in the most senior positions on the memorial, out on the flanks.



The badges of the Foot Guards are in the order that the regiments would have been placed when facing the enemy (in reverse order



when seen from the front). The most senior regiments are on the flanks and the junior regiment (Welsh Guards) in the centre.



On the rear are the mottos of the regiments:



Grenadier - ‘Evil be to him who evil thinks’



Scots - ‘No one assails me with impunity’



Welsh - ‘Wales for ever’



Irish - ‘Who shall separate us’



Coldstream - ‘Second to none’



Although the Coldstream Guards were formed first, they are second in order of seniority as they originally served the Scottish



Crown and only came to serve the English Crown after the formation of the Grenadier Guards.



Seniority of the regiments is also indicated by spacing of the buttons on dress uniform tunics. Grenadier (most senior) have



single spaced buttons; Coldstream (next senior) have buttons in pairs; Scots Guards in 3s; Irish in 4s; and Welsh (most junior)



in 5s.



The interlocking paving stones are England (white granite), Scotland (red granite), Ireland (green limestone) and Wales (black



slate). The stones represent the union of the regiments, despite their rivalry.



To the rear of the memorial are five Wellingtonia trees, also known as Giant Redwood or Giant Sequoia. These trees were



chosen because the connections between the Duke of Wellington and the Guards during the Napoleonic Wars.

name: INTELLIGENCE CORPS
description:
The monolith is a memorial to those who served in the Intelligence Corps.

This British Army unit was originally formed in 1914. It is responsible for collecting, analysing and disseminating mil itary



intelligence and also for counter-intelligence and security.

The corps’ personnel are engaged in a range of activities, including analysing human intelligence, signals and image intelligence,



electronic warfare, counter-intelligence, field security, carrying out interrogations and dealing with cyber threats.

Members of the corps have taken part in most of the Army's deployments since 1945.

The motto translates to ‘knowledge gives strength to the arm’. The roses (‘Cognito’), inspired by the motto and the badge, were



specially commissioned for the memorial.

name: GCHQ (GOVERNMENT COMMUNICATIONS HEADQUARTERS)
description:
The globe of pink granite is a tribute to all those who have served, and continue to serve, in the vital departments gathering information

to support the British Government in its overseas and domestic operations.



On the theme of communications, the morse code message reads ‘GC&CS’ (the former name of the organisation being Government

Code & Cypher School). The binary code reads ‘GCHQ’.



GC&CS was formed in 1919. During WW2 it was stationed at Bletchley Park, working on the breaking of the Enigma code, and began

to call itself GCHQ. In the 1950s it moved to Cheltenham, which is where its main offices are now.



GCHQ is the UK’s intelligence and cyber agency. Its mission is to help keep the country safe through intelligence gathering for the

purposes of:



Counter terrorism

Cyber security

Tackling serious and organised crime

To gain strategic advantage over potential hostile nations

Supporting defence



The location of the memorial is deliberately concealed to suggest the organisation’s involvement with covert operations.

name: NOT FORGOTTEN ASSOCIATION
description:
In 1919 American soprano Marta Cunningham visited a Ministry of Pensions hospital, having heard that there were ‘perhaps a



handful’ of soldiers wounded in WWI still residing there. She called on the Matron and asked if she had a few lonely patients



who would like to come out for tea. The Matron looked surprised and replied that there were in fact 600 injured patients lying



in the hospital, with many more across the country. Marta was horrified by what she saw.



An avid charity worker during the Great War, Marta soon set about contacting her friends to organise tea parties, concerts and



outings for those able to attend. During one of these early invitations one injured soldier said: “We don’t want no charity Miss,



we are forgotten by everybody and we’d better stop so.” But, undeterred, in August 1920, Marta formed the “NOT



FORGOTTEN” Association for the ‘comfort, cheer and entertainment’ of the war wounded and within a year some 10,000 men



had been entertained.



The memorial is made of solid green polished granite with a sculptured elephant’s head on top. The elephant and sword form



the basis of the emblem of the association.



The plaque on the ground outlines the part of Marta Cunningham in setting up the Association.



The Not Forgotten Association is a charity that continues to provide events for wounded serving personnel and disabled



veterans, which improve physical and mental health, address isolation and loneliness, and provide a sense of community and



balance.



The Victoria Cross



The Victoria Cross is awarded for:-



... most conspicuous bravery, or some daring or pre-eminent act of valour or self-sacrifice, or extreme devotion to duty in

the presence of the enemy.



The VC is the first level award for all ranks of the British armed forces.



The Victoria Cross was founded by Royal Warrant dated 29th January 1856. Queen Victoria presented the first 62 awards in

Hyde Park on 26th June 1857: 12 Navy, 2 Royal Marines and 48 Army.



The warrant has been amended several times. E.g.:



In 1902 King Edward VII approved the principle of awarding the VC posthumously.

On 21st October 1911 King George V admitted native officers and other ranks of the Indian Army to eligibility for



the VC.

The warrant of 22nd May 1922 extended the scope of the award to include members of the RAF, and ‘Air Forces of



our Dominions, Colonies, Dependencies or Protectorates’; and ‘Matrons, sisters, nurses and staff of the Nursing

Services and other services pertaining to Hospitals and Nursing and civilians of either sex serving regularly or

Temporarily under the orders, direction or supervision’ of specified Naval Military or Air Forces.



The medal, made from the bronze cascabels of cannon captured at Sebastopol, has always been manufactured by Messrs

Hancocks of London.



The ribbon, 1½ inches wide, has been crimson since the Royal Warrant of 22nd May 1920 (originally it was crimson for the

army and dark blue for the navy) and the inscription on the medal reads ‘FOR VALOUR’. When the ribbon is worn alone a

miniature of the V.C. is placed at the centre of the ribbon.



The bar to the V.C. has been awarded on only three occasions: Captain Arthur Martin-Leake R.A.M.C. (Vlakfontein, South

Africa 1902 and Zonnebeke 1914), Captain Noel Godfrey Chavasse R.A.M.C. (Guillemont 1916 and Wieltje1917) and

Captain Charles Hazlitt Upham NZ Army (Crete 1941 and Western Desert 1942).



The Victoria Cross has been awarded on1358 occasions; to 1355 individuals, the three bars mentioned above and one to the

Unknown Soldier buried in Arlington National Cemetery, Washington, DC. In addition to British service personnel it has

been awarded to 5 civilians and to 14 non British Empire/Commonwealth citizens.



In recent years Canada, Australia and New Zealand have awarded their own version of the Victoria Cross through their own

honours systems. One New Zealand VC and 4 Australian VCs have been awarded.



Five of the largest public collections of Victoria Cross’ are in the Australian War Memorial which has 80 (including 10 on

loan), The Imperial War Museum which has 45 (including 28 on loan), the National Army Museum which has 40 (including

1 one loan), The Canadian War Museum (which has 39) and the Museum of Military Medicine which has 23. The largest

private collection is the Ashcroft Collection which has 213 (displayed in the Imperial War Museum).

name: ATOMIC BOMBING
description:
On the 6th August 1945 our American allies dropped the first ever atomic bomb on the Japanese city of Hiroshima killing around

150,000.



The bomb was given the name "Little Boy"



The bomb itself was a uranium gun type.



It was widely felt that after the bombing of Hiroshima the Japanese would surrender but to surrender was not an option the Japanese

would consider; they fought on.



Three days later on the 9th August a second atomic bomb called "Fat Man" was dropped on the Japanese city of Nagasaki. This time

it was a plutonium implosion-type bomb which caused around 80,000 deaths.



On this bombing raid Group Captain Leonard Cheshire was an official observer on the American B-29 bomber.



But the Japanese fought on until the Emperor at the time, Michinomiya Hirohito, of who it is said was considered a living God by his

people, finally brought the war to an end on the 15th August 1945.



As we make our way towards the Anglo-Japanese Grove of Reconciliation, would like to point out just a few memorials to regiments

that fought in the war with Japan.



On our left The Staffordshire Regiment, a tree on the army parade to the Sherwood Foresters, over on the right The Green Howard's,

and The West Kent’s. Finish walk on the AFM looking down on the Anglo-Japanese Grove of Reconciliation.

name: ANGLO-JAPANESE GROVE OF RECONCILIATION
description:
The circular grove of European and Japanese maple trees is the ANGLOJAPANESE GROVE OF RECONCILIATION, presented by Japanese

business people. The intermingling of their leaves symbolizes the strengthening friendship between the two nations, as does the pink

granite STONE OF RECONCILIATION itself, which was presented to us by the Japanese Government.



Adjacent to it is the HIROSHIMA CAIRN. The top-most stone was donated by the people of HIROSHIMA, the Japanese city destroyed

by a bomb (named Little Boy) in August 1945 and is dedicated to the millions of people who died and suffered in the Second World

War.



8TH ARMY (DESERT RATS)



8th Army was a field army formation of the British army established in 1941 until 1945.



The army was made up of many soldiers from around the Commonwealth.



They fought in the Western Desert Campaign, Tunisia, Sicilian and Italian Campaigns.



Special operations units were set up from 8th Army, including Popski's Private Army who have a memorial on our special forces area.

name: DESERT RATS
description:
Located by Lions Shelter and Gulf War Memorial

The 7th Armoured Division was a division of the British Army that saw distinguished service during World War II, where its



exploits in the Western Desert Campaign gained it the ‘Desert Rats’ nickname. Since then, the desert rats insignia has been

worn by generations of military units, celebrating the kinship and tenacity of those men and women fighting in the desert.



The stylised sculpture, whilst representing the Desert Rats insignia, also symbolises armour, both light and heavy.



The sculpture sits on a stone plinth, with sloping sides to represent the angles used on some armour and tanks. The sides of

the plinth are carved with a sand motif with the words “Desert Rats” engraved and fading in and out of the pattern to

suggest movement through time and sand.

name: TOBRUK
description:
Half-way down is a memorial to those involved in the siege of Tobruk.



Tobruk is the only deep-water port in Eastern Libya which British Forces were occupying in 1941. It was attacked by German and

Italian forces and was under siege for 241 days - the longest siege in the history of the British Army. Our forces managed to repel the

invaders and keep control.1

name: 1ST ARMY
description:
1st Army was first formed in WW1 1914-1918, then disbanded only to be reformed in WW2 1942-1943. They were reformed to fight

in Operation Torch the allied invasion of North Africa. After the allied victory in 1943 the 1st Army was disbanded.

name: MALTA
description:
In the middle is a memorial to Malta, known as The George Cross Island. The people of Malta defended their island against the

German/Italian invasion in 1941. Although the islanders were close to starvation and running out of



ammunition, they fought on regardless to defend the island successfully.



The island was an essential base for the British.



In recognition of the bravery of the islanders, on 15 April 1942, King George VI awarded the George Cross to the people of Malta.

name: MONTE CASSINO
description:
A major addition in 2012 was a memorial to the 1944 battle for Monte Cassino, an historic hilltop abbey in Italy, which cost the Allies

55,000casualties to dislodge the defending Germans in order to advance on to

name: ITALIAN STAR
