description: This memorial recognises the achievements and sacrifices of the British Forces fighting in Italy in WW2.

name: GIBRALTAR
description:
Gibraltar has been under British control since 1704. "The Rock" is a deepwater harbour which during WW2 provided the British and

our allies with a strategic naval base.



Gibraltar proved useful again in 1982 when it supplied the British Task Force on its way to reclaim the Falkland Islands.



Today NATO still uses Gibraltar as a naval base for humanitarian missions.



The white marble plinth has a model of "The Rock" which has been carved from a 3-ton block of Gibraltar limestone. Around the

plinth, it names some of the fallen from Gibraltar in both World Wars.

name: ANGLO-GERMAN GROVE
description:
Circle of stones forming the ANGLO-GERMAN GROVE. The stones are from the Frauenkirche (Church of Our Lady) in Dresden, which

was destroyed by bombing during WW2. The metal plates on the stones carry the names of British and German cities that were

bombed.



WE WILL REMEMBER THEM.

name: Far East Air Force Memorial
description:
Dedicated in 2006, this memorial, comprising 42 hand engraved Lakeland slate tiles, commemorates the history of the Royal Air Force

from 1948 to 1971, when the RAF was engaged in assisting the Malays through confrontation and a period of emergency.



Malaysia gained independence in 1957 and Singapore separated from Malaysia in 1965. As both nations developed their own Armed

Forces, the RAF reduced its commitment and withdrew in 1971.



The Units listed on the memorial were the backbone of operations and provided bases for strategic reinforcement to the Far East,

should it have been required.

name: Yangtze Incident Memorial
description:
The Yangtze Incident memorial commemorates those who lost their lives when the British Royal Navy ship HMS Amethyst was trapped

on the Yangtze River for three months during the Chinese Civil War in 1949.



The circular planting of 46 Chinese euonymus plants commemorates each life lost during the Yangtze Incident in China in 1949.



A plaque alongside the memorial tells the full story of the Yangtze Incident. Inside the circle is a black polished granite monument and

trees planted as a tribute to HMS Amethyst, HMS Black Swan, HMS Consort and HMS London which were the four ships involved in

the incident. The human cost in the four ships was 46 dead and 68 injured.



The tree planted just outside the circle remembers the RAF Sunderland flying boat, named D-DOG ML772, from 88 Squadron. On its

fourth attempt it landed successfully on the Yangtze River alongside HMS Amethyst to deliver medical supplies and a replacement

doctor.

name: Royal Indian Navy and Army Memorial
description:
Between the Yangtze Incident and Far East Air Force memorials, trees from the Indian sub-continent such as Kashmir rowan, cedar

and Bhutan pine have been planted as a tribute to those who served in the Royal Indian Navy (1934 – 1947) and Indian Army. The

memorial lies within a small area surrounded by a hedge.



The British Indian Army (1858 – 1947) was a force recruited locally during the British Colonisation of India and commanded by British

and Indian officers. Substantial numbers of Indian soldiers served in both World Wars. Note also the memorials to the Dogra, Baluch

and Sikh soldiers.



The Royal Indian Navy had its origins in the East India Company’s Marine, later the Bombay Marine. From 1830 to 1858 the Bombay

Marine became the Indian Navy. After the end of Company rule in 1857 the name reverted to Bombay Marine until in 1877 it was

renamed Her Majesties Indian Marine. In 1892 it became the Royal Indian Marine. With the introduction of the Indian Navy (Discipline)

Act 1934, the Royal Indian Navy was formally inaugurated on 2nd October 1934; its ships carried the prefix HMIS. During WW2 the

service greatly expanded, and the Women’s Royal Indian Naval Service was established. Two of its sloops HMIS Sutlej and HMIS Jumna

played a role in the invasion of Sicily. In 1947 the Navy was split between India and Pakistan. From 1950 when India became a republic

the ships have been prefixed INS.

name: The Diamond Grove
description:
The trees in the Diamond Grove have been sponsored by couples from the Second World War generation to celebrate 60 years of

marriage, their Diamond Wedding anniversary.

name: Royal Norwegian Navy
description:
Sponsored by the Royal Norwegian Navy this avenue holds native species of silver birch trees from Norway together with memorial

plaques commemorating Norway’s important involvement in protecting the Merchant Convoys of the Second World War.

name: National Association of Memorial Masons
description:
The Association was formed in 1907 to promote excellence and craftsmanship within the memorial masonry trade.



Through its strict codes of business practice and working practice, the National Association of Memorial Masons (NAMM) demands

the very highest standards of its members.



The NAMM memorial ‘exhibition’ was created to provide a permanent marker to celebrate 100 years of service to both its members

and bereaved families. It is a timeline of memorialisation from Stone Age to the present day.



The garden also aims to encourage children to understand how history, remembrance and heritage are linked to memorialisation.



The ‘exhibition’, designed as a Centenary Garden, was officially opened by HRH The Princess Royal on



20 May 2008.

name: British Nuclear Veterans Memorial
description:
The BNTVA



Formed in 1983, the British Nuclear Test Veterans Association (BNTVA) is a focus for all those who served at the test sites and combines

comradeship with the objective of recognition of the ill effects suffered by some veterans, their families and children born with lung

problems.



The BNTVA believe that over 22,000 British servicemen from the Army, Royal Air Force, Royal Navy, Merchant Navy, and Royal Fleet

Auxiliary participated in the British and American nuclear tests and clean-ups between 1952-1966, along with scientists from the

Atomic Weapons Research Establishment and civilians.



The BNTVA promote research into the effects of clastogenic radiation on the nuclear community, and educate the general public about

the nuclear tests in creative ways.



The BNTVA has about 1,400 members of which one third are widows. Membership is limited to men who served in the nuclear test

areas, their widows and their descendants.



The Nuclear Test Program



Between 1952 and 1958 21 atmospheric tests took place at the locations listed on the memorial. The yield from these tests varied

between 1 and 150 kilotons.



3rd October 1952: the Hurricane Test at Monte Bello



15th & 23rd October 1953: 2 Totem Tests at Emu Field



16 May & 19th June 1956: 2 Mozaic Tests at Monte Bello



September-October 1956: 4 tests in the Buffalo series at Maralinga



May – June 1957: 3 tests in the Grapple series at Malden Island



September –October 1957: 3 tests in the Antler series at Maralinga.



November 1957 – September 1958: 6 tests in the Grapple Series at Christmas Island.



From the 1960s further tests were undertaken at underground facilities in Nevada in cooperation with the USA.



The Medal for British Nuclear Test Veterans



The BNTVA campaigned for many years for a medal to be awarded to recognise the service and sacrifice of the service personnel who

had taken part in the tests.



At a ceremony at the BNTVA Memorial on 21st November 2022 the Prime Minister Rishi Sunak announced that the British Nuclear

Veterans would now be entitled to a medal to mark their service and said:



“I am incredibly proud that we are able to mark the service and dedication of our nuclear test veterans with this new medal. Their

commitment and service has preserved peace for the past 70 years, and it is only right their contribution to our safety, freedom and

way of life is appropriately recognised with this honour.



This medal is an enduring symbol of our country’s gratitude to each and every person who played a part in this effort and their loved

ones who supported them.”



HM Government website states that:



The Nuclear Test Medal will be a commemorative medal that can be worn by recipients.



The medal also recognises the contribution made by veterans and civilians from across Australia, New Zealand, Fiji and Kiribati. All

service personnel and civilians under UK command, including close partners from the Commonwealth and Pacific region, who

participated in, or were present at, the British or American nuclear tests at the Montebello Islands, Christmas Island, Malden Island

and Maralinga & Emu Field, South Australia between 1952 and 1967 will be eligible for the medal. This also includes scientists and

local employees.



It is estimated that around 22,000 veterans will be eligible for the medal.

name: Army Commandos
description:
The British Commandos were first formed by the Army in June 1940, during the Second World War, as a well-armed but non-regimental

raider force, employing unconventional and irregular tactics to assault, disrupt and reconnoitre the enemy in mainland Europe,

Scandinavia, North Africa, The Levant (Eastern Mediterranean) and the Far East.



Initially raids were made by comparatively small numbers, were of short duration and at night but later growing in complexity and

size. The Commandos were formed and operated in secrecy and produced a demoralising effect on German coastal forces while

achieving celebrity status among the British public, comparable with that attached to fighter pilots, and shrouded in myth.



This memorial consists of a reproduction of part of the Association badge – the wreath in copper and the Fairbairn-Sykes fighting knife

in stainless steel.



The impressive piece was created at Anwick Forge in Lincolnshire and dedicated in the presence of HRH Prince Philip, The Duke of

Edinburgh, in July 2007. At the centre of the memorial is a stone with the names of eight commandos awarded the Victoria Cross.

Behind the memorial is a roll of honour listing all 1,205 commandos who died in training or on operations during the Second World

War.



On examination of the Roll of Honour you will note that many were executed: this is because on capture they were executed under

the terms of the infamous Hitler “Kommandobefehl” Commando Order.

name: Shropshire Yeomanry Plinth
description:
The Shropshire Yeomanry date their origin to the raising of the Wellington Troop in 1795 during the French Revolutionary Wars.



The memorial was dedicated on Saturday 13 March 2010 by Colonel Evans, President of the Association. It was built by Bob Sadler

after a ‘buy-a-brick’ scheme organised with Association members to raise funds. The central plaque was produced by stone mason

John Beer.

name: Royal Naval Patrol Service (RNPS) – HMS Europa
description:
The Royal Naval Patrol Service (RNPS) was set up in August 1939. Consisting initially of 200 trawlers, drifters and whalers manned by

some 6,000 fishermen, the ships were equipped with guns mostly from the First World War and with anti-submarine patrol and

minesweeping equipment.



By the end of the Second World War there were 66,000 men, 600 Wrens and 2,000 ships. Minesweeping activities were vital to the

task of keeping open the shipping lanes around the United Kingdom and further afield. The RNPS was involved in the Norway Campaign

where Captain (then Lieutenant) Richard Stannard was awarded the Victoria Cross while in command of HMT Arab being attacked

from the air at Namsos.



Thousands of troops were ferried back to the United Kingdom from Dunkirk by ships of the RNPS. As the war developed, the RNPS

could be found in many naval theatres – from the eastern seaboard of the USA, where refitted trawlers were lost to the U-boats they

were searching for, to the Mediterranean, where HMT Moonstone captured the Italian submarine ‘Galileo Galilei’. In 1944, 235

minesweepers swept the Channel ahead of the invasion fleet.



The bravery of ‘Harry Tate’s Navy’ or ‘Churchill’s pirates’, as they had come to be known, is told by their losses – over 5,000 men

perished, 2,385 with no known grave but the sea, and 475 ships never returned to port.

name: Master Mariners Sundial
description:
The 20 foot (six metre) diameter ‘human’ sundial was designed by Christopher St J H Daniel and placed in situ by Mark Frith in Dunhouse

stone and blue Elterwater slate.



The dial represents an oval outline chart of the world and the shadow of a person standing on the date scale indicates Greenwich

Mean Time (GMT) on the surrounding numbers. So, to get the correct and very accurate time, stand on the appropriate month, add

seven minutes (the difference in time between GMT and the Alrewas time) and in the summer add the extra hour.



It was presented by the Honourable Company of Master Mariners and dedicated in 2001 to commemorate the loss of 2,535 ships of

the Merchant Navy and the 32,000 merchant seamen who gave their lives in the Second World War.

name: The Merchant Navy Convoy Wood
description:
The Merchant Navy Convoy Wood is dedicated to over 46,000 British merchant seafarers and fishermen lost in conflict during the 20th

century, including two World Wars, Falklands, Kuwait, Vietnam, Iran, Iraq and others.



During the Second World War, 31,908 seafarers perished, proportionately more than any of the Armed Services.



Originally the wood had 2,535 trees, each representing a British vessel lost at that time; the number of trees has been significantly

reduced by the need to thin out the wood as the trees matured. Oak was the material originally used for building ships. Additionally,

the wood was planted with bluebells to represent the sea.



The ships cargoes included food, troops, armaments, ammunition and fuel carried to the United Kingdom and every theatre of war.

The seafarers were civilians who faced the enemy and the sea with equal bravery and courage, to keep the supply lines open to Britain

and its allies.

name: Aguila Memorial
description:
Located in the garden The Women’s Royal Naval Service (WRNS) Garden, is the Aguila Memorial, a beautifully carved wren which

commemorates the 21 WRNS and one Naval Nursing Sister who were lost when SS Aguila was torpedoed in 1941.

name: Staffordshire Yeomanry Memorial
description:
The Staffordshire Yeomanry memorial plaque commemorates those who gave their lives in the campaigns of The Boer War, The First

World War (The Great War) and The Second World War.

name: The Royal Navy Engineers Benevolent Society (RNEBS) Memorial
description:
The RNEBS supports the Engineering Artificers and Technicians of the Royal Navy.



The Society was established to promote intellectual and general welfare and the provision of Death or Invaliding Benefits for Members.

Any member of the Engineering Branch serving in the Royal Navy is eligible to join the Society.



The Royal Navy Engineers Benevolent Society (RNEBS) Memorial was originally dedicated on 1 October 2011. It was refurbished and

re-dedicated by The Reverend Paul Bentley, himself an ex-artificer, on 2 October 2016.



The memorial sits on a circular stone terrace and is encircled by a dark inset band displaying the Royal Navy Engineers Benevolent

Society in white lettering. The face of the memorial displays the coloured badge of the RNEBS above an inscription to commemorate

Royal Naval Artificers who gave their lives in service of their country.



Carved into either the side of the memorial are motifs associated with Engineering Artificers and Technicians. The top displays the

carved face of a Green Man, a symbol that is also seen at the bottom of the RNEBS badge together with the motto Tubal Cain – a

character referenced in the book of Genesis which suggests he may have been the very first artificer in brass and iron (KJV).

name: Antelope Garden
description:
The garden was opened on 2 April 2007 by Captain Nick Tobin, the former Commanding Officer of HMS Antelope, which was sunk

during the campaign. It is planted with a deciduous azalea (Viscosa Antelope), which produces a pink fragrant flower in May.



Nearby is a tree, planted by Lady Fieldhouse in memory of her husband, Admiral of the Fleet Lord Fieldhouse of Gosport, in the County

of Hampshire. As Commander in Chief Fleet in 1982, John Fieldhouse was the Commander of the Task Force and given responsibility

for ‘Operation Corporate’, the mission to recover the Falkland Islands.

name: HMS Kenya Memorial
description:
HMS Kenya was a Crown Colony-class cruiser of the Royal Navy. Commissioned in 1940, she saw action during the Second World War

hunting for the German battleship Bismarck in May 1941 and as part of Operation Stonewall, to intercept U-boats. She later took part

in naval operations during the Korean War.



The memorial, by the HMS Kenya Association, is dedicated to the comradeship and memory of the officers and men who served aboard

HMS Kenya in times of war and peace from 1940-1962.



The memorial is a light grey granite plinth displaying the name and an outline drawing of HMS Kenya on the front. On top of the plinth

a polished black granite tablet is inscribed with a dedication and a list of battle honours reflecting her years of active service.

name: HMS Glory
description:
The memorial is dedicated to all who served on the Light Fleet Carrier HMS Glory between 1944 - 1957 and to those who lost their

lives during that service. It was unveiled on 6 October 2007.

name: HMS Gambia
description:
HMS Gambia was a Crown Colony-class light cruiser of the Royal Navy and has been the only ship of the Royal Navy to bear the name.



She saw active service in the East Indies with the British Eastern Fleet, and in September 1942, was involved in the Battle of

Madagascar. Following a refit, she participated in Operation Stonewall to intercept blockade runners off the west coast of France.



From 1943 - 1946 she was in the service of the Royal New Zealand Navy (RNZN) as HMNZS Gambia. She later served with the Far East

Fleet and in 1950 was assigned to the 2nd Cruiser Squadron in the Mediterranean.



In 1955, she became flagship of the 4th Cruiser Squadron on the East Indies Station and from 1960 remained in reserve at Portsmouth.



The memorial is dedicated to the memory of the men of the Royal New Zealand Navy and the Royal Navy who served in HMS Gambia

during her eight commissions 1942 – 1960. It was donated by the HMS Gambia Association 7th May 2005.

name: Athel Shipping Line Memorial
description:
The memorial to the Athel Line – The United Molasses Company is placed in the Athel Line Grove of six English Oaks dedicated in

gratitude to those who served in the Athel Line of Liverpool at Home and Overseas, Ashore and Afloat. Of the 32 ships owned by Athel

Line Ltd and Tankers Ltd, 22 ships were lost.



This memorial honours the 205 souls who perished as a result of enemy action.

name: Training Ship Exmouth
description:
This memorial plaque commemorates all the officers and boys who served on the Training Ship Exmouth (off Grays, Essex 1876-1942)

and later as the London Nautical Training School (1942-1951).



Having completed their training, the boys served in all branches of the Armed Forces, the Merchant Navy and the fishing fleets.



In September 1939, at the outbreak of the Second World War, the boys were evacuated from the ship to Burnham on Crouch in Essex.

In July 1940, they were moved on to Lydney in Gloucestershire, which became their main base for the duration of the War. A third

move took them to them to temporary quarters at Bray Court, near Maidenhead, before finally locating to their last home at

Wolverstone Hall in Suffolk.



The ship was used by the London Fire Brigade as River Fire Station until 1942. It then moved to Scapa Flow where it was commissioned

as HMS Exmouth, a depot ship used for the welfare, recreation and training of the crews for minesweepers and submarines.



Following the Second World War HMS Exmouth returned to the River Thames and finished her days as HMS Worcester at Greenhithe.



At the bottom of the memorial plaque is a dedication to those who gave their lives in Service which is accompanied by the quote “We

Few, We Happy Few, We Band of Brothers” taken from William Shakespeare's play, Henry V.



It was installed by the T.S. Exmouth Association in 2003.

name: Neutral Irish Registered Vessels
description:
The memorial is dedicated to all those who were serving aboard the Neutral Irish Registered Vessels lost as a result of enemy action

during the Second World War - especially the 149 Seamen who lost their lives. The memorial lists the companies ships that were lost

in WW2.

name: Royal Mail Lines
description:
The memorial comprises a commemorative plaque and a line of trees dedicated to the ships of the Royal Mail Lines which were sunk

or destroyed during the Second World War and to all who, as a result of enemy action gave their lives whilst serving aboard them. The

memorial was donated by the Royal Mail Association.

name: Shaw Savill & Albion Co Ltd
description:
Shaw Savill & Albion Co Ltd was a British shipping company that operated ships between Great Britain, Australia and New Zealand.



The memorial, donated by the Shaw Savill Society, is dedicated to all who served in the ships of the Shaw Savill & Albion Co Ltd during

the Second World War and especially to those who made the supreme sacrifice in the ships that were lost as a result of enemy action.

name: Clan Line Steamers, Houston Line, Scottish Shire Line, Bullard, King and Co. and King Line Steamers
description:
This memorial is dedicated to all who served with Clan Line Steamers, Houston Line, Scottish Shire Line, Bullard, King and Co. and King

Line Steamers and to those serving on the vessels lost or destroyed by enemy action.

name: Training Ship Indefatigable
description:
This memorial is in tribute to all boys from Indefatigable Training Ship and School (1864 – 1995) especially remembering those who

lost their lives in service of their country.



The first Indefatigable was an ex Royal Navy wooden frigate which was moored off Rock Ferry, on the Birkenhead side of the Mersey

until 1914. The trainees, typically poor and orphaned boys whose fathers were seamen, were trained for a life at sea and actually lived

on board the ship. The ship’s gun deck was converted to accommodate 200 boys in hammocks.



The second Indefatigable (previously HMS Phaeton) entered service as a Training Ship on 15 January 1914 and continued to train boys

in seafaring until 1941. During the Second World War the heavy bombing of Liverpool made it unsafe to stay in the River Mersey. The

school found temporary shore-based premises near Ruthin in Wales before moving to a mansion at Plas Llanfair at Anglesey in Wales

in December 1944.



The School closed in July 1995, after which the premises was sold to the MOD who agreed to retain the name in the title of the new

establishment; hence The Joint Service Mountain Training Centre Indefatigable.

name: Union Castle Line
description:
The memorial plaque accompanies a line of trees dedicated to the ships of Union Castle Mail Steamship Company lost in the Second

World War and to the sea and shore staff who died as a result of enemy action.

name: Training Ship Vindicatrix
description:
The Vindicatrix was a British ship built in 1893. She sailed under a red ensign for 17 years until being sold to a German firm in 1910.

After the First World War she was repossessed and given to the Shipping Federation. Having been located in London Docks for some

time she was relocated to Sharpness Old Dock in Gloucestershire in 1939 where she became a training ship for boys entering the

Merchant Navy.



The Training Ship Vindicatrix memorial is made of grey flecked granite and displays the badge of the Association. It is dedicated to the

estimated 70,000 boys who received their basic training for the Merchant Navy between 1939 – 1966 many of whom gave their lives

in the Second World War.

name: TS Mercury, HMS Worcester, Conway, SATS General Botha, Nautical College Pangbourne Memorial
description:
This memorial, which was re-dedicated on the 3 September 2016, is to the five following Training Ships and Nautical Colleges:



The Training Ship HMS Conway

The Nautical College Pangbourne

The Training Ship Mercury

The South African Training Ship General Botha

The Incorporated Thames Nautical Training College, H.M.S. Worcester



Made of black polished granite it displays the badges of each Training Ship and Nautical College with their names inscribed beneath.

It includes the following inscription at the bottom:



Dedicated to the memory of the former cadets and staff of these Training Ships and Nautical Colleges who gave their lives in service

of their country in times of war.

name: HMS Bruce
description:
The grey polished memorial stone is dedicated to the Officers, Instructors, Men and Boy Seamen that served in HMS Bruce between

1947–1950. It contains the inscription “May they find safe haven”.



The memorial was presented by the HMS Bruce Association.

name: Royal Naval Association – Uttoxeter
description:
The memorial plaque is dedicated to all members of The Royal Navy, The Royal Marines and The Merchant Navy who have served in

H.M. Forces from the Uttoxeter and Districts of Staffordshire.

name: HMS Neptune and HMS Kandahar
description:
In December 1941, the destroyer HMS Kandahar and the cruiser HMS Neptune were sunk by mines in the Mediterranean with a loss

of over 800 lives.



The tragedy ranks among the heaviest crew losses experienced in any naval theatre of the Second World War and was the second

most substantial loss of life suffered by the Royal Navy in the whole of the Mediterranean campaign.



At 0300 on the 19th December the cruisers HMS Neptune (Captain Rory Chambers O’Connor), HMS Aurora (Captain William G Agnew

CB) and HMS Penelope (Captain Angus Nichol DSO) and the destroyers Kandahar (Commander William Geoffrey Arthur Robson DSO,

DSC), Lance (Lt-Commander R W F Northcott), Havok (Lt-Commander G R G Watkins DSC) and Lively (Lt-Commander W F E Hussey

DSC) , the combined Forces B and K, steamed into a newly laid Italian minefield and HMS Neptune hit two mines and then while

attempting to go astern hit a third. HMS Aurora and HMS Penelope also struck mines. HMS Kandahar attempted to pass a tow to the

Neptune and struck a mine and had her stern blown off. Captain O’Conner warned all ships to stand clear. HMS Neptune sank later

with the loss of all but one of her 765 crew; 150 were from New Zealand.



On 20th December HMS Jaguar (Lt-Commander Lionel Rupert Tyrwhitt DSC) saved all but 91 of the crew of HMS Kandahar and then

torpedoed the hulk. On 24th December, Able Seaman John Norman Walton, the only survivor from HMS Neptune was picked up by

an Italian ship after spending 5 ½ days on a Carley raft.



The pyramid shaped memorial is positioned so that it aligns with the position off the coast of Libya where the wreck of HMS Neptune

lies.



Concealed within the stone is a roll of honour of the 837 men who died and a painting of the sky as it was on the night of the sinking.

name: H.M. Ships Bulwark, Albion, Centaur
description:
The memorial is in proud memory of the ships companies FAA Squadrons, Royal Marines and Embarked Forces H.M. Ships Bulwark,

Albion, Centaur 1953-1981.

name: HMS Hood Memorial
description:
HMS Hood, named after the 18th Century Admiral Samuel Hood, was commissioned in 1920 and was the last battlecruiser built for

the Royal Navy. For many years she was considered the largest and most powerful warship in the world - her prestige being reflected

in the nickname "The Mighty Hood".



HMS Hood was sunk in action with the German Battleship Bismarck in the Denmark Strait off Greenland on 24 May 1941.



The memorial, which was dedicated on 25 October 2008, is of grey polish granite and displays HMS Hood’s crest, a Cornish Chough

holding a gold anchor, which is based on elements of Lord Samuel Hood’s coat of arms. It is dedicated to the memory of the 1415

officers and ratings who died including 24 Commonwealth, 4 Polish Midshipmen and 5 Free French Sailors. Only 3 of the ship’s company

survived.



In 2015, the ship’s bell was recovered from the wreck of HMS Hood and conserved. It had been the expressed wish of Ted Briggs, one

of the only three survivors, for this to be recovered as a memorial to his shipmates.

name: HMS Caledonia Memorial
description:
HMS Caledonia was used for Artificer Apprentice training from 1937 to 1985. A stone memorial tablet containing the Caledonia insignia

at the top includes the inscription: This tree is dedicated to all Caledonia trained Artificer Apprentices.

name: The Fisgard Association Memorial
description:
The Fisgard Association Memorial and nearby tree are dedicated to the former Royal Navy artificer apprentices, most of whom served

all or part of their training at the Royal Navy Artificer Training Establishment, HMS Fisgard or as part of the Fisgard Squadron in HMS

Raleigh.



The original HMS Fisgard was a 46 gun Leda class frigate which was used as a training establishment between 1848 and 1872. A second

Fisgard was established in hulks at Portsmouth in 1904 and went through several incarnations. The establishment was moved to

Chatham in 1930 and in July 1932 moved ashore. In October 1940 the establishment moved to Torpoint in Cornwall, near Devonport

Naval Base. The base was closed on 21st October 1983 when its activities were absorbed into HMS Raleigh.

name: HMS Formidable
description:
HMS Formidable was an Illustrious-class aircraft carrier (28,661 tons full load) that saw extensive service during the Second World

War. She was commissioned on 24 November 1940.



HMS Formidable took part in the Battle of Cape Matapan on 27 March 1941. On 26 May 1941, she received serious damage while

transporting aircraft to Malta, being hit by two 1000-kilogram bombs that put her out of action for six months. After repairs in the

United States, she re-equipped with Vought Corsair and Martlet fighters.



In 1942, she travelled across the Pacific and served briefly in the Indian Ocean, returning to the Mediterranean in October. HMS

Formidable then provided air support for the North African campaign and Italian campaign (1943), including the Allied invasion of

Sicily, before taking part in an Arctic convoy. On 17 November aircraft from HMS Formidable attacked U-Boat U-331 (the U-Boat that

sank HMS Barham) and sank her.



On 17 July 1944, Swordfish aircraft from HMS Formidable were involved in an attack on the Tirpitz in Norway and took part in further

attacks on Tirpitz in August.



During 1945 she saw service against Japanese forces with British Pacific Fleet and survived several kamikaze attacks while supporting

the landings on Okinawa. On 4 May a Japanese kamikaze plane crashed into the flight deck, making a massive dent about 10 feet long,

two feet wide and two feet deep in the armoured flight deck. A large steel splinter ruptured a steam line, and came to rest in a fuel

tank, starting a major fire in the aircraft park. Eight crew members were killed and forty-seven were wounded: the 3" armoured steel

flight deck of HMS Formidable prevented further damage by Kamikaze attacks. By 5pm the fires were brought under control, the crater

in the deck was repaired and Corsairs were again able to land on Formidable. A further Kamikaze hit HMS Formidable's flight deck on

9 May, but the level of damage was nowhere near as serious.



The accumulation of damage through the war took its toll on the ship. The bomb damage received in the Mediterranean had left her

with damage that was beyond economical repair. She was placed in reserve in 1947 and was sold for scrap in 1953.



The blue plaque on the face of the stone memorial contains details of HMS Formidable’s Battle Honours and a reference to Lieutenant

Robert Hampton Gray VC, DSC, RCNVR of 1841 Squadron - a Canadian naval officer, pilot, and posthumous recipient of the last Victoria

Cross (VC) of the Second World War. Robert Hampton Gray is thought to be one of the last Canadians to die during the Second World

War.



Located behind the main memorial to HMS Formidable is an oak tree which was planted by the HMS Formidable Association on 22

September 2001 and commemorates in tribute “all who served in and flew from this great ship”.

name: HMS Royal Arthur
description:
This polished grey stone obelisk shaped memorial is dedicated to all the men and women who entered service in the Royal Navy at

HMS Royal Arthur at the former “Butlins Holiday Camp” Skegness between 1939 - 1945 and to all the officers and ratings who passed

through HMS Royal Arthur, Corsham, Wiltshire in the years 1945 – 1993.



A gold naval anchor is inscribed in the memorial’s pyramidal top below which is the badge of HMS Royal Arthur displayed in blue and

gold.



The inscription below includes a dedication remembering all HMS Royal Arthur shipmates who have ‘crossed the bar’ (a naval term

used when comrades have passed away which is taken from Tennyson’s poem Crossing the Bar). The memorial’s installation was made

possible by the generous legacy of shipmate Nellie Wilson.

name: HMS Dunedin
description:
HMS Dunedin, a Danae-class light cruiser, was launched in 1918. During the 1920s and 1930s she served as part of the New Zealand

Division of the Royal Navy, sailing around the Pacific. Returning to England in 1937, she served at Portsmouth as a Boys Sea Training

Ship until August 1939 when she was allocated to the 12th Cruiser Squadron based on Kirkwall for service on the Northern Patrol.



Dunedin spent time hunting for German battleships and during 1940 was operating in the Caribbean Sea intercepting German

merchant ships. On 15 June 1941, the German tanker Lothringen was captured by HMS Dunedin, denying German U-Boats of vital oil

supplies. Important, classified Engima material was also discovered aboard the tanker during its capture.



On 24 November 1941, whilst steaming in the Central Atlantic Ocean, east of the St. Paul's Rocks, HMS Dunedin was torpedoed and

sunk by the German submarine U-124. Of her 486 crew, only four officers and 63 men survived.



The memorial to HMS Dunedin was unveiled on 26th July 2003 by the last four known survivors.

name: The L.S.T. and Landing Craft Association Memorial
description:
Landing Ship, Tank (LST), or tank landing ships were built during the Second World War to support amphibious operations by carrying

tanks, vehicles and cargo and landing troops directly on to shore. As their unique design meant that they could provide amphibious

assaults to any beach they were used extensively around the world in both the European and Pacific theatres.



The L.S.T. and Landing Craft Association Memorial is dedicated to all those who served in or in support of Landing Ships and Landing

Craft especially those who gave their lives in service of their country.

name: Royal Naval Coastal Forces Memorial
description:
The Coastal Forces Veterans’ Association was formed in 1974 by crews who served in the Royal Navy from 1939 to 1957 in the ‘Little

Ships’.

name: HMS Cavalier Memorial
description:
This memorial is dedicated to all those who served on the HMS Cavalier and was donated and erected by the HMS Cavalier Association.

The insignia badge of the HMS Cavalier is displayed at the centre of the memorial. HMS Cavalier joined the 8th Destroyer Flotilla Home

Fleet and quickly saw action. In February 1945 she took part in three operations off Norway. “Selenium”, a strike against enemy

shipping, “Shred” to provide fighter cover for a minesweeping flotilla and “Groundsheet” an aircraft mine laying strike.



Cavalier was one of three destroyers sent from Scapa to reinforce the escort of Artic Convoy RA64 which had left the Kola Inlet on 17th

February. After being attacked by U-boats and enemy aircraft on 23 February the convoy was scattered in a hurricane combining force

12 winds with icing. Cavalier went to round up the convoy with the other escorts and on 1 March 31 of the 34 merchant ships arrived

safely in Clyde.



This mission earned HMS Cavalier a well deserved “Battle Honour” Arctic 44.



HMS Cavalier is now preserved at the National Destroyer Memorial in The Historic Dockyard, Chatham.

name: HMS Cossack Memorial
description:
There have been six ships bearing the name HMS Cossack. The fifth ship, HMS Cossack – LO3, was arguably the most famous of the 16

Tribal Class destroyers that served with the Royal Navy during the Second World War.



As a large, heavily armed destroyer, HMS Cossack saw much action and was involved in the pursuit and sinking of the German

battleship Bismarck in May 1941. On 23 October 1941, while escorting a convoy from Gibraltar to the United Kingdom, HMS Cossack

was struck by a torpedo causing immense damage: 159 of her 219 crew were killed. She eventually sank on 27 October and survivors

were picked up by HMS Legion, HMS Carnation and the Free French Ship Commandant.



The memorial bench is dedicated to Shipmate George Toomey, the founder of the HMS Cossack Association, and to the memory of all

those who served in the Cossacks.



To the right of the memorial bench is the Cossack oak tree planted by the HMS Cossack Association in memory of the 159 officers and

men who died in HMS Cossack 23 October 1941. The plaque commemorates all those who served in HM Ships Cossack 1938-1941 and

1945-1960.

name: Baker Troop – 45 Commando
description:
This memorial honours all Royal Marines who were members of the ‘Baker’ Troop – 45 Commando – (1955 - 1957) serving with

distinction in the Cyprus EOKA Emergency and the Invasion of Suez.



The memorial was presented with the aid of a legacy from Captain F Collingwood BEM RM.

name: Kenya Police Memorial
description:
Although the bench, tree and plaques were dedicated on 20th October 2004, the memorial itself was dedicated on 7th June 2015 to

remember all ranks who served in the Kenya Police and Kenya Police Reserve up to the year 1963, when Kenya was granted

independence from Britain.



The memorial consists of a 6 feet tall obelisk of black Indian marble whichhighlights significant events in the history of the force. The

photographs etched on the memorial depict various aspects of their work including air patrols as shown by the aircraft flying past

Mount Kenya.



On 10th August 2022 a Hexahedral Stone plinth (also of black Indian marble)was placed in front of the memorial: on it is the Kenya

Police insignia (bronze) which was originally installed above the force headquarters in Nairobi. It was returned tothe UK after Kenya

gained independence.



A History



The Kenya Police has its roots in the early British East African Police. This remarkably small force grew slowly with the protectorate,

with only the first organised policemen being established in Mombasa in 1896. The force consisted of just a few British and imperial

officers, European Police Constables, Indian sepoys and African askaris. Many of these came from military backgrounds and indeed a

number of Regular Army drill instructors were also seconded from Britain to assist with the training of new recruits.



In 1920, with the establishment of Kenya Colony, the Kenya Police was then formed. The force remained very small and had limited

resources, then required to deal primarily with the settler increase. All policemen had to be a jack of all trades in the fledgling colony

and their duties were well beyond what would be seen as normal policing today. A significant reduction in police resources during the

Great Depression years and the resulting austerity, stretched the force even further. Secret societies often sprang up which needed to

be dealt with by the law. It was therefore frequently deployed on various internal operations, often in support of the military. During

both of the world wars, the Kenya Police took part in routine military and counter insurgency operations, mostly within the borders of

the colony. Throughout this period, there was constant fighting in the North Frontier Province, with criminal armed incursions across

the borders by the Shifta banditry amongst others. The force remained very much paramilitary in nature, due of course to the policing

requirements of the time.



The post war period then saw a significant increase in crime, leading up to the Mau Mau Emergency declared in 1952. This led to a

rapid expansion, with more police deploying into the native reserves in that year, where policing had previously been left up to the

administration in the main. The Kenya Police Reserve also played a significant part in the campaign and by December 1953, there were

over 8,000 serving reservist officers. These were both full time and part time policemen from all of the races in Kenya. By that time,

the regular police consisted of over 1,000 Europeans, 185 Asians and around 10,000 Africans. Due to the significant threat at that time,

nearly 300 contract officers were also recruited mainly from the United Kingdom. The Kenya Police then consisted of many vital

capabilities. These included the Police Airwing, the General Service Unit, Mounted Squadron, Dog Section, Tracker Combat Teams,

along with the routine traffic department, police stations and posts across the whole of the colony. Vital support was provided by the

Signals, Prosecutions and Transport Branches. The Railway Police and a small maritime force in Mombasa, also had to police the lines

of communication. The period saw in particular, the establishment of a very much expanded Special Branch and CID. The police worked

closely with the military in most operations throughout what was a very difficult time for all in Kenya. Of note, the use of Pseudo gangs

involved both policemen and soldiers, disguised as terrorists, operating deep in the forests. This was certainly a significant tactical

success which helped locate and defeat the remaining Mau Mau gangs.



The Emergency formally ended in 1960, but the Mau Mau threat had effectively been dealt with by 1956. However, there remained

various internal problems in Kenya up until Independence in 1963, which had to be dealt with by the police. The Shifta campaign on

the Somali border in particular, became politicised and very much a significant issue for both the police and the military, well into the

1960s. This exacerbated the already problematic Northern Frontier and its often near lawless state. Many European officers

nevertheless, stayed on during the period providing some stability to the force during this difficult time - which of course was also one

of careful transition to the new Kenya Police.

name: The Christmas Truce Memorial
description:
The Christmas Truce took place in December 1914

This memorial was sponsored by the Football Association

There was a national competition for schools to design a memorial that reflected the events of the Christmas Truce

35 schools were shortlisted and those designs were displayed at the National Memorial Arboretum

The winning design was created by a school boy from Newcastle upon Tyne

The competition was judged by Theo Walcott and Price William

It must be stressed that it is highly unlikely that there was ever a formal game of football in No Man’s Land during the



Christmas Truce. An informal kick-a-about is much more likely to have been the case

No primary documents have been found to confirm an actual formal football match despite all that we might read in the



press

name: Millennium Chapel
description:
The Chapel welcomes people of all faiths and none and aims to provide a quiet space for reflection, where everyone will feel

comfortable. It is the only place in the country where the Act of Remembrance is observed every day. The act, consisting of the

Last Post, the Two Minute Silence and the Reveille, starts at 10.50am. All are invited to participate and reflect on the sacrifice of

those who have given their lives in the service of their country. The Chapel is constructed largely from wood, reflecting the

environment surrounding it, and the National Memorial Arboretum’s commitment to sustainability. The roof is supported by 12

columns of Douglas fir, each carved with one of the 12 disciples, by ex-Royal Marine and Shropshire woodcarver Jim Heath.



At the entrance to the Chapel, the Millennium Prayer written by 13 year-old competition winner Anna Crompton is carved into

cherry wood. The chapel’s altar, along with the lectern and pulpit, was made locally by young oŽenders at Swinfen Hall Prison.

The altar cloth, showing the Tree of Life, was commissioned by the Women’s Section of the Royal British Legion, intended to

remind us of the passing seasons. The altar candlesticks were created by Robert Pritchard-Gordon, a Birmingham silversmith,

who collaborated with Arthur Price, the internationally reputed tableware company and Robert Carr, a Lichfield jeweller. These

represent the twelve knives used by apostles. They are bound by barbed wire as a reminder that people still starve as a result of

war and imprisonment



On the wall behind the altar are three crosses. The central one is the ‘Sword of Sacrifice’, found at Commonwealth War Graves

Commission cemeteries. Either side of this are crosses made from the wood of trees actually grown in the Arboretum. The

uprights are made of ash taken from trees in the Ulster Ash Grove and the crosspieces are made of hazel taken from trees in the

Royal Army Medical Corps Wood.

name: Cadet Forces’ Memorial
description:
The circular seat, sponsored by the Army Cadet Force, a national voluntary youth organisation for young people aged 12–18,

honours former members of the Cadet Forces who went on to join the Armed Forces and subsequently lost their lives.

name: Military Music Society
description:
At the back of the Chapel, you’ll also find the International Military Music Society that commemorates the incalculable number

of bandsmen, drummers, pipers and buglers who lost their lives in the service of their country, and celebrates the courage and

fortitude of those military musicians whose actions were recognised with awards for bravery.

name: British Limbless Ex-Service Men’s Association (BLESMA) Orchard
description:
BLESMA - The Limbless Veteran’s Orchard. The 70 fruit trees here, including varieties of bramley seedling ‘Malus domestica’,

Fiesta, James Grieve, Golden Delicious, Cox’s Orange Pippin, Katie and Egremont Russet, are dedicated to those serving and exservice personnel who are assisted by Blesma, The Limbless Veteran’s charity.

name: Auxiliary Territorial Service Statue
description:
The statue of an Auxiliary Territorial Service (ATS) woman wearing basic khaki uniform was sponsored by the Auxiliary Territorial

Service as a tribute to its members who played an important role in the Second World War from 1939 to 1945. Initially, made up

of volunteers who undertook six weeks of basic training, the ATS was formed in September 1938. By December 1939 there were

23,900 women aged between 19 and 23 years old in the service, peaking in 1943 at 212,500. Her Late Majesty Queen Elizabeth II

joined the ATS following her eighteenth birthday, becoming the first female member of the Royal family to be an active-duty

member of the British Armed Forces. Training as a mechanic, she started as a second subaltern, and was later promoted to

junior commander, the equivalent of captain. On 1 February 1949, the ATS was disbanded and the Women’s Royal Army Corps

(WRAC) was formed. During hostilities, 335 members of the ATS were killed, 94 reported missing, 302 wounded and 20 became

prisoners of war.

name: Royal Hong Kong Police Memorial
description:
The Hong Kong Police Force was founded in 1844, when Hong Kong Island was ceded to Britain by China following the First

Opium War. The first Police O›cers were European and Indian ex-soldiers, together with some locally recruited Chinese. In 1845,

Charles May, a former London Metropolitan Police Superintendent, took command of the 171-strong Force. Hong Kong grew in

importance as a trading port and, following the Japanese Occupation during the Second World War, as a manufacturing, financial

and tourist centre. The Force was honoured with the title ‘Royal’ following very serious disturbances arising from the Cultural

Revolution which took place in China in 1967. By 1997, when sovereignty of Hong Kong returned to China, the population of

Hong Kong was some 6.5 million people, and the Force consisted of 28,000 regular police o›cers, with 5,700 auxiliaries and 6,000

civilian staff.

name: Twin Towers Memorial
description:
Pays tribute to those who perished as a result of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Centre, New York on 11 September

2001, including 64 British Citizens. The memorial is sponsored by the communities of Herefordshire and Worcestershire and the

Hereford and Worcester Fire Authority in recognition of the courage and dedication of New York’s emergency personnel.

name: Gulf War 1990-1991 Memorial
description:
This memorial was dedicated in honour of the 47 British personnel who died in the liberation of Kuwait and all those who fought

in the Gulf War. The memorial comprises three stainless steel supporting pillars representing each of Britain’s three Armed

Forces. The centre stone of the memorial carries the image of the reverse of the Gulf Medal, engraved in black granite. Each of

the 47 pavers on the memorial, which are laid out in concentric circles, carries the name of one of the fallen. Beneath the centre

stone, there are 48 poppies from the Festival of Remembrance at the Royal Albert Hall in 2015, one poppy for each of the ‘47

fallen’ and one solitary poppy for all of the veterans who have passed away since the Gulf War. The memorial, which is aligned

on a compass bearing of 302 degrees from true north - the compass bearing from Kuwait to the Arboretum, carries an inscription

in English, Latin and Arabic. The inscription reads: ‘In memory of the 47 fallen comrades, and to all those who fought in

Operation Granby (1990-91) - The Liberation of Kuwait, those who subsequently passed away and also those that continued to

fight their own battles, long after the guns fell silent. Lest We Forget

name: Royal Fleet Auxiliary (RFA) Memorial
description:
Dedicated in the presence of the RFA Commodore-in-Chief, His Royal Highness The Earl of Wessex. The Royal Fleet Auxiliary is a

civilian-manned fleet of vessels owned by the United Kingdom, and provides support for various functions of the Royal Navy,

such as resupplying fuel and ammunition to Navy ships while at sea. The triangular plinth of polished granite represents the bow

of an RFA ship, and is surrounded by diŽerent coloured stones forming the shape of the ship’s bow wave.

name: Poppy Memorial; ‘RBL Never Forget Tribute Garden’
description:
This is a unique and personal memorial, commemorating the loved ones of sponsoring supporters of the Royal British Legion. A

poppy bearing each name is planted in the bed, in the month in which their relatives and friends wish to remember them. The

poppy as a symbol of Remembrance: John McCrae was a Canadian doctor who served in France in the First World War. His

experience of war inspired him to write the poem ‘In Flanders Fields’. His image of red poppies springing from the war-torn

ground symbolised hope of new life, and inspired American teacher Moina Michael to hand out cloth poppies in Remembrance.

After the American Legion took up her idea it spread rapidly to other countries. The British Legion ordered nine million poppies

for 11 November 1921, and raised £106,000 for veterans helping them to find employment and housing after the First World

War. The Poppy is perhaps the most recognisable symbol of Remembrance today.

name: Blown Away
description:
This sculpture which is on permanent loan to the Arboretum from Peter and Carole Wilcock. ‘A study of a moment in time. The

young man, his life fleeting as a gust, sees the whole world in a glance.’ The artist’s inspiration for the piece was the Four

Quartets, a work by the writer and poet T.S.Eliot: “Time present and time past Are both perhaps present in time future” The

sculpture is made from bronze laurel leaves and sits on a plinth fabricated in mild steel. The plinth’s shape suggests hastily

despatched munitions or a ship’s funnel. It has intentionally been left to rust, with stripes of bronze reflecting its adopted

strength.

name: The 41 Club memorial garden
description:
Celebrates the community service achievements by former Round Table members (young men aged between 18 and 45) since

the association was founded. 41 trees, surround a central obelisk.

name: Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI)
description:
This memorial has been designed to reflect the work of the Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI) crews and the relationship

between crew members, a rescued person and all their families whose lives become interwoven during a rescue. It is intended

not only as a celebration and recognition of the work of the RNLI but also to honour those crew members and people who have

lost their lives saving others. The coastal scene creates a beautiful space in which to contemplate and reflect on the work of the

RNLI. It embodies the journey of one member of a volunteer crew. As you enter you will see the statue of a lifeboat crew

member. Take the path going to the left, and depending on the season, the colours of the plants are muted like the sea on a

calm day. The stone monoliths represent more crew members heading out on a rescue mission. As you pass by the groynes and

beach, you overlook the water. Throughout the year, the colours change to shades of red to embody danger and stormy waters.

The stone cairn represents those rescued encircled by the crew and the last stone monolith on your journey symbolises the

crews and survivors returning to safety and their families. In the north corner 29 trees reflect the pattern of the tides, which are

so significant in the lives of lifeboat crews; there are 29 days (and 12 hours) between full moons.

name: Cardiac Risk in the Young, Dawn, Dusk
description:
Just after the play area, still amongst the trees are Dusk and Dawn, commissioned by Pam Holmes in memory of her son Nick

who died in March 2015 and in appreciation of the support provided by Cardiac Risk in the Young (CRY). An owl represents dusk

and dawn is represented by a crowing cockerel.

name: Posted - Service Children’s Education Memorial
description:
‘Posted’ recognises the work of Service Children’s Education (SCE), an Agency of the Ministry of Defence (MOD), dedicated to the

education of the children of His Majesty’s Armed Forces, MOD Personnel and sponsored organisations stationed overseas.

Military postings require most families to move every two years or so, either within the UK or to other overseas locations. It can

sometimes be hard for children to regularly leave friends behind and start afresh. The memorial features a traditional red British

post box on a black post with sculpted birds above representing the dispersal and regrouping experience of posted families.

name: Royal British Legion (RBL) Poppy Field
description:
In June, the wildflower display with the distinguishable poppy is simply stunning. The 200-metre meadow is lined with 44 tall

English oaks ‘Quercus robur’, intended, as they grow to provide a dramatic tree-lined vista.

name: Leyton Orient Somme
description:
The O’s Somme Memorial honours the service and sacrifice of the 41 players, staŽ, club o›cials and supporters of Clapton Orient

Football Club (now Leyton Orient FC) in the First World War. It is the first Memorial to commemorate a football club at the

into the British Army. They joined the 17th Battalion Middlesex Regiment, which was later to become known as ‘The Footballers’

Battalion’. The football and boots are reminiscent of that time.

name: Royal and Sun Alliance Insurance Limited Memorials
description:
The memorials now displayed here underneath the railway bridge, were once located within the local o›ces of Royal and Sun

Alliance companies across the UK. The memorials are made from diŽerent materials including bronze and marble. Together they

commemorate over 915 employees from across the Royal Sun Alliance Insurance Group who served their country, and in many

cases gave their lives during both World Wars. The memorials were originally unveiled by former companies that over the years

all became part of the Group. Together, they create a lasting memorial and place of Remembrance, ensuring that the service

given and sacrifices made by former colleagues throughout both World Wars will never be forgotten.

name: No. 47 Squadron RAF Memorial
description:
No. 47 Squadron Royal Flying Corps was formed on 1 March 1916 at Beverley as a home defence unit to protect Hull and East

Yorkshire against attacks from German Zeppelins. The Squadron saw active service in East Africa, the Eastern Mediterranean and

India during the Second World War and later supported the Berlin Airlift. In more recent times the Squadron supported United

Nations (UN) and NATO operations in the Balkans by delivering aid to besieged cities and also assisted coalition forces in

operations in Iraq and Afghanistan. Also in this area… Take a look inside our original Type 24 Pillbox, where soldiers during the

Second World War were expected to use the reinforced concrete walls for protection, whilst fighting an invading enemy. There is

an information panel just outside if you’d like to find out more. The memorial’s five figures represent two airmen from the First

World War and Second World War and the other three figures represent a modern air crew. An introductory plinth displays the

Squadron badge depicting a demoiselle crane’s head in front of a fountain. The memorial also includes nine corten steel plaques

that represent the Squadron’s battle honours.

name: Type 24 Pillbox
description:
It’s an original, where soldiers during the Second World War were expected to use the reinforced concrete walls for protection,

whilst fighting an invading enemy. There is an information panel just outside if you’d like to find out more.

name: NAAFI; Navy, Army and Air Force Institutes
description:
Sevitor Servientium Serving those who Serve The NAAFI Memorial honours the courage and sacrifice of the 550 members of the

Navy, Army and Air Force Institutes who gave their lives whilst providing service to the Armed Forces during the Second World

War. The Navy, Army and Air Force Institutes, aŽectionately known as ‘NAAFI’, was created by the British Government by

combining the Expeditionary Force Canteens and the Navy and Army Canteen Board on the 9 December 1920. Over the years,

NAAFI has proudly supported the British Armed Forces worldwide wherever and whenever. This includes the conflicts in the

Falklands, NATO obligations during the Bosnian conflict, the two Gulf Wars and Afghanistan amongst many others. Today a

smaller, but still dynamic and agile NAAFI operates a broad range of services in Germany, Gibraltar, Brunei, the South Atlantic

Islands and in the UK onboard HM Ships and supporting exercises. NAAFI’s ethos and core purpose has not changed, it remains

committed to serving the services by providing a taste of home to the British Armed Forces and their families and is ready to

operate whenever called to do so.

name: Salvation Army Memorial
description:
General William Booth founded The Christian Mission in 1865. The organisation was renamed The Salvation Army in 1878.

Members came from all walks of life and were to be found in both the Royal Navy and the regular Army. The Salvation Army

oŽers practical support, unconditional friendship and practical help to people of all ages, backgrounds and needs. The two

outstretched hands on the glass panel symbolise hope and help.

name: The Women’s Institute Memorial Seat
description:
WI Wall was designed and built by one of Derbyshire’s only registered female dry stonewaller’s, Sally Hodgson. Established in

1915, the Women’s Institute set out to give women a voice and to be a force for good in the community. Today, it is the largest

women’s organisation in the United Kingdom and prides itself on being a trusted place for all women of all generations, to share

experiences and learn from each other.

name: Tree of Cherished Memories
description:
The Tree of Cherished Memories is a magnificent four metre sculpture by artist Jill Berelowitz. Nestled amongst a landscaped

wooded glade, this magical tree creates an alternative Remembrance space for all. Cast in bronze, the Tree of Cherished

Memories is steeped in symbolism. Immortalising one of the Arboretum’s very own hawthorn ‘Crataegus’ trees, the design

represents a peaceful connection between humanity and nature. Its interwoven trunk and visible roots emanate strength and

determination, and the globe-like crown of the tree symbolises connection and togetherness. On the ground, a growing seedpod

represents youth and new life. Glinting bronze leaves and figurative dancers are entwined within the branches and will continue

to grow as personal dedications are added. Beautiful leaf and figurative elements of the sculpture can be individually

commissioned as a dedication to a loved one, or to mark special occasions for celebration and Remembrance. If you wish to

locate a dedication that has been made on the tree, please speak to a member of our team.

name: Royal British Legion Remembrance Glade
description:
The Glade is designed to provoke reflection and contemplation through symbolic forms, features and plants. It provides an ideal

spot for those who just want to reflect on what Remembrance means to them. Denoting strength, the curved oak gateways

provide an entrance into an inner sanctum. The glade is a perfect circle of white stemmed himalayan birches ‘Betula

Jacquemontii’, creating a sense of harmony and unity. The mirror reflects truth and brings light.

name: Prison Officers Association Memorial
description:
Dedicated to all those who continue to serve the Crown, have served in the Armed Forces and all those lost in service, who

joined the trade union via their work within our secure services including; public sector and private sector prisons, immigration

centres, youth custody services, escort services and secure psychiatric institutions. The memorial recognises the dangers staŽ

who work in these environments place themselves in, whilst serving to protect the public.

name: Scouting Memorial
description:
Remembers the service given by Scouts across communities and throughout the Armed Forces and recognises the diŽerence

Scouting has made. The design features stone seating circling a roaring campfire that moves and flickers. Three young Scouts,

carved from solid stone, rest around the fire as if tired from a long and active day, while their adult leader keeps watch over

them. A lone neckerchief next to them represents all the missing Scouts. The scene is one of peace and warmth that captures the

essence of Scouting’s spirit of global friendship and adventure.

name: Spiritualists’ National Union Memorial
description:
This memorial was dedicated in memory of Spiritualists who have served and continue to serve in the British and

Commonwealth Armed Forces, and all Spiritualists who have served their country in times of conflict. The design comprises a

circular bench made from polished beige granite topped with curved coping slabs to form a seat. Within the bench are seven

curved pieces of Balmoral red granite, each one bearing symbolic words. The internal floor of the circle is paved with the same

types of granite, depicting a seven-pointed star. Standing in the centre of the circle is an obelisk with a pyramid top.

name: Quaker Services Memorial
description:
During both World Wars, members of the Religious Society of Friends (Quakers) were active in relief work, which was recognised

by the award of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1947. The Friends Ambulance Unit was an independent body led by Quakers and open

to people of all denominations, giving conscientious objectors to military service an opportunity to serve in theatres of war.

Bronze stars set in the paving mark the 17 lives lost. The Friends Relief Service was the o›cial arm of the Society for the relief of

civilian distress. Twelve hundred people, nearly half of them women, from all denominations, served as members. The circular

design of the memorial, which symbolises reconciliation between opponents, invites visitors to rest and contemplate; it also

represents the unity and equality which Friends bring to their worship and lives. Quakers recognise the reality of conflict and

have practical experience of the power of love in its resolution.

name: The Garden of the Innocents
description:
A memorial to all children who are victims of war and terrorism. The white planting symbolises innocence and the raised beds

are in the shape of jigsaw pieces that do not fit together, symbolising the confusion and bewilderment children suŽer through

war and violence. In the centre of the garden is an elder tree ‘Sambucus nigra’, planted in memory of Anne Frank. Every year on

Anne’s birthday, the blossoms of the tree are cut so the tree never bears fruit, just as Anne herself was prevented from reaching

maturity.

name: War Widows’ Rose Garden
description:
A tribute to the Nation’s war widows who often endure great hardship, as well as emotional stress, through the loss of their

husbands. The garden is designed to take visitors along the journey of bereavement through the colours of the roses – it begins

with the reds of anger, into the purples of despair, then passes through the gentler colours of quiet acceptance and finally into

the yellows of happy memories.

name: Basra Memorial Wall
description:
The Basra Memorial Wall is a truly poignant monument to the 178 United Kingdom Armed Forces Service personnel and one

Ministry of Defence (MOD) civilian who lost their lives on combat operations in Iraq. It also lists members of Coalition Forces

who were killed whilst under United Kingdom command during the six years of conflict. The original memorial was built in Basra

in 2006 and stood outside the front of the Headquarters of the Multi-National Division (South East). It was originally built by

members of the Royal Engineers on their own initiative and in their own time, often in darkness and after a hard day’s work. The

Wall was dismantled, and reconstructed at the Arboretum by British soldiers from 37th Armoured Engineer Squadron in a

personal gesture to commemorate their fallen comrades. The original bricks would not have survived our climate, so have been

incorporated into the foundations and replaced by red granite. The brass plaques on this memorial are the originals placed on

the wall when it was in situ in Basra, Iraq. The plaques are cleaned twice a year; before the anniversary of the end of combat

operations in Iraq and before Armistice, but in between they are allowed to weather naturally. This will allow the detail on these

original plaques to last for as long as possible for the benefit of future generations.

On the back of the memorial is a representation of the Iraq Medal; the campaign medal issued to O›cers and Other Ranks of the

British Armed Forces as well as others, who served on, or in support of, Operation TELIC. It depicts an Assyrian protective deity,

known as a Lamassu and often shown with a bull or lion’s body, eagle’s wings, and human head. The bull demonstrates strength.

The eagle, being the most powerful bird in the sky, symbolises the king’s power as he looks over those he rules. The crowned

human head represents intelligence. On top of the head is a crown, which features horns as a sign of divinity. It is symbolic of the

region in which British service personnel fought.

name: Royal Army Physical Training Corps (RAPTC)
description:
Memorial Opposite the Basra Wall on the raised grass area is a memorial to The Royal Army Physical Training Corps (RAPTC),

which is responsible for physical fitness and physical education and was formed in 1860 as the Army Gymnastic StaŽ. The

memorial is made from black polished granite with a sandstone top and is shaped like a gymnastic vaulting box. The design has

the inscription, motto and badge of the RAPTC together with the dates reflecting the name changes of the Corps. The sides of

the memorial are inscribed with the words of the RAPTC Collect and Corps March. The memorial stands on a stone pavement

with date inscribed sandstone balls located at each corner.

name: King’s Royal Hussars Memorial
description:
Dedicated to mark the 300th anniversary of the rising of the earliest antecedent regiments, the Light Dragoons and the Prince of

Wales’s Own Hussars. The regiment and its antecedent regiments have taken part in many wars and campaigns over 300 years

including the Duke of Wellington’s Peninsular War, the Indian Mutiny, the Boer War and both World Wars. It was during the

Battle of Vitoria (June 1813) that the Duchess of York’s Own Light Dragoons captured a silver chamberpot belonging to Joseph

Bonaparte (brother of the Emperor) and as a result acquired the nickname 'The Emperor’s Chambermaids'. The o›cers still drink

from the pot on mess nights.

name: Duke of Lancaster’s Regiment Memorial
description:
The Duke of Lancaster’s Regiment is the Infantry Regiment of the North-West of England, known as the 'Lions of England'. The

reigning monarch of the United Kingdom is the Duke of Lancaster. The regiment consists of two Regular Army Battalions (1

LANCS and 2 LANCS) and one Army Reserve Battalion (4 LANCS). It was formed on 1 July 2006 by the amalgamation of the King’s

Own Royal Border Regiment, the King’s Regiment and the Queen’s Lancashire Regiment. The memorial includes a carved plinth

of Cumbrian stone, which is set on a circular stone pavement. The impressive heraldic ‘Lion of England’, standing proudly on top

of the plinth, commemorates those The Gordon Highlanders Memorial Representing the 200-year history of the Regiment and

the soldiers’ family roots, the memorial is an ever-lasting statement for future generations. It is sculpted from local material to

identify with the Gordon Highlanders. Underneath the main Gordon Highlanders cap badge, the inscription concludes with the

Regiment’s motto – the Scottish word ‘bydand’, which translates to ‘steadfast’, or 'not to run away from danger and keep going

no matter the di›culties'. who have died whilst serving with the Regiment since its formation. The memorial, with the Lion’s paw

pointing towards Lancaster, was unveiled by Her Late Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, the then Colonel-in-Chief, The Duke of

Lancaster’s Regiment on 17 May 2016.

name: Soroptimist International
description:
Soroptimist International is a vibrant, dynamic organisation for today’s professional women. They are committed to a world

where women and girls achieve their individual and collective potential, realise aspirations and have an equal voice in creating

strong, peaceful communities worldwide. The name Soroptimist derives from the Latin soror, meaning sister, and optima,

meaning best. It can be translated as ‘best of sisters’. Soroptimist International is the world’s largest women’s service

organisation. For 100 years, Soroptimists around the world have worked to improve the lives of women and girls by focussing on

education, empowerment and enablement through awareness, action and advocacy. The sculpture, features a limestone base

with a design that reflects the diversity of Soroptimists. The women are holding hands showing unity and friendship, and are

facing outwards to face the challenges ahead. On top of the limestone base is a glass structure made of individual blue

toughened glass layers forming the iconic logo of Soroptimist International Great Britain and Ireland - the merging of the letters

S and I. Soroptimist International Great Britain and Ireland has had a presence at the Arboretum since 2003, working towards the

global initiative of ‘Planting Trees for a Brilliant Future’. To-date, over 65,000 trees have been planted world-wide and

Soroptimist International works with the United Nations on the sustainable development goals.

name: Armed Forces Memorial
description:
The Armed Forces Memorial, dedicated in the presence of Her Late Majesty Queen Elizabeth II on 12 October 2007, is a

nationally significant focus for Remembrance, providing recognition and thanks for those from our Armed Forces who have given

their lives in the service of the country since the end of the Second World War. The Memorial is a stunning piece of architecture

designed by Liam O’Connor, which draws its inspiration from the ancient landscapes of prehistoric Britain and the classical forms

of ancient Rome. It consists of a six-metre-high earth mound, 100 metres wide at the base reducing to 50 metres wide at the

top, which is based on early British barrows or tumuli. The spiral walkway that navigates the grassy slopes, planted with clipped

holm oaks 'Quercus ilex', provides accessibility to people of all ages and levels of mobility. At the top of the mound stands a 43

metre diameter stone structure, comprising two curved walls and two straight walls which are constructed of 200,000 bricks

faced with over 1,000 tonnes of Portland stone panels. In recognition of the importance of Armistice Day, a gap has been left in

the two southern walls, which allows a shaft of sunlight to penetrate to the heart of the Memorial, onto the central bronze

wreath.

The Memorial is particularly important for the many families and friends who have no grave to visit, or who remember those in

graves in far-off places. The Memorial plays a valuable role in helping all who grieve for an Armed Forces service person to come

to terms with their loss, by providing a focus for their grief as they pass through different stages of their lives. The names are

arranged firstly by year and then in service order: Royal Navy, Army and then the Royal Air Force. Within service order the names

are arranged chronologically, in the order of the event which caused the death. This ensures that those who died together are

recorded and remembered together. The name and initials are shown without ranks but, where appropriate, honours are also

included. In the summer of each year the names of those who have died in the previous year will be carved and their names

dedicated at a special service. At the centre of the Memorial are two bronze sculptures, the embodiment of loss and sacrifice.

Created by Ian Rank-Broadley, best known for his image of Her Late Majesty Queen Elizabeth II which appeared on all UK and

Commonwealth coinage produced between 1998 - 2015, the sculptures bear silent witness to the cost of armed conflict. This

significant work is becoming an icon identifiable to all and especially to those who live with the consequences of the Nation’s call

to duty.

name: Phantom Memorial
description:
The Phantoms were a wireless communication unit for the Special Air Service (SAS). The memorial particularly remembers

events of 1944 when F Squadron was in France to provide communications for Operation Loyton. The path is laid out in a ‘P’

design to denote the word Phantom; planting represents the 140 men and boys who did not return from concentration camps.

The coral granite memorial stone was cut from a much larger stone at Senones, a few miles from Moussey, and represents the

resolve of the villagers and resistance forces that protected the soldiers on the operation. The Cross of Lorraine was later added

to the memorial to represent the Anglo / Norman link.

name: Royal Air Force Boy Entrants Memorial
description:
Dedicated in memory of the many thousands of boy entrants who trained between 1934 and 1965 and to record their singular

contribution to the Royal Air Force.

name: RAF Administrative Apprentices Memorial
description:
Commemorates all who trained as RAF Administrative Apprentices and Apprentice Clerks from 1925–1973 at Ruislip, St. Athan,

Hereford and Bircham Newton.

name: Girls Venture Corps Memorial
description:
The Girls Venture Corps Air Cadets is a voluntary uniformed organisation set up to meet the aspirations of young women

between the ages of 11–20 and adult volunteers of all ages.

name: Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers (REME) Memorial
description:
The Corps of Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers (REME) maintain the equipment used by the British Army. The memorial

is dedicated to past and present members of the Corps and depicts both their former and current badges. Planting includes oak

‘Quercus’ trees and bluebells - ‘bluebell’ was their call sign.

name: Auxiliary Territorial Service / ACK ACK (ATS / ACK ACK)
description:
A memorial rock remembering the women who staffed the anti-aircraft guns in the Second World War, the Auxiliary Territorial

Service / ACK ACK (ATS / ACK ACK), who were attached to the Royal Artillery.

name: Victims of Overseas Terrorism
description:
This national memorial recognises the loss that has been suŽered by British families through acts of terrorism overseas. The

memorial sculpture named ‘Still Water’ is designed to represent the calm after the storm, reflecting how the trauma of an event

for any person who suŽers loss will eventually lessen but not be forgotten.

name: Women’s Section Memorial, The Royal British Legion
description:
The stone plinth, surrounding garden and benches are dedicated to members and friends of the Royal British Legion Women’s

Section. The three trees in the garden are maple ‘Acer’, mountain ash ‘Sorbus aucuparia’ and a three stemmed silver birch

‘Betula pendula’.

name: Allied Special Forces Association Grove
description:
The Allied Special Forces Association Grove is a living memorial, laid out in the form of an ‘Open Air Book’, where you can read

about individuals and military units who have served with the Allied Special Forces up to the present day. The Grove has an oak

sun room at its heart, and includes memorials to historical moments such as; the Dieppe Raid, Cockleshell Heroes, the Battle of

Mirbat, the Falklands Conflict and many others.

name: The Falkland Islanders Resistance Memorial
description:
This memorial depicts three upland/ magellan geese in flight, heading south. The three geese represent lightness, movement

and freedom.

name: 10th Royal Hussars Memorial
description:
The Regiment was raised as Humphrey Gore’s Regiment of Dragoons at Hertford in 1715 as part of the response to the Jacobite

rising.



In 1784, His Majesty King George III appointed his son, then Prince of Wales, as Colonel of the Regiment which has since borne

the title of ‘Prince of Wales’s Own’ with the coronet and feathers, together with the Rising Sun and Red Dragon (an ancient

badge of Wales) and the motto “Ich Dien” (“I serve”).



The Regiment campaigned in the Peninsula War and fought at Waterloo. The 10th were in the Crimea and were awarded two

VCs in the South African War.



In 1806, the Prince of Wales obtained permission to clothe and equip the regiment as Hussars and it thus became the First

Hussar Regiment in the British Army. The 10th Royal Hussars has taken part in most British Army campaigns around the world.
