On 25 October 1969, the 10th Royal Hussars amalgamated with the 11th Hussars to form the Royal Hussars.



One nickname is ‘The shiny 10th’, possibly a derivation from the earlier ‘Chainy 10th’ which came from various ‘chain mail’

type uniform insignia and decoration which needed to be kept highly polished.

name: The 11th Hussars (Prince Albert’s Own)
description:
The 11th Hussars (Prince Albert’s Own) was established in 1715 as a cavalry regiment of the British Army.



Conflicts and battles in which the Regiment has taken part are listed on the plinth, including the Battle of Waterloo and Charge

of the Light Brigade. The Regiment is associated with notable personalities including Prince Albert (husband of Queen Victoria)

from whom the Regiment got its famous cherry coloured trousers. The nickname Cherry Pickers came after an incident in a

cherry orchard during the Peninsular War.



During the Second World War, the Regiment led the Desert Rats, the 7th Armoured Division, and were the first British troops

into Berlin. The 77 battle honours shown on the memorial tell the full story. The Regiment was amalgamated with the 10th

Royal Hussars in 1969.

name: Boys Brigade
description:
This garden, a grass rectangle with one corner curved, is bounded by a low hedge of field maple and box.



At the entrance, two pieces of 5,000 year old ‘bog oak’, donated by the Republic of Ireland and the Northern Ireland Districts,

depict the twin pillars of Religion and Discipline. A path winds down to a small patio area where visitors can sit on a bench, set

on a bed of Portland stone.



A large granite rock from Scotland, to which a real metal anchor is attached and inscribed with the chorus of The Boys’ Brigade

Hymn “Will your anchor hold?”, occupies a prominent position, as does a solid slate plinth from Wales in the centre of the

patio.



Five Hundred bulbs were planted in 2009 – 125 bulbs each of standard daffodils, pheasant-eye narcissi, Tête-à-tête daffodils

and blue grape hyacinths. The bulbs represent the 125 years of existence of The Boys’ Brigade.



Along one side of the Garden are 17 stones, each bearing the name of a Boys Brigade member who has been awarded the

Victoria Cross.



A time capsule was buried in the garden containing items from Boys’ Brigade young people in 2009.

name: Church Girls Brigade/Church Lads Brigade
description:
Dedicated on 22 June 2002, the garden was one of the first memorials to be created after the Arboretum was opened to the

general public.



It is dedicated to members of The Church Lads’ and Church Girls’ Brigade who served their country in war and peace. Also

dedicated during the ceremony was the Lectern Bible which was donated by the Brigade Association for use in the Millennium

Chapel in Advent 2001.



It is estimated that around 50,000 Brigade lads served in the First World War, during which many honours and distinctions

were awarded, including 21 Victoria Crosses. It is not recorded how many Brigade personnel served in the Second World War,

nor the honours awarded, but an additional Brigade lad received the Victoria Cross in 1945 posthumously.



Younger Brigade lads and girls also served on the Home Front in both World Wars. The 22 Berberis shrubs were selected to

represent the Brigade’s military past but, more specifically, to represent its 22 Victoria Cross recipients.



The pathways form a Christian Cross to represent the Brigade’s present path. The two benches commemorate the 16th

Battalion of the King’s Royal Rifle Corps which was comprised entirely of past and present members of the Brigade in the First

World War. This was known as a “Pals'.



The title plaque on the plinth has some of its information recorded in Braille, for the benefit of those with impaired sight.

name: 36th Ulster Division
description:
The memorial commemorates the actions of the 36th (Ulster) Division during the First World War.



The 36th (Ulster) Division, formed in September 1914 under Kitchener’s ‘New Army’ recruitment initiative, played a vital role

in the Great War. Commanded initially by Major General C H Powell C.B., the Division was made up from units of the Ulster

Volunteer Force, which had been formed in 1913 to fight against Home Rule in Ireland. After initial training in Ireland, Seaford

and Aldershot, the Division was deployed to France in September 1915 under the command of Major General Oliver Nugent

C.B. D.S.O.



The 36th (Ulster) Division took part in the long awaited ‘Big Push’– the Battle of the Somme - commencing on 1 July 1916.

Remarkably, progressing as far as the German Third Line, they were the farthest advances made on the day. However, the

Division subsequently got caught in German enfilade (flanking) fire from the side and from behind and with the possibility of

being cut off with limited supplies they withdrew and were relieved the following day having suffered heavy causalities.



The bravery and exploits of the Division are legendary - seeing action in many of the subsequent campaigns of the Western

Front until the Armistice in November 1918. The Division ceased all military action at the end of June 1919 when the last

soldiers were de-mobbed.



It is estimated that The Great War cost 36th (Ulster) Division 32,186 men killed, wounded or missing.



The memorial comprises a large, rustic, black granite stone on a base plinth with a black polished façade inscribed with gold

lettering. The stone’s rugged profile, suggesting the toughness of the men who fought in the 36th (Ulster) Division, is

emphasised by the lines of the polished face.



The heraldic Red Hand of Ulster (depicted: sinister / left), which is the insignia badge of the 36th Division, is featured at the

top of the memorial above the following inscription:



This memorial is dedicated to the Officers and Men of the 36th (Ulster) Division who fought in the 1st World War and the

Nursing and Medical corps who served beside them.



At the centre of the memorial is a reproduction of the famous James Prinsep Beadle painting ‘The Attack of the Ulster Division’

depicting a scene on the fist day of the Battle of the Somme (1 July 1916), the original of which hangs in the City Hall, Belfast.

The Division’s Western Front campaigns are listed either side of this.



Interestingly, soil from each of Ulster’s nine Counties has been placed within the memorial along with soil from the following

battlefield sites: Somme, Messines, Passchendaele, Wytchaete and Polcapelle.



In total, nine members of the 36th (Ulster) Division were awarded the Victoria Cross, four of which were awarded for actions

during the Battle of the Somme.



Below the central painting is a verse from the poem Remember Them by D. Ross Campbell:



They heard the call, they answered yes,



They proudly wore the battle dress,



For us who live they gave their all



That our great flag would never fall.



The base of the memorial displays the inscription: At the going down of the sun and in the morning we will remember them,

whilst the reverse notes the memorial was funded by the 36th (Ulster) Division Memorial Association.



Footnote:



The famous Ulster Tower memorial (based on Helen's Tower in Clandboye near Belfast), which dominates the skyline around

the village of Thiepval in Northern France, occupies the site of what was the German Front Line and is opposite Thiepval Wood

where the 36th (Ulster) Division made its historic charge on the first day of the Battle of the Somme.

name: The Cheshire Yeomanry Memorial
description:
'Moving Forward, Looking Back'



This memorial was commissioned to coincide with the 225th anniversary of the raising of the Cheshire Yeomanry Regiment.

With the constant uncertainties of future British Army structures and the unknown future threats of town planning, what

better place to secure our memorial, for future generations of Cheshire Yeomen, than at the National Memorial Arboretum.

We now have a permanent and fitting place to lay our wreaths and pay our respects to all our comrades. We have a focal point

to be able to contemplate those that have gone before us.



The Cheshire Yeomanry was raised as a light cavalry regiment in 1797 under the threat of a Napoleonic invasion. The regiment

has built a proud history during that period. Our role remains today as Light Cavalry and throughout its early history up to and

during World War 2 the regiment served with its constant companion, the horse. Since then, we have had another type of

companion, who has been our protection, our weapon, our shelter and our means of transport, the mechanised vehicle. Our

memorial represents the strength and power of a horse, but at the same time represents through its design, examples of many

of those other vehicles.



Designer and Sculptor - Joanne Risley (Sculptor)



“I was very honoured to have been chosen to create the memorial sculpture for the Cheshire Yeomanry to celebrate 225 years

since its inception. In response to the brief, I have designed a life-sized rearing war horse created using the mechanisms,

structure and detail found on the Fox, Ferret and Jackal armoured vehicles.



Objects of war mix with more familiar domestic objects such as a spade and the beloved ‘BV’ boiling vessel that provides the

crew with hot water for tea and cooking. The plinth carries a turret wheel which frames the cast bronze regimental crest. I

have tried to encapsulate the strength and dynamism of the animal with the armoured feel of the regiment’s vehicles.



The arboretum already features a highly naturalistic life-size horse so I wanted to create a unique and modern monument that

would strike a different note. The regiment kindly provided historic context, photographic material and access to Fox Barracks

where I was able to study one of the Jackal vehicles up close. At the Cheshire Military Museum the Fox and Ferret armoured

vehicles provided further inspiration.



The body of the horse is tank-like and incorporates toeholds, wheel arches, rear lights and smoke canisters. The legs and thighs

are formed from wheels and tyre treads with the helmet-like head supported by gun parts and a spine and ribs derived from

the Jackal anti-roll system.



The whole sculpture stands 3m tall. Created from weathering steel, which contains copper and smaller bronze elements, the

overall appearance will take on a rusted and aged appearance whilst the material’s unique properties provide a protective

surface that will endure indefinitely.



As well as being of symbolic and emotional importance to the regiment, the horse embodies courage, freedom, power,

endurance, personal drive, passion and heroism. The animal appears to be moving forward but looking back in order to

represent soldiers of the regiment past and present.



Joanne Risley studied Fine Art at Mid-Cheshire College, Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art and then at The University of

Ulster.



She was elected a member of Manchester Academy of Fine Art in 2017. www.joannerisley.co.uk



Materials Used - Rusted Corten steel, copper, and smaller bronze elements.



Age of Memorial - The build was completed during 2021 and installed at the NMA in June 2022 and a dedication ceremony

was held 12th June 2022.



Symbolism - The Memorial has been created to allow visitors to remember those lost and to contemplate, surrounded by the

memorials of all Yeomanry Regiments and positioned so that there is a full view from all angles of Yeomanry Avenue.

name: Civil Defence George Cross Awards
description:
This memorial commemorates the 12 men awarded the George Cross for outstanding bravery while engaged in Civil Defence

work. Ten recipients, who were Civil Defenders during WWII, are also commemorated by a blue plaque, erected on 30th June

2007, by an oak tree behind this memorial.



Nine men were awarded the George Cross for Fire and Rescue duties that frequently involved burrowing through burning

buildings in danger of further collapse; in fact the first individual to be awarded the George Cross was Thomas Hopper Alderson

who was part of this group.



Three men were awarded the George Cross for bomb disposal work, one of whom, Charles Howard was killed when the bomb

on which he was working blew up. For security reasons the citation for these three men sometimes read “For conspicuous

bravery in carrying out dangerous duties”.



Two men, Frederick Davies and George Henderson, were Civil Defenders who have been awarded the George Cross for

gallantry since World War II. George Henderson was a Gibraltar fireman who received a posthumous award for his gallantry:

for this reason a piece of stone from the Rock of Gibraltar has been placed in the memorial.



The memorial was unveiled on 18th June 2011 by Jim Beaton GC, Chairman of the VC and GC Association. Jim Beaton’s own

award was for the defence of Princess Anne when she was attacked in the Mall in 1974.

name: Cyprus Emergency (1955-1959)
description:
The memorial, located within the Mediterranean Campaigns of World War II Garden, is dedicated to all those who served

during the ‘Cyprus Emergency’ 1955 – 1959 and in memory of the 371 who lost their lives together with 21 British Policemen.



The memorial comprises a large Cypriot rock, which was transport to the Arboretum by the RAF, set on top of a polished

granite plinth inscribed with the insignia of all the units involved. An outline map of Cyprus is displayed on the side of the rock

which includes the dedication. Inside the rock is held the ‘Roll of Honour’ with details of the 371 who lost their lives together

with 21 British Policemen killed.

name: Glider Pilot Regiment
description:
The Regiment was established in 1942 and remained active until 1957, when it was absorbed into the modern Army Air Corps.



The Regiment’s motto was “Nothing is impossible”, as the nature of their one way trips required the aircrews to subsequently

join in combat operations on the ground.



The Regiment’s highly trained aircrew was also used to great effect in covert activity.



In the post war years, the Regiment remained active, undertaking liaison and reconnaissance roles in the Light Aircraft Flights

operated by the Army. On 1 September 1957, the Regiment disbanded to create the foundation of what was to become the

modern Army Air Corps.



The memorial stone is sourced from Gelderland in the Netherlands to acknowledge the Regiment’s major role in the Battle of

Arnhem.

name: Hiroshima Memorial
description:
The Hiroshima Memorial Cairn lies at the corner of the Anglo-Japanese Peace Garden and is surmounted by a granite stonefrom

the ruins of Hiroshima.



The nearby plaque reminds us of the efforts of the late Philip Malins MBE MC, the Midland Japanese Association and the East

Midlands Japanese Association in enabling the memorial to be placed here.



The following inscription curves round the base of the Cairn:



This memorial, the topmost stone of which is denoted by the people of Hiroshima from the ruins of their city, destroyed by an

atomic bomb in 1945, remembers the millions of people who died and suffered in the Second World War. It gives thank that

the world has since been free from world war, which hope there will never be another and that the people of Britain and Japan

will remain forever united in friendship.

name: Orange Institution Memorial
description:
The Orange Institution was formed over 200 years ago to commemorate the victory won at the Battle of the Boyne in County

Meath, Ireland by William of Orange (King William III) over James II in July 1690. Since its formation many members of the

Order have joined the British Armed Forces and served around the world.



A memorial to the service and sacrifice of members of the Orange Institution was unveiled at the National Memorial Arboretum

on Saturday 2 September 2017 and was formally dedicated by the Grand Master of the Grand Orange Lodge of Scotland, Jim

McHarg.



It is formed in the shape of a lectern with an open Bible on top dressed with an Orange collarette.



The inscribed message in gold lettering reads: ‘This Memorial is Dedicated to God and erected to Joshua, in thanksgiving to all

members of the Loyal Orange Institution who served and paid the supreme sacrifice in the service of their Country’.



An Orange Institution memorial behind the Ulster Tower in Albert, France is dedicated to all those members who lost their

lives in service during the First World War.



An Orange Lodge in Cumbria was opened in memory of Private Abraham Acton who, as a member of the Whitehaven Lodge,

was awarded the Victoria Cross for his bravery rescuing wounded comrades whilst under heavy enemy fire during the Battle

of Rouge Banc in France in 1914. He was killed in action on 16 May 1915 during the Battle of Festubert, before he could collect

his medal, and his body was never recovered. He was only 22 years old.

name: Palestine Police Memorial Old Comrades
description:
The memorial, located within the Mediterranean Campaigns of World War II Garden, is in memory of all those who served in

the Palestinian Police, a British colonial police force, in the period of British Mandate between 1922-1948.



The memorial displays the badge of the Palestinian Police together with a dedication remembering over 500 members of the

force who died during the British Mandate. It also acknowledges that over 300 medals were awarded, including one George

Medal, during this period.



The final ‘stand down’ parade for the Palestinian Police took place at Buckingham Palace on 20 July 1948, where in his address

King George VI said of the force ‘you can look back on a job well done’.

name: Palestine Veterans Association
description:
Palestine Veterans' Association Memorial, located within the Mediterranean Campaigns of World War II Garden, is dedicated

to the memory of 784 members of the British Armed Forces who lost their lives whilst acting as a peace keeping force in the

region.



The memorial plaque, which displays the badge of the Palestine Veterans' Association, includes the dedication: “When

Comrades fall, we’ve shown them all, we never shall forget”.

name: MEMORIAL TO THE VENERABLE ORDER OF THE HOSPITAL OF St JOHN OF JERUSALEM
description:
The memorial dedicated to the Order of St John was designed and installed to commemorate the thousands of volunteers who

have helped the charity over the years in its mission to provide first aid in many different situations. Prince Richard, Duke of

Gloucester, who is the Grand Prior of the Order of St John, officially opened the memorial in 2009; however, it took some

fourteen years to completion and was not finally completed until 2022.



The design of the memorial takes the form of the St John (Amalfi) Cross. The entrance is through one of the arms of the cross

which is flanked by two granite panels depicting the badge of St John and the Priory of England and the Islands. At the centre

of the cross is a black granite stone with the inscription: “In honour of all those who have faithfully served the Venerable Order

of the Hospital of St John of Jerusalem and its foundations.”



The other various priory emblems are fixed to the arms of the memorial in order of precedence (It should be noted that

because the cross was designed to give a particular perspective when viewed from the front, the tops of the walls which form

the arms of the cross are slanted and therefore are not necessarily horizontal. In order to ensure that all the plaques are in

line with each other when the monument is viewed as a whole, individual plaques will not always be parallel to the tops of the

respective wall to which they are attached.)



The Venerable Order of the Hospital of St John of Jerusalem shares its origins with the religious Knights Hospitaller, who served

in a hospice in Jerusalem which looked after pilgrims in the twelfth century. The English branch was dissolved by King Henry

VIII in 1540 and briefly reinstated by Queen Mary in 1557. An early 19th century move to revive the Order in England eventually

resulted in the creation of a British Royal Order of Chivalry. Her Majesty Queen Victoria granted the Order of St John a Royal

Charter and became its Sovereign Head in 1888. The Order, as an Order of Chivalry, is unique in its corporate work for the

benefit of society. It has two key foundations: the St John of Jerusalem Eye Hospital and St John Ambulance.



The Order conducts its affairs around the world through the St John Eye Hospital Group, 11 Priories, 5 Commanderies and 32

Associations. The Priory of England and the Islands manages the day-to-day affairs of Order business in England, Northern

Ireland, the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man. The Priory’s main role is delivered by its subsidiary charity StJohn Ambulance

which delivers first aid and first aid training in the community. It also carries out Ambulance work in support of the NHS, and

has a thriving Youth movement.



The Order is also involved in welfare services alongside the British Red Cross Society of the International Red Cross through a

residential home for ex servicemen and women, ex-nurses and ex-members of St John and the Red Cross. The welfare of

patients in Service Hospitals is looked after by the Order of St John and British Red Cross Defence Medical Welfare Service.

Furthermore, in association with the British Association of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta, through the Orders of St John

Care Trust the Priory promotes the Trust’s work with residential care homes and alms houses. The Order’s Museum is located

at St John’s Gate in Clerkenwell, London. There is also a flourishing St John Fellowship with branches throughout England and

the Islands, as well operating in many of the overseas priories and associations.



The Crests of the Priories of the Venerable Order of St John of Jerusalem are placed on the memorial in clockwise order as

follows:



England and Islands



Scotland



South Africa



Canada



USA



Singapore



Eye Hospital



Hong Kong



Kenya



Australia



New Zealand



Wales

name: Townswomens Guild
description:
The Townswomen’s Guild Memorial is dedicated to those who have served in HM Forces or in civilian services and died as

casualties of war, civil conflict or peacekeeping . It was unveiled by HRH The Princess Royal, Patron of the Townswomen’s

Guild, on 5 October 2017.



The memorial was funded by donations from Guild members, who raised over £15,000 through coffee mornings and

imaginative initiatives.



The Townswomen’s Guild was formed in 1929 but has its roots in the suffrage movement of the late 19th Century. During the

Second World War many member of the Guild were conscripted, worked in hosptials, civil defence, factories or on the land.

Others used their organisational skills to assist in the maintenance of civil society and staged shows and concerts to boost

morale.



Townswomen’s Guild is one of the largest women’s organisations in the UK with approximately 600 Guilds and 24,000

members. The Guild has seen significant growth in recent years from those attracted by the events, friendship, crafts and

opportunities to campaign on social issues offered collectively and by individual Guilds around the country.

name: Yorkshire Regiment
description:
The Yorkshire Regiment was formed from three former regiments: The Prince of Wales’s Own Regiment of Yorkshire, The

Green Howards, and the Duke of Wellington’s Regiment.



The design of the Yorkshire Regiment memorial is based on The Keeper of the Souls, a replica of an interpretation piece which

has been installed on the East Front of the York Minster. The Keeper of the Souls has a grand pedigree, being an original idea

of HRH The Duke of York who was Colonel in Chief of the Regiment. During a visit to the stone yard in February 2009, he

suggested that carvers might include a tribute to the soldiers and this idea was developed by Conservator Mason Carver; Lee

Godfrey.



The design of The Keeper of the Souls draws on the original motifs and meaning of York Minster’s Lady Chapel. It is based upon

the 14 Angels who surmount York Minster’s Great East Windows depiction of God the Father in heaven. The East Window

Angel voussoirs (wedge shaped stones used in the building of arches) influence the hair, facial features and cloud formation.

The wings and position of the hands are based on angels hovering in the bosses of the Lady Chapel. Finally, the altars in the

Lady Chapel were used as places to pray for the acceptance of departed souls.



The angel holds a shield to protect the insignia and souls of the Yorkshire Regiment; the angel is also the protector to the

insignia and souls of the antecedent regiment, namely: The Princes of Wales’s Own Regiment of Yorkshire, The Green Howards.

The Duke of Wellington’s Regiment (West Riding), The Yorkshire Volunteers and the Yorkshire Volunteers and the York and

Lancaster Regiment.

name: 9th/12th Royal Lancers
description:
The 9th/12th Royal Lancers can date its ancestry back to 1715 with the formation of Wynn's Dragoon and Bowles Dragoons.

The antecedent regiments served in many campaigns including the Peninsular War, Waterloo, Crimean War, Indian Mutiny,

Boer War, WW1 and WW2. In May 2015 it was amalgamated with the Queen's Royal Lancers (see Memorial M-287) to form

the Royal Lancers.



The amalgamation history is shown in the table below.



9th/12th Royal Lancers (Prince of Wales’s) September 1960

9th Regiment of (Light) Dragoons 1783 from 9th Regiment of Dragoons 1751 from Wynn’s Dragoons 1715



o 12th (Prince of Wales’s) Royal Lancers 1817 from 12th (Prince of Wales’s) Lancers 1816 from

(Prince of Wales’s) Light Dragoons 1768 from 12th Regiment of Dragoons 1751 from

Bowles’s Dragoon’s 1715

name: 1st Airborne Reconnaissance Squadron - The Freddie Gough Squadron.
description:
This black Scottish granite memorial is dedicated to the men of the 1st Airborne Reconnaissance Squadron, known as the Freddie

Gough Squadron.



The 1st Airborne Reconnaissance Squadron was a Reconnaissance Corps unit which formed part of the 1st Airborne Division and was

sent to North Africa, seeing service in Italy, Arnhem and finally in Norway. It had various names before the authorities settled on the

name by which it was finally known.



The first commanding officer was Major Freddie Gough and it quickly became known as the Freddie Gough Squadron. It should be

noted that Major Gough came from a distinguished military family (see below). Charles Frederick Howard “Freddie” Gough was born

in India in September 1901. He was awarded the MC for his actions with the Squadron during the Italian Campaign. The Squadron took

part in the Battle of Arnhem; hence the location of this memorial. Freddie Gough was taken prisoner at the Bridge at Arnhem and

remained a POW until he escaped in April 1945.



75 men from the Squadron escaped from the Arnhem Battle and at the end of the war were sent to Norway to help disarm the German

occupying forces. During the autumn of 1945 the Squadron was demobilised.



After the war Freddie Gough was Member of Parliament for Horsham and died at the age of 76 while on holiday on Italy in 1977.



The Gough VCs



Three members of the Gough family were awarded the Victoria Cross.



General Charles John Stanley Gough VC, GCB

General Hugh Henry Stanley Gough VC, GCB (brother of Charles & grandfather of Freddie)

Brigadier General John Edmund Gough VC, KCB, CMG (son of Charles)

name: 214 (Federated Malay States) Squadron RAF Memorial
description:
The memorial commemorates the distinguished record of the No 214 (FMS) Squadron in bomber, radio, countermeasures, transport

and in air-to-air refueling tanker roles. It remembers all those who served on the Squadron and those who gave their lives in war and

peace.



Formed originally as No.7A Squadron, Royal Navy Air Service on 28 July 1917, it became No 214 Squadron and was named the

Federated Malay States Squadron in June 1941 in recognition of the gift of aircraft purchased with funds subscribed to the British

Government through the Federated Malay States war fund.



No 214 Squadron, Royal Air Force, was disbanded on 28 January 1977.



The memorial is located within the RAF Memorial Grove (known as the RAF Wing) which comprises a collection of silver birch trees

planted in the shape of an eagle’s wings. The wing honours both the Fighter and Bomber Commands.

name: 4th Royal Tank regiment 1916-1993
description:
This stone Alter was originally presented to the Church Centre, York Barracks, Munster in Germany.



It was later rescued and re-erected at the Arboretum by the 4th Royal Tank Regiment of Scotland.



Dedicated on 5 May 2016, the memorial commemorates all those who served in “D” Company Heavy Section Machine Gun Corps, “D”

Company Tank Corps, 4th Battalion Royal Tank Corps, and the 4th Royal Tank Regiment 1916-1993.



The badge of the 4th Royal Tank Regiment is inscribed on the upright face of the memorial together with the Regiment motto: “Fear

Naught”.

name: 49 Squadron RAF
description:
The memorial to 49 Squadron is made of polished South African Dark Grey granite. The circular headpiece, fixed to a rectangular base,

depicts the squadron’s badge - a racing greyhound surmounting the motto 'Cave Canem' (Beware of the Dog) and is surrounded by

the inscription: 49 Bomber Squadron Royal Air Force. The badge was officially recognised on 14 June 1937 following the Squadron’s

relocation to Worthy Down.



The base of the memorial is inscribed with the words:



In memory of those who served on 49 Squadron 1916 – 1965



49 Squadron was originally formed during the First World War at Dover in April 1916. Its first 18 months were spent as an aircrew

training unit equipped with BE2Cs, RE7s and Martinsydes. Between 1917 and 1918 the squadron was tasked with day bombing raids

and high and low level bombing until the end of the war when it was subsequently disbanded in July 1919.



During the Second World War the reformed squadron operated as a front line bomber squadron and took part in most major

operations by Bomber Command equipped with Lancaster Bombers. In peacetime the squadron carried out routine training and also

saw action in Kenya.



In 1956, equipped with Valiant B1 aircraft (the first of the V Bombers), the squadron was tasked with carrying out a series of nuclear

tests based on Christmas Island in the Pacific Ocean.



Reverting to the normal medium bomber role the squadron moved to Marham in 1961. On 5 June 1964 Her Royal Highness Princess

Marina, Duchess of Kent, presented 49 Squadron with its standard.



49 Squadron was disbanded at RAF Marham on 1 May 1965, when all Valiant aircraft were withdrawn from service.



Honours and awards gained by members of 49 Squadron during the Second World War include:



1 Victoria Cross (VC)



(Awarded to Flight Lieutenant (later Wing Commander) Roderick Alastair Brook Learoyd for his bravery during the successful low level

attack on the Dortmund Ems canal, 12 August 1940. It was the first VC awarded in Bomber Command.



1 Empire Gallantry Medal (later the George Cross)



7 Distinguished Service Orders



131 Distinguished Flying Crosses



2 Conspicuous Gallantry Medals



105 Distinguished Flying Medals

name: 90 Signals Unit TCU
description:
90 Signals Unit (90SU) provides a vital role in ensuring the RAF achieves operational success and exists to provide Expeditionary

Information Services, whenever they are required.



Comprising two Wings, Force Generation Wing (FGW) and Tactical Communications Wing (TCW), the Unit’s history can be traced back

to the mid1950s, although TCW did not become an autonomous signals unit until later (1973).



Since this time, 90SU have been involved in every major conflict and support operation that has taken place worldwide.

name: Air Formation and Support Signals
description: The Air Formation and Air Support Signals Memorial is in the RAF Wing.

name: Air Loadmaster Association
description:
The Air Loadmaster Association is one of only a few remaining associations for members of the Royal Air Force who have served as Air

Quartermaster or Air Loadmasters (AQM and ALMs).



The memorial, located within the RAF Memorial Grove (known as RAF Wing), is a truncated obelisk of white Portland Stone set in a

blue slate bed edged with small stones. The front face of the pyramidal top is engraved with the letters RAF below which the face of

the memorial is ornamented by engravings of Air Loadmaster insignia and a dedication to the fallen.



During the service of dedication on 14 October 2011 a fly past took place to honour those killed in action, or in the course of duty.

name: Ancient Burial Ground
description:
At the heart of the Arboretum is a Bronze Age burial mound that is between 3500 and 4500 years old.



The Bronze Age is the name given to the period of time between the Stone Age and the Iron Age. Bronze is a metal alloy, or mixture

of tin and copper, and was used extensively to make a wide range of tools and weapons.



The monument was first identified from an aerial photograph taken in 1965, which revealed the visible cropmarks of a prehistoric

multiple ring ditch. It was later Scheduled as a site of historic significance in 1969. Although there is little in the way of discernible

remains above ground the site is now a set-aside wildflower meadow which attracts much important wildlife.



During excavations in 1996, a prehistoric pottery vessel thought to be a late example of Beaker Ware, was discovered by archaeologists

about 0.5m below the surface. Very few examples have been found in the Trent Valley and so this is an important find. The vessel is

currently on display in the Landscapes of Life exhibition in the Remembrance Centre.



In the Bronze Age, many important people were buried under mounds like this one. Excavations show that it was probably part of a

much bigger commemorative landscape that included other burial monuments. Between 1500 and 500 BC, this prehistoric landscape

seems to have changed. No new monuments were built, and the meaning of the old ones probably faded as farming and flooding

eroded their remains. Thousands of years later, archaeologists working during quarrying are revealing their stories.



Bronze Age burial mounds marked territory and reflected status. Their size and positioning in the landscape sent out a message. This

mound is set above where the River Tame meets the Trent.

name: Princess Louise’s Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders
description:
Princess Louise’s Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders were formed in 1881 from the amalgamation of the 91st Regiment of Foot (Argyll

Highlanders) and the 93rd Regiment of Foot (Sutherland Highlanders). In 2006, they were absorbed into the Royal Regiment of

Scotland.



During the First World War 27 Battalions were raised. Nine thousand Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders gave their lives in the First and

Second World Wars.



Sixteen members of the Regiment, including seven in the Sutherland Highlanders, were awarded the Victoria Cross.

name: Armed Services Wood
description:
The Armed Services Wood is a woodland of mixed trees individually sponsored as living tributes to those who served in the British

Army, the Royal Navy and the Royal Air Force.

name: Army Benevolent Fund Rose Garden
description: No information in CI.

name: Royal Army Chaplains’ Department
description:
The memorial is a tribute to all chaplains who have given their lives in war and conflict whilst serving in the Royal Army Chaplains’

Department (RAChD) as well as celebrating those who have served in it.



Chaplains are ordained, Professionally Qualified Officers who have been selected to hold a commission in the Army. They wear the

uniforms of the British Army and will accompany their soldiers wherever they go providing spiritual support, pastoral care and moral

guidance to all, irrespective of religion or belief. Chaplains exercise leadership and management but do not command. They are noncombatants and they do not bear arms.



Between 1914 and the end of hostilities in 1918, almost 4,400 Army Chaplains were recruited into uniform. Most of them saw service

in the trenches and 179 lost their lives. Many were decorated for bravery with three being awarded the Victoria Cross.



There are currently about 150 chaplains, known as ‘Padres’, serving with the British Army. Military veterans assisted blacksmiths in

the creation of the memorial, which was unveiled by Lieutenant General James Everard CBE, Commander Land Forces on 21 July 2015.



The ploughshare ends of the crossed swords reference the bible passage Isaiah 2:4 “they shall beat their swords into plowshares, and

their spears into pruning hooks…

name: Army Dog Unit (Northern Ireland) Association Red Paw Memorial
description:
This memorial was dedicated on 1 August 2009 to the memory of those, both humans and animals, who lost their lives whilst serving

in the Army Dog Unit, Northern Ireland.



The memorial comprises a natural boulder with an inscribed polished, black granite plaque displaying the Association’s red dog paw

badge and motto “Search and Secure”.

name: Army Wood
description:
This wood is divided into Army Wood -Central, Army Wood -East and Army Wood – West



The Army Wood comprises mixed native trees individually sponsored and dedicated to those who have served in the British Armed

Forces. Within the wood are the Irish, Tank, Logistics, Army Air Corps and Fusilier memorials.

name: Ulster Defence Regiment CGC Memorial Seat
description:
The Ulster Defence Regiment (UDR) was an infantry regiment formed in 1970. It was the largest regiment in the British Army - carrying

out regular patrols and establishing vehicle checkpoints on the public roads of Northern Ireland.



The UDR was operational for 22 years before amalgamating with the Royal Irish Rangers in 1992 to form the Royal Irish Regiment.



In 2007, the Conspicuous Gallantry Cross was awarded to the regiment for its service in Northern Ireland and now uses the post

nominal letters CGC as part of its name (The Ulster Defence Regiment CGC).



The memorial, a polished grey stone bench, bears the inscription: The Regimental Association of The Ulster Defence Regiment CGC.

Donated by the Portadown Branch. The badge of the UDR, a gold harp topped with a crown, appears above the inscription.



Accompanying the bench are a series of low-level dedicated plinths punctuating the Royal Ulster Defence Regiment Memorial Way.

name: RAF Barrage Balloons Memorial
description:
The memorial, unveiled in November 2015, is dedicated to the memory of the men and women who served with the Balloon Barrage

Squadrons of RAF Balloon Command during the Second World War.



The purpose of the Balloon Barrage was to prevent accurate bombing by forcing enemy aircraft to fly at higher altitude. This was

achieved by steel cables held up by the balloons flown to a height of up to 5,000 feet. Aircraft which flew into the cables could be

seriously damaged or brought down.



Barrage Balloons were filled with hydrogen gas and were flown from either fixed or mobile winches, each operated by ten men or 14

women and two NCOs.

name: The Royal Gloucestershire, Berkshire and Wiltshire Regiment
description:
This memorial commemorates the following regiments:



The Gloucestershire Regiment (28th & 61st) 1694 – 1994



The Royal Berkshire Regiment (Princess Charlotte of Wales’s) 1743 – 1959



The Wiltshire Regiment (Duke of Edinburgh’s) 1756 – 1959



The Duke of Edinburgh’s Royal Regiment (Berkshire and Wiltshire) 1959 — 1994 (The amalgamation of The Royal Berkshire

and The Wiltshire Regiments in 1959)



The Royal Gloucestershire, Berkshire and Wiltshire Regiment (1994 — 2007) (The amalgamation of The Gloucestershire and

The Duke of Edinburgh’s Royal Regiments in 1994)



In 2007 The Royal Gloucestershire, Berkshire and Wiltshire Regiment merged with The Devonshire & Dorset Regiment, The Light

Infantry and The Royal Green Jackets to form The Rifles.



The right to wear the ‘Back Badge’ on the back of their headdress was awarded to the 28th Regiment of Foot for extreme bravery at

the battle of Alexandria in 1801. It was subsequently worn by The Gloucestershire and The Royal Gloucestershire, Berkshire and

Wiltshire Regiments, and is now worn by The Rifles.

name: Bidadari Cemetery
description:
The four cherry trees commemorate the Bidadari Christian Cemetery, which contains the graves of people who died in Singapore from

1908 to 1972. Today, Bidadari Cemetery is no longer in use, and most of the graves have been exhumed to allow land redevelopment.

name: Birmingham Children’s Hospital Memorial
description:
There are five sculptures along this Riverside Walk, as well as further pieces within Birmingham Children’s Hospital. The organic or

‘seed-like’ sculptures represent the key sentiments of love, loss, endings and new beginnings. There is a bench at the beginning of the

walk.

name: British South Africa Police
description:
This memorial was dedicated on 25 July 2010 and replicates the memorial erected in 1921 in the Morris Depot (the training depot for

new recruits) in Salisbury, Rhodesia (now Harare, Zimbabwe).

name: Brixmis Memorial
description:
BRIXMIS (the British Commanders’- in-Chief Mission to the Soviet Forces in Germany) along with its American and French counterpart

military liaison missions, worked throughout the Cold War from 1946-1990 in East Germany.



As well as keeping open high-level communication channels between the Soviet and British military commands in Germany, these

missions evolved into highly professional and successful intelligence gathering units. Their patrolling operations, both on the ground

and in the air, were conducted under conditions of strict secrecy.



The dedication of the BRIXMIS Association Memorial at the Arboretum on 17 September 2016 marked the 70th anniversary of the

Anglo-Soviet agreement to set up reciprocal military liaison missions.

name: Cavalry Crescent
description:
The Cavalry Grove (Crescent) grove consists of a colourful mix of ornamental trees and memorials dedicated to the Cavalry Regiments

of the British Army. These include 9/12 Lancers, The Queen’s Royal Hussars, The Royal Dragoon Guards, The Queen’s Royal Lancers,

The King’s Royal Hussars and The Light Dragoons.

name: Cheshire Regiment Memorial Bench
description:
This polished grey granite bench from the people of Winsford is dedicated to the service men and women of The Cheshire Regiment

who gave their lives in conflict. The badges of the Cheshire Regiment, comprising an acorn accompanied by crossed oak leaves, are

displayed either side of the inscription.

name: Captain Class Frigates
description:
The 78 Captain Class Frigates were all built in the USA and supplied to the United Kingdom as part of the lend-lease programme. They

were all named after Royal Navy Captains who had served with distinction.



They served as Convoy escorts and anti-submarine vessels, contributing to the sinking of over 30 U-boats. However 7 were sunk and

a further 8 so severely damaged they were considered a constructive total loss.



At the end of the war they were rapidly returned to the USA in order to avoid further costs.



They can be divided into two groups:



Evarts Type – displacement of 1140 long tons, 290 feet long, diesel-electric propulsion and a complement of 156



Buckley Type– displacement of 1400 long tons, 306 feet long, tubo-electric propulsion and a complement of 156

name: The Catenian Association Memorial
description:
The Association



The Catenian Association is an organisation of Catholic men whose prime aim is to provide a network of support and friendship

amongst its members and their families including widows.



Members support the Church both locally and nationally. The Association believes strongly that it should support the development of

young people.



As part of this commitment, there is a Bursary Fund which provides grants to young people undertaking community projects and

helping at Lourdes.



Catenians are members of the Catholic Youth Ministry Federation and sponsor the major youth rally ‘Flame’ held every two years at

Wembley Arena.



In recent years, the Association has developed beyond Great Britain to Australia, Malta, India, Southern Africa, Ireland, Bangladesh

and Nazareth.



The Memorial



The memorial is situated in a very pleasant location alongside the Royal British Legion poppy field. It is immediately opposite the police

memorial.



It is a very peaceful location surrounded on three sides by trees representing a place for peaceful reflection.



The design is very simple topped with the Catenian Association emblem which is very distinctive as you approach. The emblem

represents a chain (“catena” is latin for chain) This is meant to symbolise togetherness, friendship and support.



The memorial is in memory of members of the Association and their families and friends who suffered, were wounded or gave their

lives in conflicts since its formation in 1908. It was designed to be an all embracing memorial and it is hoped that people will visit it as

an opportunity to reflect on all loved ones who are no longer with us.

name: Flt Lt J W Lucas DFC
description:
This memorial is dedicated by the Lucas family to honour Flight Lieutenant James William Lucas D.F.C 1918-2001, who in

commemoration of his dedication to duty as a Second World War pilot, was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross.



The memorial is a grey polish granite bench with a dedication panel of black polished granite beneath the seat. The panel is inscribed

with a dedication and features a propeller and the badge of Bomber Command contained within a white circle.



The memorial is located within the RAF Memorial Grove (known as the RAF Wing) which comprises a collection of silver birch trees

planted in the shape of an eagle’s wings.

name: Foresters Friendly Society Memorial
description:
The Ancient Order of Foresters Friendly Society was formed in 1834 to provide fraternal mutual support to members in times of

sickness and bereavement.



Two members of the Order Lance Corporal William Charles Fuller and Lance Corporal William Angus were awarded the Victoria Cross

for valour during the First World War.

name: Free Spirit Horse Memorial
description:
A tribute to the unique contribution made by horses throughout history in times of War. Recognising their continuing service to

humankind in Work, Rehabilitation, Education, Sport and Leisure.



In 2013 a group of people with a love of horses came together with a vision to create a memorial acknowledging the horse’s unfaltering

service to humankind and to celebrate the unique relationship between horses and humans that exists through sport, history, work,

rehabilitation, education and leisure. This beautiful sculpture and its carefully planned setting were unveiled in 2019, made possible

through generous donations and the work of local craftspeople who contributed their skills to realising the vision of Free Spirit.



Free Spirit is a unique project that embodies the inclusiveness that is reflected in the non-judgmental partnership between horse and

human. Gartmore Riding School in Hammerwich and many contributors raised funds to create a life-sized bronze statue acknowledging

the horse’s unfaltering service to humanity, to be displayed at the National Memorial Arboretum, Staffordshire.



There are few people left today that remember the essential role the horse played through history and how until a generation ago the

horse was part of everyday life. The memorial expresses endurance, service and partnership and represents determination and trust,

inspiration for which came from young people. The project brought together individuals from all ages and backgrounds sharing the

importance of the horse to different generations, ethnicities and religions.



The groundwork has been carefully designed to welcome all visitors, regardless of mobility or disability, allowing all members of society

to enjoy the memorial together. The provision of spaces between the seats creates multiple points of access for wheelchair users; a

lower plinth height and plaques incorporating Braille and Makaton allow the visually impaired to enjoy the memorial through a tactile

experience.



Free Spirit brought the essential contribution that the horse has made to humanity to new audiences and generations in a number of

projects, including art, music and history, and worked across the local community and beyond. The opportunity to meet a pony has

never been easily accessible to many of the young people visiting by the project, and Free Spirit recognises that the unique relationship

between horse and human can increase confidence and self-esteem, and that this connection leaves a legacy that continues to bring

joy to this and future generations.



The horse is part of our story, and the people involved in its inception and creation were particularly proud to see so many young

people engaging with the project. Inspired by the thoughts and feelings of these young people, Birmingham songwriter Dominic Malin

wrote a signature song for Free Spirit. The song embraces the qualities associated with the horse and the music reflects the past,

engages with the present and carries a message into the future.



It is an honour to have horses in our lives and Free Spirit represents this for centuries and generations to come.

name: Home Service Force
description:
The memorial plinth with its surrounding trees, shrubs and plaques is dedicated to the Home Service Force (HSF) 1985 – 1992.



The HSF was formed on 1 April 1985 as part of the Territorial Army (TA), although it is acknowledged that some units were formed on

a trial basis earlier than this.



Membership of the HSF was restricted to those who had previous service in the Armed Forces or in the TA. Forty-eight units were

formed throughout the country with each unit being attached to an existing Regular Army or TA Regiment or Battalion for things such

as administration and training.



The HSF was given the task of guarding key installations in the United Kingdom such as major power stations and communication

centres, the loss of which, through subversive enemy action, could have seriously affected the running of the country.



However, in 1992 the threat that had necessitated the forming of HSF was considered to have diminished sufficiently to enable it to

be disbanded.

name: Kingfisher Wood
description:
The Kingfisher Wood is a mixed woodland of individually dedicated native trees. It is named after the kingfishers seen flying along the

nearby riverbank.

name: Queen’s Own Highlanders
description:
The regiment was formed on 7 February 1961 at Redford Barracks, Edinburgh, with the amalgamation of 1st Battalion, Seaforth

Highlanders and 1st Battalion, Queen's Own Cameron Highlanders.



The battalion was sent to Singapore in April 1961 from where it was deployed to Brunei in December 1962 in order to help suppress

the Brunei Revolt at an early stage of the Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation. On return to Scotland in January 1964, it was based at

Milton Bridge Camp, a former facility for German Prisoners of War, located south east of Glencorse Barracks. In June 1964 the

battalion moved to Mercer Barracks at Osnabrück Garrison, part of British Army of the Rhine, remaining there until August 1966 when

the battalion moved to Wavell Barracks in Berlin.



The battalion returned to Redford Barracks in September 1968 from where units were deployed to Sharjah in May 1969. In April 1971

the battalion returned Osnabrück Garrison and moved into Belfast Barracks: from their units they were deployed to Northern Ireland

at the height of the Troubles. In June 1976 the battalion returned to Scotland, this time to Ritchie Camp from where more units were

deployed to Northern Ireland. Then in March 1980 the battalion was despatched for a tour at Stanley Fort in Hong Kong before

moving to Tidworth in November 1981. Units of the battalion saw action in the Falklands War the following year. The battalion

moved to Alexander Barracks, Aldergrove in November 1983 and on to Fort George in November 1985. In March 1988 the battalion

moved to Buller Barracks in Münster from where units were deployed to Northern Ireland again and to the Gulf War in 1991. The

battalion returned to Scotland again in October 1993 and moved into Dreghorn Barracks this time.



Due to the Options for Change defence review the battalion was amalgamated with 1st Battalion, Gordon Highlanders on 17

September 1994 to form 1st Battalion, Highlanders (Seaforth, Gordons and Camerons).

name: Sherwood Rangers Yeomanry
description:
The Sherwood Rangers Yeomanry (SRY) is one of the five squadrons of the Royal Yeomanry (RY), a light cavalry regiment of the Army

Reserve. Designated as 'A' Squadron, the Sherwood Rangers Yeomanry's current role is to support the Light Cavalry Regiments on

operations by providing skilled reconnaissance soldiers.



Originally raised as the Nottinghamshire Yeomanry Cavalry in 1794, the Regiment was used on several occasions in the 19th Century

to maintain law and order. Since 1900, the Regiment has seen overseas service during the Second Boer War and both World Wars,

earning 44 battle honours during these campaigns.

name: Care of Police Survivors (COPS)
description: No description on CI

name: Co-op Celebration of Life Grove
description:
Supported by the Midlands Co-operative Society, the grove is a large semi-circular planting of mixed spring-flowering blossom trees

individually dedicated as a celebration of the life of family members and friends who have passed away.

name: Fleet Air Arm VCs
description:
This is a group of 4 trees. It is not a memorial.



Tree



World War 1

o Flight Sub Lieutenant Reginald Warneford VC, RN 19-360

o Flight Lieutenant (later Vice Admiral) Richard Bell Davies VC, CB, DSO, AFC, RN

World War 2



o Lieutenant Commander Eugene Kingsmill Esmonde VC, DSO, RN 19-362

o Lieutenant Robert Hampton Gray VC, DSC, RCNVR* 19-363

name: The Far East Prisoners of War (FEPOW) Grove
description:
The Far East Prisoners of War (FEPOW) Grove is approached through the Changi Lych Gate, originally constructed at the POW Cemetery

in Singapore.



On its right is the memorial of the National Federation of FEPOW Clubs and Associations who were amongst the first to make a donation

to the Arboretum. On its left is a map of the Japanese Empire six months after the outbreak of war in the Far East.



Half of the approximately 50,000 British servicemen captured by the Japanese in the Second World War were forced to work on the

Burma/Thai Railway.



Other FEPOWs worked building airfields and roads, and many were transported to Japan to work in mines, shipbuilding yards and

other heavy industries. Approximately 800 British POWs were amongst those who built a railway in Sumatra.



Most of the trees in the Grove are dedicated to individual FEPOWs from all three services and to internees.



Other trees relate to groups of FEPOWs and four of these are worthy of special mention:



The estimated 1,000 UK FEPOWs who died in North Borneo, principally on the “Death Marches”.



The estimated 600 UK FEPOWs transported from Singapore who died in or near the Solomon Islands.



All FEPOWs lost at sea while being transported.



The civilian and military women and children who perished.

name: Brotherhood of Greek Veterans Chapel
description:
The Brotherhood exists to ensure that the Greek Campaign of the Second World War and the men who were left behind are not

forgotten.



The impressive Greek stone and marble altar in this outdoor chapel symbolises the strength of this Brotherhood that was established

in April 1991 commemorating the 50th Anniversary of the surrender of The Allied Forces at Kalamata, the Peloponnese in Southern

Greece.



Ten thousand men were captured and became Prisoners of War (POWs), enduring massive hardship and terrifying trials until

Liberation. The horrors of war and incarceration created a band of spirited and brave young men whose camaraderie and resilience

survives even to this day.



A plaque located beneath the altar states “In memory of all those who took part in the Greek campaigns 1940-1945. They will be

remembered”.



Within the memorial area there is a small memorial to three ships sunk with heavy casualties while evacuating British troops from

Greece - SS Slamat, HMS Diamond & HMS Wryneck.

name: Iraq and Afghanistan Willows
description:
Included as part of the Camp Bastion Memorial is a curved line of weeping willow trees along the edge of the nearby Darbyshire Ditch

which connects this memorial with the Basra Wall. They are dedicated to individual service personnel who were killed in Afghanistan

and Iraq.

name: L Cpl Kevin “Dinger” Bell REME
description:
A small memorial to the right of the nearby Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers (REME) Memorial remembers Lance Corporal

Kevin ‘Dinger’ Bell from REME who was killed in Bosnia. It originally marked the spot in Bosnia where he died but was brought back to

the United Kingdom when troops pulled out.

name: Institute of Quarrying Garden
description:
The Institute of Quarrying exists to support people working in the mineral extractive and related industries through membership and

training services.



To celebrate its centenary in 2017, The Institute of Quarrying created an award-winning show garden at the inaugural RHS Chatsworth

Flower Show. The Quarry Garden, designed by award winning garden designer Paul Hervey-Brookes, shows the contribution of the

quarrying industry in creating the products we use in everyday life through to the diverse habitats they create for plants and animals.



The Quarry Garden has been re-created at the National Memorial Arboretum for everyone to enjoy. It is an expression of nature and

hand-crafted stone, blended with mass produced products manufactured from extracted materials. It is a garden experience that

celebrates modern architecture, natural planting and sculptural elements.



Comprised of a paved avenue, adjacent to Gifford Avenue, which links the Remembrance Centre and the Far East Zone, the garden

features a series of six large, sculpted panels of corten steel (designed by Ann-Margreth Bohl) from the original installation at

Chatsworth. Entitled Passing Light the panels are reflective of the quarry face. Each one contains apertures through which light passes

to reveal lengthening shadows and views across the landscape.



Three rectangular columns stand at the garden’s entrance - each inscribed with the Institute of Quarrying's Latin motto: Terram autem

filiis hominum meaning the fruits of the earth for the children of men – (a sentiment loosely associated with Psalm 115 v16) which

provides the inspiration behind the garden.



The Quarry Garden is completed with landscaped areas of planting and seating accompanied by a panel displaying the Institute of

Quarrying's Coat of Arms together with a stone sculpture.

name: Ladysmith Memorial
description:
The Ladysmith Memorial was commissioned on 21 October 2012 and is dedicated to all “Field Gunners” from the Boer War through

to the present day.



Ladysmith, South Africa, 15 October 1899 - under heavy fire, General Sir George White defending the town of Ladysmith, requested a

few guns in support from the Naval contingent in Simonstown. The request found Captain Percy Scott RN in Simons Bay. His crew had,

in 24 hours, prepared two 4.7-inch guns and four 12-pounders for land warfare. Under the command of Captain Hedworth Lambton

RN, the Naval Brigade set out over land for Ladysmith. Crews from HMS Powerful and HMS terrible were formed for this task.



After oxen failed to haul the guns across the rough terrain, only one option was left. The Naval Brigade (Bluejackets) had to haul the

guns by muscle power themselves and still managed to arrive within 48 hours. Soon after their arrival at Ladysmith the siege of 119

days began. More men from the ships set out with more guns of both 4.7” and 12-pounders with a six in monster called “ROMA”.



The Determination, Teamwork and Dedication of the Bluejackets captured the public’s hearts back home and, on the ships, return the

Naval Brigades were to be paraded. This was so popular that the following year a tournament was staged at the 1900 Military

Tournament at the Royal Agricultural Hall in Islington, London. The Field Gun Competition was born.



Later the Royal Tournament moved to Olympia and then to Earl’s Court. Earl’s Court became the home to the Command Field Gun

Competition with crews from the ports of Chatham (CHATS), Devonport (GUZZ), Portsmouth (POMPEY) and Fleet Air Arm (Air), who

joined much later in 1947. In 1919 a set of rules was agreed and has fundamentally remained the same until the demise in 1999.

name: Lichfield Wood
description:
The mix of native trees in the City of Lichfield Wood includes species relating to districts of the city such as The Cherry Orchard. Many

of the trees have been sponsored by local groups and individuals associated with the Lichfield District area.

name: The Green Howards Memorial Stone
description:
The Concept



The Green Howards (Alexandra, Princess of Wales’s Own Yorkshire Regiment) was a British Army Infantry Regiment raised in 1688 by

Colonel Francis Luttrell at Dunster Castle. It was based in Richmond, North Yorkshire and amalgamated for the first and only time in

2006 to form part of The Yorkshire Regiment.



The Green Howards has a vibrant Association with branches spread over North Yorkshire and Teesside and others as far away as

London and Kent.



Although The Green Howards is well served with memorials honouring its fallen up to 1945, particularly at its home in Richmond and

at Crépon in Normandy, there was nothing in stone, other than The Armed Forces Memorial, where all those who died whilst serving

on duty or were killed in action after 1945 are honoured.



An application was lodged with the NMA on 8th January 2019 to place an appropriate and proportionate stone dedicated to those

Green Howards named on the Armed Forces Memorial. It was further deemed appropriate to commemorate all those who have served

with the Regiment from the time of its raising.



The Design Team



Major Michael Pickard, a retired Green Howard, was invited to design the stone in June 2018. He was assisted by Colonel Clive Mantell

and Major Tony Warriner, the Chairman and Secretary of the Green Howards Association. It was designed, quarried, carved and

erected in time for a dedication service on the 165th anniversary of the Battle of the Alma on the 19th September 2019.



The Design



The stone is a waisted, square section, silver/grey granite column, approx. 6 feet 4 inches high, in three parts set on a stone paved

base.The top part is a solid hand-carved Norwegian King’s Crown with polished extremities and honed on the inner surfaces.



The middle part is a plain polished truncated pyramidal form resting on four lower tapered faces.



On one face of the stone the lineage displayed creates a permanent and lasting record of the 318 years of its history above a dedication

to all those who have served with the Regiment.



On the opposite face is a record of countries where the Regiment has served since 1945 above a dedication to the proud memory of

those Green Howards killed in action or on duty and honoured on the Armed Forces Memorial.



Everything on the stone is significant and interlinked:



The two badges (one from the first half of the 20th c and the other from the second half) show the cipher of HRH Alexandra, Princess

of Wales, interlaced with the Dannebrog, surmounted by a princess’s coronet and the date 1875 when the Regiment was designated

‘The Princess of Wales’s Own’ (Thus starting the close connection with the Royal Houses of the Kingdoms of Denmark and Norway).



The crown at the top recognises the Kings of Norway who were Colonels-in-Chief from 1914 to 2006.



The Battle of the Alma, the principal battle honour, celebrated every year on, or near, the dedication day is included to emphasise

the importance of this anniversary to the Regiment: 19th September 2019.



The 19th Regiment of Foot (XIX) features strongly because The Green Howards is one of just a handful of Line Regiments to retain its

original designated number.



Material and Construction



The silver/grey granite was quarried and cut to shape in Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India and then carved and installed by Strongs Memorials

Limited, 39 Park Road, Bloxwich, Walsall, West Midlands WS3 3SS



Project leader: Andrew Hodgson. Inscription carving: Andrew Walsh. CAD: Mark Abesamis and Robin Mills.



Position



The stone is positioned 100 metres to the West of the Armed Forces Memorial and close to both the memorials of The Yorkshire

Regiment and the Prince of Wales’s Own Yorkshire Regiment.

name: British and Commonwealth Forces who died at sea as P.O.W. 1941-2
description:
This free-standing plaque (DQ-0000-00103) is to be found in the Mediterranean Campaigns Area between the Italy and Sicily areas.

Technically this is not a memorial but a free-standing plaque.



Six Italian ships carrying British and Commonwealth Prisoners of War were sunk in the Mediterranean Sea by British submarines during

1941 and 1942. Over 2000 POWs died. The difficulty that submarine commanders faced was that the ships did not carry any markings

indicating that they were carrying POWs and it was impossible to distinguish them from those carrying Italian troops or war supplies.



Jason aka Jantzen or Sebastiano Venier (6310 tons) was torpedoed by HM Submarine Porpoise (commanded by Lt Co Edward Fowle

Pizey DSO) on 9th December 1941. The Ship was beached near Point Methoni in Greece where the survivors were rounded up and

taken to POW Camps. 320 Allied POWs were killed.



HMS Porpoise was sunk in the Malacca Straits in January 1945.



Ariosto (4170 tons), on route from Tripoli to Sicily, was sunk by HM Submarine P38 (commanded by Lt J R Hemmingway DSC) on 15th

February 1942. 138 Allied POWs on board were killed; almost half of those on board.



HMS P38 was sunk shortly after this action.



Tembian was sunk by HM Submarine Upholder (commanded by Lt Co Malcolm David Wanklyn VC, DSO & 2 bars) on 27 th February

1942. 390 out of 468 Commonwealth POWs on board died



HMS Upholder was lost with all hands in April 1942.



Nino Bixio (7137 tons), carrying Allied POWs from Benghazi to Italy, was torpedoed by HMS Turbulent (commanded by Lt Co. John

Wallace Linton VC, DSO, DSC) on 17th August 1942. The ship didn’t sink and was towed to Navarino in Greece. 237 POWs were killed

of which 118 were New Zealanders.



HMS Turbulent was sunk on 12th March 1943 with the loss of all hands.



Loreto was sunk off Cape Gallo, Sicily by HM Submarine Unruffled (P46, commanded by Lt John Samuel Stevens DSO, DSC) on 13th

October 1942. 130 Allied POWs were killed.



HMS Unruffled survived the war.



Scillin (1600 tons) was sunk, 10 miles off Cape Milazzo by HM Submarine Sahib (P212, commanded by Lt John Henry Bromage DSO,

DSC) on 14th November 1942. The Scillin had on board 814 Allied POWs on route from Tripoli in Libya to Italy. After the attack the Sahib

rescued 27 allied POWs and 35 Italian crew. 787 POWs were killed. It was not until 1996 that the truth of this sinking was made public.



On the 24th of April 1943, the Sahib was attacked by bombs from German Ju-88s and depth charges from the Italian corvette Gabbiano;

badly damaged, the Sahib was brought to the surface and after the crew had evacuated the ship was scuttled; Lt Bromage was awarded

a bar to his DSO for this final action of the Sahib.

name: Life Guards Memorial
description:
The Life Guards the memorial, together with the Blues and Royals Memorial, is part of the memorial to the Household Cavalry

Regiments. It was placed on site in 2016 and is dedicated to The Life Guards Regiment which was founded in 1660.



The memorial was officially dedicated on 28 September 2017 by Field Marshal The Lord Guthrie of Craigiebank GCB LVO OBE DL Colonel

of the Life Guards.



Two black polished granite stones slabs, each bearing the badge of The Life Guards and The Blues and Royals respectively mark the

entrance to the memorial garden.

name: Market Garden Grove
description:
These are the trees either side of Yeomanry Avenue near the Market Garden Memorial. They are dedicated to various Market Garden

Veterans Associations. Technically this is not a memorial.

name: Light Dragoons
description:
The Light Dragoons were formed by the amalgamation in 1992 of the 13th/18th Royal Hussars and 15th.19th Kings Royal Hussars. The

earliest of their ancestor regiments can be dated to 1715. The regiment has seen service in many campaigns including Waterloo in

1815, Crimea (including the Charge of the Light Brigade in 1854), WW1, WW2 (including the Normandy Landings in 1944) and more

recently served in Iraq and Afghanistan.



An outline of the antecedent regiments and amalgamations is shown below.



Light Dragoons 1992



o 13th/18th Royal Hussars (Queen Mary’s Own) 1922



13th Hussars 1861



Light Dragoons 1715



18th Royal Hussars (Queen Mary’s Own) 1919



18th (Queen Mary’s Own) Hussars 1910



o 18th Hussars 1858



o 15th/19th King’s Royal Hussars 1922



15th King’s Hussars



King’s Hussars 1759



19th (Queen Alexandra’s Own Royal) Hussars 1908



19th Hussars formerly 1st Bengal European Light Cavalry (H.E.I.C.) 1862



HEIC means the Honourable East India Company.

name: Lions International (Shelter No 4)
description:
The Lions is a charitable organisation dedicated to serving local, national and international communities. The memorial is a shelter

dedicated to the memory of Lions from Great Britain and Ireland in grateful thanks for their service.



Opened on 14 September 2011, by HRH The Countess of Wessex, Royal Patron of the Lions Clubs of the British Isles and a member of

Wokingham Lions Club, this shelter provides a place to reflect on how much ordinary people can do when they work together.



There are millions of volunteer Lions Clubs members around the world who are working hard to improve their local communities. They

do this by raising money for good causes, as well as supporting international campaigns, helping those less fortunate and having fun

by organising all kinds of activities.



Before their 2017 centenary, Lions Clubs everywhere adopted the message: “Where there’s a need, there’s a Lion” and took on a

challenge to serve 100 million people.



The Lions shelter also features details on memorials from the Woodland Zone including the First Gulf War 1990-1991, the Society of

Friends (Quakers) and the Merchant Navy Convoy Wood.



The featured hands-on elements include an original Second World War ship’s wheel and bell. The Memorial Stone Masons feature

includes original mason’s tools and a section of stone worked from rough hewn rock to the finished inscription.



Views of the Merchant Navy Convoy Wood are enjoyed from this shelter.

name: Mercian Wood
description: Mercian Wood is a mixed woodland of native broadleaf tree species containing individual dedications.

name: Mercian Volunteers
description:
The Mercian Volunteers Regimental Association created the Mercian Grove in 2004 with four oak saplings and a stone memorial.



It commemorates all those regular and Territorial Army (TA) soldiers who served with Mercian Volunteers and its constituent units

between 1967 and 1988.



For 21 years, its battalions were part of the British Army’s contribution to NATO during the Cold War and had a specific role in Germany.

Its direct successor is the 4th Battalion The Mercian Regiment. Private Luke Cole, one of its TA soldiers, was awarded the Military Cross

in 2007 whilst serving in Afghanistan.

name: Millennium Wood
description:
Millennium Wood is a woodland of native broadleaf tree species including oak, ash and field maple. The trees are individually

sponsored with remembrance plaques and labels.

name: Neville-Barry Grove
description:
This group of trees has a number of trees dedicated to the Neville-Barry Family and two trees associated with Commander David

Childs, the founding director of the Arboretum. This is not a memorial.

name: Northern Ireland Prison Service Memorial
description:
The memorial commemorates the 32 men and women of the Northern Ireland Prison Service who lost their lives as result of their

employment during 1942 - 2016. Many were killed off duty by shooting or by having their cars booby-trapped.



The memorial was upgraded, new names added and placed in its current position in July 2023.

name: Northern Rhodesia Police Association
description:
This memorial commemorates all who served in the Northern Rhodesia Police from 1911 to 1964 and its predecessors the

Northeastern Rhodesia Constabulary and Barotse Native Police, who suppressed the slave trade.



It particularly remembers those who died on duty in Northern Rhodesia (now Zambia) or on active service in East Africa 1914 – 1918.



The memorial consists of a black granite stone on a light grey honed granite plinth with an incised silver line map and solid gilded area

showing Northern Rhodesia.

name: Nyasaland Police
description: Interred in this memorial is a scroll containing the names of officers who served in the Nyasaland Police from 1921 – 1964.

name: PC Mandy Rayner
description:
The blue lamp, previously situated within the Police Memorial Garden, came from the police station in Hitchin in Hertfordshire and is

in memory of WPC Mandy Raynor, the youngest policewoman (18) to be killed on duty. It is now situated at the top of the Beat neat

the Aspects Building.

name: Play Area
description: A second children’s play area is located in the Children’s Wood in the Woodland Zone.

name: Police Service of Northern Ireland: PSNI
description:
The memorial displays the badge of the Police Service of Northern Ireland above an inscription which commemorates all those who

lost their lives in service of the people of Northern Ireland.

name: Prince of Wales Own Regiment of Yorkshire
description:
The Prince of Wales's Own Regiment of Yorkshire was formed on 25 April 1958 following the amalgamation of The West Yorkshire

Regiment (The Prince Of Wales's Own) and The East Yorkshire Regiment (The Duke of York’s Own); these in turn date back to 1685

when they were the 14th and 15th Regiments of Foot. When several regiments were amalgamated in June 2006 the Regiment became

the 1st Battalion of the Yorkshire Regiment whose memorial is nearby. Curiously, the Regiment mascots were two ferrets named

Imphal and Quebec.



The one tonne slate memorial, located in the shadow of the Armed Forces Memorial, stands on a bed of York Stone Pavers and is

inscribed with the badges of the ancestor regiments and the following dedication:



The West and The East Regiments (14th and 15th Foot) 1685 – 2006



To understand this Regiment, understand its people: Proud to be of Yorkshire.



Determined, tough and fiercely competitive on operations, in training and in sport.



Courageous, reliable and long suffering but not complaining!



We said what we thought, meant what we said and when a job needed doing, we did it right.



Banter and humour sustained us through all adversity.



Together, we were guided by our motto and never deterred by difficulties.



Nec asperea terrent



A list of the Regiment’s 158 Battle Honours, displayed on the Regimental Colours, is inscribed on the rear of the memorial with the

Regimental Collect beneath.



The Prince of Wales's Own Regiment of Yorkshire memorial was dedicated on 29 April 2018 and attended by:



Major General EHA Beckett CB MB – The West Yorkshire Regiment (Prince of Wales’s Own) XIVth Foot



Major General HM Tillton CB CBE – The East Yorkshire Regiment (Duke of York’s Own) XVth Foot



Major General GJ Binns CBE DSO MC – The Prince of Wales’s Own Regiment of Yorkshire



Queen's Own Buffs, The Royal Kent Regiment - The Buffs (Royal East Kent Regiment), The Queen's Own

name: West Kent Regiment
description: Currently no description on collections

name: Queen’s Regiment
description:
Formed on 31 December 1966, by the amalgamation of the four county regiments of Queen’s Royal Surrey, Queen’s Own Buffs (Royal

Kent Regiment), Royal Sussex and Middlesex, The Queen’s Regiment served in numerous operations around the world.



The Regiment was later amalgamated with The Royal Hampshire Regiment to form The Princess of Wales’s Royal Regiment on 9

September 1992.



The Dedication of The Queen’s Regiment Memorial took place on 15 May 2016 and was unveiled by Captain Harrie Welmer, Defence

and Naval Attache to the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands.



The memorial is dedicated to the fallen of the Regiment.

name: RAC Future Forests
description:
Future Forests is a scheme that measures emissions of carbon dioxide, the greenhouse gas which scientists think is responsible for

global warming. The scheme helps to offset this pollution by planting natural forests and woodlands and investing in renewable energy.



The Royal Automobile Club (RAC) Future Forests wood was sponsored by the RAC as part of the Future Forests scheme and as a tribute

to their employees who have now retired.

name: Queen’s Royal Hussars
description:
The Queen’s Royal Hussars was created on 1st September 1993 by the amalgamation of the Queen’s Own Hussars and the Queen’s

Royal Irish Hussars and is part of the Royal Armoured Corps. Their history dates to 1685 with the creation of (King's Own) Dragoons

and Queen's own Dragoons. The battle honours of the antecedent regiments include Dettingham (the last battle in which a British

Monarch was present), The Peninsula War, Crimea (including Alma, Inkerman, Balaklava & Sevastopol), The Boer War, WW1 and WW2

(which included Wl Alamein). More recent deployments have included Iraq and Afghanistan.



8 soldiers from these regiments have been awarded the Victoria Cross.



Colonels in Chief of the current regiment have included Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh.



The relationships of the antecedent regiments is shown in the following diagram.



o Queen’s Own Hussars 1958



3rd (King’s Own) Light Dragoons 1818



o (King’s Own) Dragoons 1685



(Queens’s Own) Hussars 1690



o Queen’s Royal Irish Hussars 1958



4th Queen’s Own Light Dragoons 1818



o Queen’s Own Dragoons 1685



King’s Royal Irish Light Dragoons 1693

name: RAF Cranwell Apprentices
description:
A Staffordshire blue brick plinth and memorial plaque, sponsored by the Royal Air Force Cranwell Apprentices Association in 2005, is

dedicated to all aircraft apprentices who trained at Royal Air Force Cranwell from 1922 to 1952. The memorial was later upgraded with

a new facing.



Cranwell is currently the home of the Royal Air Force College. It was taken over from the Royal Navy by the RAF on its formation in

1918, for officer cadet training, a role it fulfils to this day as the world’s first air force college.

name: RAF Locking Apprentices
description:
This memorial commemorates all Apprentices who trained at RAF Locking between 1952 and 1976.
