The accommodation, messing and medical facilities were all housed in wooden huts. Training facilities were, however, mostly brickbuilt hangars. The Aircraft Apprenticeship comprised a year of basic mental and physical training followed by two years of more

specialised instruction.



The apprenticeships covered the Ground Radar, Ground Wireless and Air Radio trades. During the mid-1960s, changes were made in

the Apprentice Training system following the raising of the school leaving age from 15 to 16 and a two year apprenticeship was

introduced and called the Craft Apprenticeship.



A further scheme called Technical Apprenticeships was introduced and successful graduates passed out as Corporals with an Ordinary

National Certificate (ONC) as opposed to Junior Technicians. In 1970, a one-year course was introduced to be undertaken by Mechanic

Apprentices but apprentice training finally finished in March 1976, ending 54 years of ‘Trenchard’s Brats’.

name: Queen's Royal Lancers
description:
The Queen's Royal Lancers (known as the Death or Glory Boys) was formed in 1993 by the amalgamation of the 16th/5th Queens Royal

Lancers and the 17th/21st Lancers. The regiment can trace its lineage back to 1689 with the raising of Wynne's Regiment of Enniskillen

Dragoon. The battle honours of the antecedent regiments include the Duke of Marlborough's four victories in the War of the Spanish

Succession and the Duke of Wellington's victories in the Peninsular War, Crimea (Alma, Balaklava (Charge of the Light Brigade),

Inkerman, Sevastopol), Boer War, WW2, WW2 and the Gulf War of 1991.



The following table shows the relationship of the antecedent regiments.



o 16th/5th Queens Royal Lancers 1922



Queen’s Light Dragoons 1759



5th (Royal Irish) Lancers 1858



o 17th/21st Lancers 1922



17th Lancers 1822



o Light Dragoons 1759



21st Lancers 1897



o 21st Hussars formerly 3rd Bengal European Light Cavalry (H.E.I.C.) 1862



The H.E.I.C. is the Honourable East India Company.



NB the 5th Regiment of Dragoons were originally raised as Wynne's Regiment of Enniskillen Dragoons 1689 and disbanded in 1799:

they were reraised in 1858 as the 5th (Royal Irish) Lancers.

name: The Royal Air Force (RAF) Police
description:
The Royal Air Force (RAF) Police has supported worldwide RAF operations since 1918.



Peaking in 1945, the branch comprised 20,500 personnel and by 1948, RAF Police investigators had brought to justice the surviving

killers of 50 RAF officers who had taken part in the Great Escape.



His Majesty King George VI approved the RAF Police badge and motto in 1950 and throughout the 30 year ‘Cold War’ the branch

provided security protection for the RAF’s nuclear deterrent. Having served in 66 countries since 1918, the RAF Police are today in the

forefront of the war against terrorism, serving in current conflicts. The RAF Police Association was formed in 1984.



The RAF nickname for their police is ‘Snowdrops’ because they wear white hats, and this is reflected in the flowers engraved on the

edges of the stone.

name: Royal Air Force Wood
description:
The Royal Air Force Wood is a woodland of mixed native trees alongside the River Tame dedicated to individuals who have served in

the Royal Air Force. It includes a tree dedicated to Wing Commander Guy Gibson VC of ‘Dambusters’ fame.

name: Douglas Skene Grove
description:
Douglas Skene (1948 – 2007) was a dedicated military historian, a serving officer in the Royal Scots Greys and a member of the

Territorial Army with the Royal Green Jackets. He practiced as an independent financial consultant, but his hobby was to lead tours to

First World War battlefields.



His other great love was trees and he enjoyed watching the Arboretum develop from its inception until his untimely death at the age

of 59. Following his death, his family, friends and colleagues raised funds towards setting up the first grove of specimen trees at the

Arboretum, a lasting legacy to his memory.



Trees in the Grove include the barberry (Berberis valdivian) from Chile; the sweet buckeye (Aesculus flava) from South-East USA; the

Chinese weeping cypress (Cupressus funebris) from central China; and the Japanese white pine (Pinus parviflora).

name: Rhodesian African Rifles and Rhodesia Native Regiment Memorial
description:
Formed in May 1940 as the successor to the Rhodesia Native Regiment (RNR) the Rhodesian African Rifles (RAR) was the oldest

regiment in the Rhodesian Army.



The memorial’s design is based on the ruins of the 14th century city of Great Zimbabwe, near Masvingo in Zimbabwe, which is now a

recognised World Heritage Site.



The stone wall behind the memorial’s central column contains dedications honouring the fallen of the Rhodesia Native Regiment

during the First World War and the 311 officers and men of the Rhodesian African Rifles who fell in campaigns during and since the

Second World War.



It was unveiled on 19 July 2015 by the Marquis of Salisbury KCVO, PC, DL President of the Rhodesian African Rifles Regiment

Association.

name: Rhodesian Air Force
description:
The Rhodesian Air Force (RhAF) was an air force based in Salisbury (now Harare) which represented several entities under various

names between 1935 and 1980: originally serving the British self-governing colony of Southern Rhodesia, it was the air arm of the

Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland between 1953 and 31 December 1963; of Southern Rhodesia once again from 1 January 1964;

and of the unrecognised nation of Rhodesia following its Unilateral Declaration of Independence from Britain on 11 November 1965.



Named the Royal Rhodesian Air Force (RRAF) from 1954, the "Royal" prefix was dropped in 1970 when Rhodesia declared itself a

republic – the official abbreviation changed appropriately. When the internationally recognised country of Zimbabwe came into being

in 1980, the RhAF became the Air Force of Zimbabwe.

name: Roadpeace Memorial/ Roadpeace Wood
description:
RoadPeace is the national charity for road crash victims. The RoadPeace memorial stone was erected on August 9th 2021.



The stone has been crafted by renowned carver and artist Martin Cook who has made pieces for Westminster Abbey, the British

Museum, the Royal Family, RHS Chelsea Flower Show.



The stone was donated by England’s last working slate mine, Honister Slate Mine, based in the heart of the Lake District. The mine is

at the top of Honister Pass – one of the steepest roads in the country – and slate is sourced from deep inside a neighbouring mountain,

Fleetwith Pike.



The memorial stone is at the RoadPeace Wood, an area at the NMA where individual trees have been planted to remember those who

have lost their lives or been injured because of a road crash.



Planting of trees in the RoadPeace Wood began in spring 2001 and the wood was named after the charity on 10 August 2002.

name: Royal Air Force Wing
description:
The RAF Memorial Grove (RAF Wing) comprises a collection of silver birch trees planted in the shape of an eagle’s wings.



The wing honours both the Fighter and Bomber Commands. The trees are individually dedicated to some of the Squadrons. The central

‘three bladed propeller’ made up of dwarf golden honeysuckle plants was sponsored by the Aircrew Association.



The grove also includes the following memorials:



9 Squadron



30 Squadron



31 Squadron



101 Squadron



214 Squadron



216 Squadron



Second Tactical Air Force Memorial



Flt Lt. J. W. Lucas DFC



RAF Loadmasters’ Association



The Air Formation Squadron Crescent RAF



RAF Medical Services



Princess Mary’s RAF Nursing Service



RAF Search & Rescue



Royal Auxiliary Air Forcece



Royal Canadian Air Force

name: Royal Australian Air Force
description:
Eucalyptus trees planted in line with the lime trees of Millennium Avenue represent local associations with 463 / 467 Squadrons Royal

Australian Air Force.

name: The Royal Green Jackets Memorial
description:
The Royal Green Jackets (RGJ) memorial was dedicated on 11 May 2008. Over 1,100 gathered from the former Regiment to remember

all those who had served during the Regiment’s 41-year existence (1966 – 2007).



The memorial is of black polished Indian granite and weighs just over two tonnes. It is flanked by remembrance trees of the three

forming regiments of the RGJ (Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire Light Infantry, Kings Royal Rifle Corps and Rifle Brigade). A small

plaque is placed by the memorial commemorating the dedication event and the unveiling by Field Marshal The Lord Bramall of

Bushfield.



On the adjacent Armed Forces Memorial are the names of Service Personnel killed on duty or as a result of terrorist action since the

Second World War. Of these names 72 are RGJ Riflemen, with a further 61 names from the amalgamated regiments of the Royal Green

Jackets.

name: Royal Navy Wood
description:
The Navy Wood consists of mixed native trees individually sponsored and dedicated to those who have served in the Royal Navy and

Merchant Navy.

name: The Royal Dragoon Guards Regimental Memorial
description:
The Royal Dragoon Guards – ‘Our Castle, Our Strength and Shield’. The Royal Dragoon Guards was formed in 1992, as a result of the

amalgamation of the 4/7th Royal Dragoon Guards and the 5th Royal Inniskilling Dragoon Guards.



The two antecedent regiments were themselves the result of amalgamations in 1922. The 4th/7th Royal Dragoon Guards formed from

amalgamation of the 4th Royal Irish Dragoon Guards and the 7th (Princess Royal’s) Dragoon Guards, and the 5th Royal Inniskill ing

Dragoon Guards formed from amalgamation of the 5th (Princess Charlotte of Wales’) Dragoon Guards and the 6th (Inniskilling)

Dragoons.



All four of the original antecedent regiments were raised between 1685 and 1689, during the protracted contest for the English throne

between James II and William of Orange.



This memorial is dedicated to all those who fought, served and died while serving in The Royal Dragoon Guards and its antecedent

regiments, from 1685 to the present day. Accordingly, the memorial carries the cap badges of the regiments, together with the motto

of The Royal Dragoon Guards: Quis Separabit (who shall separate us), which is taken from the eighth chapter of St Paul’s Letter to the

Romans.



Age of Memorial



The current memorial replaces an earlier memorial installed in 2008. The trustees of the Regimental Charity, informed by both the

serving and veteran cohorts of the Regiment, agreed the original memorial failed to capture the spirit and tradition of the Regiment

and those who had served it. The current memorial was dedicated on Saturday 11 March 2023.



Symbolism



The Memorial is cut in the shape of a castle, to represent the Watergate that forms part of the ramparts of Enniskillen Castle, where

the 6th (Inniskilling) Dragoons were raised in 1689.



A device representing the Watergate was worn on the uniforms of the 6th (Inniskilling) Dragoons and later, embroidered onto their

Regimental Guidon in 1751, when the first regulations standardising regimental dress were introduced. The Watergate continued to

be worn on the uniform of the 5th Royal Inniskilling Dragoon Guards and to be carried on its Regimental Standard. Today, the

Watergate is carried on the Regimental Standard of The Royal Dragoon Guards and forms the centrepiece of the Regimental cap badge,

mounted in the centre of the Star of St Patrick, the cap badge of the 4th Royal Irish Dragoon Guards and later the 4/7th Royal Dragoon

Guards.



Green was the regimental colour worn on the facings, (collar and cuffs) of the 5th Dragoon Guards and continued in the uniform of

the 5th Royal Inniskilling Dragoon Guards. Today, that tradition continues in the colour of the Regiment’s beret, and the trousers worn

with barrack, service and ceremonial dress.



The engravings on the face of the memorial represent the cap badges of the antecedent regiments.



The 4th Royal Irish Dragoon Guards and 4/7th Royal Dragoon Guards using the Star of St Patrick: the former with a shamrock

surmounting the cross of St Patrick and the Regimental Motto, Quis Separabit, in the surrounding garter; the latter has the Princess

Royal’s coronet at its centre, surmounting the cross of St George.



The 5th (Princess Charlotte of Wales’) Dragoon Guards has the white horse of Hannover at its centre, surrounded by the letter

V representing the Roman number 5 and the letters DG to represent Dragoon Guards. Around the garter is the Regimental motto,

Vestigia Nulla Retrorsum (Never a Rearward Step).



This also served as the motto of the 5th Royal Inniskilling Dragoon Guards, whose cap badge was a monogram of the 5th

Dragoon Guards, surmounted by the reigning monarch’s crown.



The cap badge of the 7th (Princess Royal’s) Dragoon Guards depicts a lion rampant surmounting the Princess Royal’s coronet.

The lion rampant was the family crest of Lord Ligonier, who commanded the Regiment in 1720. The Regiment was renamed the 7th

Dragoon Guards in 1788, the name carried in the scroll below the Princess Royal’s coronet.



Lastly, the Watergate of the 6th (Inniskilling) Dragoons, flying the flag of St George mounted on a scroll carrying the name

Inniskilling (the Island of Kathleen), which is the traditional Irish spelling for the town of Enniskillen.



Below the cap badges, in silver, is the Regimental Motto (Quis Separabit). This was the original motto of the Order of St Patrick, created

by King George III in 1783. This chivalrous order lasted until the partition of Ireland in 1922, although King Charles III remains the

Sovereign of the Order to this day. His Majesty King Charles III is the current Colonel in Chief of the Regiment.

name: Royal Hampshire Regiment
description:
The Royal Hampshire Regiment was formed following the amalgamation of North Hampshire Regiment (37th Foot) and South

Hampshire Regiment (67th Foot) to become the Hampshire Regiment in 1881.



It was awarded the title ‘Royal’ in 1946 for distinguished service in the Second World War.



Throughout its history the Regiment has served in the major campaigns. It was amalgamated with the Queen’s Regiment in 1992 to

form The Princess of Wales’s Royal Regiment.



After the 67th had served in India from 1805 – 1826, it was decreed that the Colours and other appointments were to bear the figure

of the Royal Tiger with the word ‘India’.



The memorial’s plinth, which was created by stone mason Nick Johnson, tells the story of the Regiment both graphically and in words.

The Bengal Tiger on top of the plinth was created by sculptor Sara Ingleby-Mackenzie.

name: Royal Leicestershire Regiment
description:
The memorial to The Royal Leicestershire Regiment was dedicated on 27 September 2014 – the 326th anniversary of the founding of

the Regiment.



The Regiment was conferred with the title ‘Royal’ by King George VI in 1946 in recognition of its services during the Second World

War, where it was represented by a battalion in every theatre: an almost unique distinction.The Regiment takes its nickname – ‘The

Tigers’ – from its badge, which incorporates a Royal Tiger and the inscription ‘Hindoostan’. The badge was awarded to the Regiment

in 1825 by King George IV, in recognition of its exemplary conduct in India.



The Royal Leicestershire Regiment was awarded a total of 73 Battle Honours including those received for service at the battle of Namur

in 1695 to the campaign in Korea in 1952. Over the years, four members of the Regiment were awarded the Victoria Cross.



The Regiment’s last operational tour was in Borneo in 1963-64, very soon after which it was incorporated into The Royal Anglian

Regiment.



The memorial comprises a large Irish Blue limestone plinth, donated by André Vrona, of Ketton Stone from near Stamford, with an

impressive tiger on the top of the plinth which was created by Theodore Gillick of Stamford.

name: Royal Regiment of Scotland
description:
The Royal Regiment of Scotland was formed in 2006 through the amalgamation of Scotland's historic infantry regiments to form a

single fighting force.



The memorial is a low-level plinth made of Scottish granite which is located by a grove of Scots pines.



The memorial commemorates all those who have served since 1945 and especially those killed or who have died in the operational

theatres in The Royal Regiment of Scotland and its Antecedent Regiments.



The Regiment’s cap badge is inscribe above the dedication and the motto, Nemo Me Impune Lacessit ("No one harasses me with

impunity" ), is inscribed in large letters on the memorial’s base. The badges of all the regiments listed in the dedication are depicted

on individual paviours around the memorial’s base.

name: Royal Ulster Constabulary George Cross Way/RUC GC Way
description:
The Royal Ulster Constabulary George Cross Way was designed in memory of the Royal Ulster Constabulary police officers who lost

their lives whilst protecting life and property, preventing and detecting crime and keeping the community safe in Northern Ireland

from 1922 to 2001.



The Way is lined with planting and 38 individual stones representing the Sub-Divisional policing areas of the Province in which the

officers worked and were killed or injured while carrying out their duties.



The Mourne Black Granite Stone, in the centre of the Way, with the RUC and George Cross crests inscribed, acknowledges the

outstanding dedication and commitment these officers gave whilst upholding law and order in Northern Ireland.

name: Royal Scots Dragoon Guards Memorial
description:
The Royal Scots Dragoon Guards Memorial honours those members of the Regiment and its antecedent regiments who have fallen in

service of their country, and all those who served in the regiments. The regiments are:



3rd Dragoon Guards (Prince of Wales’s)



The Carabiniers (6th Dragoon Guards)



3rd Carabiniers (Prince of Wales’s Dragoon Guards)



The Royal Scots Greys (2nd Dragoons)



25th Dragoons



The Royal Scots Dragoon Guards (Carabiniers and Greys)



The memorial is based on a large Himalayan Blue stone which was quarried in Aberdeenshire. It has an inscription and badges of all

the regiments engraved on a black granite tablet.



Age of memorial - The memorial was made in 2019 and unveiled on 13 April 2019 by Lieutenant General Sir Norman Arthur KCB CVO.

name: SAS Bravo Two Zero
description: A feature in the Allied Special Forces Grove with a plaque.

name: Second Tactical Air Force
description:
The memorial is dedicated to all who served with 137 and 139 Wings RAF 2nd T.A.F. / B.A.F.O (2nd Tactical Air Force / British Air Force

of Operation).



The memorial is located within the RAF Memorial Grove near Millennium Avenue.

name: Special Constabulary Memorial
description:
This memorial recognises the dedication to duty by members of the Special Constabulary who protect and serve their communities,

and to commemorate those Specials who have died in service to their country.



The Special Constabulary is the part-time volunteer section of the Police force in the United Kingdom. They were redefined during the

First World War, where they were instructed to safeguard water supplies from German infiltrators. During the Second World War,

besides their normal duties, they were trained to deal with a range of eventualities such as first aid in case of injury, initial coordination

of the security of aircraft crash sites, clearing people from the vicinity of unexploded bombs, handling of unignited incendiary bombs

and checking compliance with lighting regulations.



The memorial was kindly donated by the people of the communities of the West Midlands.

name: Trefoil Guild Memorial
description:
The Trefoil Guild was formed in 1943 and is part of the Guiding Association. The memorial gives a brief history



of the organisation and is accompanied by a copper beech (Fagus sylvatica f. purpurea) which is dedicated to the women and men

who serve their communities and help Guiding and Scouting thrive across the United Kingdom.

name: The Western Front Association Grove
description:
All the hornbeam trees in the Western Front Association Grove were grown from the only tree left standing in Delville Wood after the

Battle of the Somme. Each tree has been dedicated by the Birmingham branch of the WFA.



The Western Front Association Grove compliments the nearby Western Front Association Memorial which is dedicated to 956,703

British Empire men and women who died in the First World War. The stone memorial is inscribed with words from Binyon’s poem,

‘For the Fallen’ and Sassoon’s poem, ‘Aftermath’. The Western Front Association (WFA) is an historical interest group established in

1980 by noted military historian John Giles and has a worldwide membership of over 6,500. The WFA supports many remembrance

and research projects, including the renovation of battlefield memorials.

name: Ulster Ash Grove Memorial
description:
The Ulster Grove memorial, made of Mourne granite, is in grateful memory of the men and women of the Royal Ulster Constabulary

GC, the Armed Forces and other originations in service of the Crown who laid down their lives in the cause of peace in Northern Ireland

1969-2001. It was dedicated on 23 September 2003, the anniversary of the death of the first soldier in 1969.



At the beginning of the UlsterAsh Grove is a stone circle reflecting the geography and geology of Northern Ireland. There is one block

of stone from each county: Londonderry, Tyrone, Armagh, Antrim, Fermanagh, Down. They are laid out to form a symbolic map of

Northern Ireland and enclose a simple granite pillar with a dedication to those involved and they form a tranquil place where people

can rest and remember those who lost their lives.



The lives of all soldiers (British and UDR) are commemorated by ash trees, one for each soldier killed in action. The ash was chosen

because of the Irish song ‘Down by the Ash Grove’. The memorial trees are dedicated by Regiment and then by date of death. The

Ulster Ash Grove was dedicated on the anniversary of the death of the first soldier in 1969.



The Ulster Defence Regiment became operational on 1 April 1970 to support the Regular Army and the Royal Ulster Constabulary in

protecting the people of Northern Ireland against sabotage and armed attack. Both men and women originally served part-time but

as responsibilities increased nearly half became full-time. 193 men and 4 women were killed on operations, in their homes or

workplace. Another 63 were also killed by terrorist action. The UDR merged with the Royal Irish Rangers to form the Royal Irish

Regiment on 1st July 1992. In October, the Queen awarded those who had served with the Ulster Defence Regiment and Home Service

Battalions of the Irish Regiment with the unique collective award of The Conspicuous Gallantry Cross. There is an avenue of trees and

a pavement of dedicated granite paviours remembering each of those who died.



The Royal Ulster Constabulary worked to protect life and property, prevent and detect crime, and keep communities safe from 1922

to 2001. While endeavouring to keep the fabric of society together against ruthless Irish terrorists 312 officers lost their lives and over

10,000 were seriously injured. Queen Elizabeth II awarded the RUC the George Cross for their gallantry and courage in trying to keep

the peace in Northern Ireland. The memorial to the RUC is the RUC George Cross Way which has granite paviours identifying each of

the 38 Sub-divisional policing areas in Northern Ireland with an Irish Juniper tree planted behind each one. Halfway along the RUC

George Cross way is a black granite memorial stone from Mourne with the RUC and George Cross crests inscribed.

name: War Widows Association Memorial
description:
The War Widows Memorial is located at the front of the War Widows Wood. It includes the emblem of the War Widows Association

of Great Britain and a dedication to those who died in service of their country.



The woodland is a mixture of individually dedicated native trees sponsored by war widows in memory of their husbands who never

returned from conflict.



The War Widows Association of Great Britain was founded in 1971. It campaigns to improve conditions for War Widows, War

Widowers, partners and dependants who lost their lives serving in the Armed Forces.

name: War Widows Wood
description:
The War Widows Wood is a mixture of individually dedicated native trees sponsored by war widows in memory of their husbands who

never returned from conflict.

name: The Women’s Royal Army Corps – WRAC
description:
The Women’s Royal Army Corps (WRAC) and its predecessors, the Women’s Army Auxiliary Corps, Queen Mary’s Army Auxiliary Corps

and the Auxiliary Territorial Service, are remembered here.



The front of the grove is based on the letter ‘W’ for women and behind is a more open area for seating and contemplation. The trees

and shrubs planted were specially selected for their grace and elegance and also with three themes in mind: the bottle green of the

WRAC uniform, the Corps Air “The Nut Brown Maid” and the connection with women’s names.



Between 1917 and 1992, nearly half a million women joined the corps, serving in every continent in over 35 trades with more than

1,200 dying in service.



Between 1990 and 1992 members of Corps became members of the Regiment or Corps to which they had been attached. The WRAC

was disbanded in 1992.

name: 3 (Fighter) Squadron RAF; 3 Squadron RAF
description:
The No. 3 Fighter Squadron Memorial honours the courage and sacrifice of those who have given their lives to the defence of the UK

through two World Wars, subsequent world conflicts, the ‘Cold War’ and general air operations.



Squadron History



In the Beginning



Following the issue of a Special Army Order, dated 28th February 1911, the Air Battalion of the Royal Engineers was formed on 1st

April 1911, comprising No.1 (Airship) Company and No.2 (Aeroplane) Company. The creation of No.2 Company, stationed at Larkhill,

marked the first formation of a British military unit composed of heavier-than-air flying machines. No.2 Company continued flying

training including participation in the Army’s Autumn (1911) manoeuvres.



The Royal Flying Corps



The Royal Flying Corps (RFC) was formed on 13 May 1912 by absorbing the Air Battalion’s No.1 and No.2 Companies, with No.2

Company being renamed No.3 Squadron (Military Wing) RFC. On the outbreak of World War 1 the Squadron deployed to France as

part of the British Expeditionary Force (BEF) in August 1914 on reconnaissance, photography and artillery spotting duties. In October

1917 Sopwith Camels were received, and the Squadron became a fighter / scout unit. After the Armistice, the Squadron was reduced to

cadre strength until re-established at Ambala (India) from January 1920 to September 1921.



The Biplane Era



After returning to UK the Squadron spent the 1920s on many short periods at various locations before arriving at Upavon in 1924 with

Sopwith Snipes. During their ten-year stay, the Squadron flew Woodcocks, Gamecocks and Bulldogs. The Bulldog was deployed to

Sudan during the Abyssinian crisis in 1935. Upon its return from Sudan, No. 3 Squadron introduced the Gladiator into the RAF which

became the last biplane operated by the Squadron and as the Second World War started converted to the Hurricane at Biggin Hill.



World War 2



A brief period with the BEF in France was followed by relocation to Scotland on night-patrol duties. During 1943, the Squadron replaced

the Hurricanes with Typhoons and switched to the anti-shipping and intruder roles. After re-equipping with Tempests in 1944, the

Squadron destroyed 288 V1 flying bombs, and following D-Day in 1944 moved on to the Continent as part of the advance towards

Germany.



The Jet Era



The Squadron remained in Germany, converting successively to the Vampire in 1948, the Sabre in 1953 and the Hunter in 1956. After

disbanding (1957 –1959) a brief time with Javelin fighters was followed by an extended period of Canberra B(I)8 operations, before the

Squadron converted to the Harrier early in 1972 at Wildenrath. In 1977 the unit moved to Gutersloh near the old East German border,

before relocating to Laarbruch with the Harrier GR7.



Following the closure of RAF Laarbruch, the Squadron returned to the UK in 1999, to RAF Cottesmore. Subsequently, No. 3 Squadron,

along with its sister RAF Harrier and Royal Navy Sea Harrier units, combined to form Joint Force Harrier and undertook several

deployments including on-board HMS Illustrious during operations in Sierra Leone. The Harrier aircraft of No 3 Squadron also saw

action in Kosovo, Bosnia-Herzegovina and both of the Iraq conflicts.



Farewell to the Harrier



On the 31 March 2006, the Squadron relinquished its Harrier role and moved to RAF Coningsby becoming the third RAF, and first

front-line Squadron to be equipped with the Eurofighter Typhoon. The Squadron’s Typhoons continue to contribute to the RAF’s ongoing commitments in Iraq & Syria plus participating in the Falkland Islands detachments and QRA (Quick Reaction Alert) to the

present day.



The date of dedication is May 12th 2023, a date which closely commemorates the 111th Anniversary of the Squadron’s inclusion in the

Royal Flying Corps in 1912.



Symbolism



There are two faces to the memorial, the aspect facing the Armed Forces Memorial carries the Squadron’s battle honours, while the

other side records the time line of its origin in 1911 and its status as recorded in official Air Ministry records. Both aspects carry the

Squadron badge with the inscription ‘Tertius Primus Erit’ – The Third Will Be First. The central image is of a cockatrice mounted on a

monolith, said to represent a fallen stone from Stonehenge. A cockatrice is a mythical beast that is hatched by a serpent from an egg laid

by a rooster, and reputedly able to kill at a glance. The frontal aspect carries two smaller badges, one representing the first location of

Larkhill on Salisbury Palin in 1912. Again, the stones symbolise the Squadron’s location of nearby Stonehenge. The second badge is

carried on the Typhoon FGR4, which commenced operations in 2006.

name: Amelanchier Walk
description:
Approximately 100 Amelanchier trees flank a Breedon gravel path with the species primed to inject colourful blossom into the 150-acre

site’s landscape during the early spring months. Commonly known as the ‘Serviceberry’, the trees naturally complement the Arboretum’s

more than 400 memorials dedicated to members of the Armed Forces, emergency services and community groups who have served our

country. It is hoped that the saplings will be recognised as one of the UK’s national collections of the species.



Barratt Developments has funded the creation of a new tree-lined walkway, improving accessibility for visitors and enhancing

biodiversity at the Nation’s year-round place to remember. The Amelanchier were propagated and supplied by Chris Lane, owner of the

Witch Hazel Nursery in Sittingbourne, Kent.



Amelanchier Walk is a fantastic addition to the Arboretum, improving accessibility for visitors while injecting seasonal colour and

enhancing biodiversity by expanding the variety of tree species across our site.

name: Auxiliary Territorial Service Statue
description:
The life-size statue of an Auxiliary Territorial Service (ATS) woman wearing basic khaki uniform was sponsored by the Auxiliary

Territorial Service as a tribute to its members who played an important role in the Second World War from 1939 to 1945.



Initially, made up of volunteers who undertook six weeks of basic training, the ATS was formed in September 1938. By December 1939

there were 23,900 women aged between 19 and 23 years old in the service, peaking in 1943 at 212,500.



On 1 February 1949, the ATS was disbanded and the Women’s Royal Army Corps (WRAC) was formed. During hostilities, 335

members of the ATS were killed, 94 reported missing, 302 wounded and 20 became Prisoners of War.



The statue is the work of Birmingham sculptor Andy De Comyn who used his wife Francesca as the model. It consists of a cementitious

render over a reinforced concrete core. The appearance is similar to limestone and is designed to withstand weathering and acid rain.

name: Blind Veterans UK (St Dunstan's) Pathway
description:
Blind Veterans UK supports anyone who has served in the Armed Forces, or who has done National Service, and who is now living

with significant sight loss. The scented pathway is lined with all-year round fragrant shrubs.

name: Boyes Garden
description:
This attractive garden with its winding path, its arches of Carpinus Betulus and water feature was funded by the G & K Charitable Trust

when the new Visitor Centre was built in 2016. Trees, shrubs and plants found in the garden include Betula Utilis ’Jacqmontii’,

Amelanchier Lamarckii, Cornus Sanguinea ‘Midwinter Fire’, Echinacea Purpurea ‘Magnus’, Echinops Rito ‘Vetch’s Blue’,

Leucanthemum Vulgare ‘Snow Lady’. The path through the garden is the principle route from Heroes Square out on to our site.



The purpose of the G & K Boyes Trust is to promote, advance and support by way of grants to charities, charitable organisations,

charitable purposes and charitable causes with a focus on (but not limited to) education, training, advancement of health or saving lives,

arts, culture, heritage, science, environment and conservation.

name: Fellowship of the Services Memorial
description:
In this peaceful setting alongside the River Tame, 114 trees have been planted as a living tribute to the Fellowship of the Services and

to keep alive the memory of the individual Messes who have sponsored the grove.



The Fellowship is a ‘Brotherhood’ of ex-servicemen, drawn from all ranks of Her Majesty’s Armed Forces, who developed a spirit of

shared comradeship whilst serving in in the First and Second World Wars.



The majority are officers and men who served in these wars and carry on a Service Brotherhood, an association created out of the

unforgettable experiences of the First World War.

name: Fleet Air Arm British Pacific and East Indies Fleets Aircrew Memorial
description:
The memorial remembers the Aircrew members of the British Pacific and East Indies Fleets operating from H.M, Aircraft carriers who

lost their lives during air attacks on enemy held territory or were captured and subsequently executed.



Also remembered on the memorial are “comrades-in-arms of allied services including the United States Army twentieth Air Force who

lost their lives in similar circumstance in Southeast Asia and the Pacific 1942-1945”.

name: HMS Nairana & 835 Royal Naval Air Squadron Memorial Grove
description:
The memorial comprises eight oak trees located in a corner of the Royal Naval Review adjacent the Merchant Navy Wood.



The symbolism of Memorial



8 Oak trees were used one representing the squadron and one for each of 7 airmen who made the ultimate sacrifice. They form a small

grove, shaped as a triangle. The Oak trees symbolise the pilots o Hearts of Oak.



The reason for establishing the memorial



On 14th May 2004 the surviving WW2 members of the squadron, then all in their eighties, assembled at the National Memorial

Arboretum with family members and friends to commemorate all the officers and men who served in 835 RNAS in World War II. Those

present particularly related to service spent aboard the aircraft carrier HMS Nairana. They especially met to remember their seven

colleagues who made the ultimate sacrifice when serving aboard HMS Nairana.



Squadron History



The squadron was commissioned in February 1942 as a convoy protection squadron equipped with 4 Swordfish aircraft. Subsequently

the squadron served for short periods aboard H.M. Ships Furious, Activity, Battler, Chaser and Argus, all aircraft carriers, and during

the period May 1942 to November 1943 was moved from place to place no fewer than 16 times.



In 1943 the squadron was equipped with 12 Swordfish and 6 Sea Hurricane aircraft and on 31st December that year it embarked on

board HMS Nairana, which was to be its parent ship until decommissioning at the end of March 1945. During this period the squadron

helped to protect 19 convoys from which only one merchantman (a straggler) was lost. Those who came to the dedication Service at the

Arboretum were mainly associated with those who served and died whilst attached to the aircraft carrier, HMS Nairana.



Initially, the squadron that served aboard the Nairana was used to protect Gibraltar convoys and on anti U-boat operations in the Atlantic

but after the fighter flight was re-equipped with 6 Wildcat aircraft in September 1944, she was transferred the next month to escorting

convoys to Russia and to operations against German shipping in the Norwegian fjords.



German U-boats were only dangerous at periscope level from where they could identify and attack their targets. The primary duty of

Swordfish was therefore to patrol the convoy and to attack with depth-charges or other weapons, any U-boats that became visible at

periscope level. Although such Swordfish attacks were minimal, their constant patrolling, both night and day and in all weathers, kept

the U-boats submerged for long periods.



When convoys, of necessity, sailed close to enemy coastlines they risked attack by land-based enemy aircraft. In such situations it was

the turn of the Sea Hurricanes and the Wildcat aircraft from the Nairana, and any of the other carriers, to defend the convoy.



The Nairana, a converted cargo ship, had a flight deck of just 495 feet long and 60 feet wide and a maximum speed of 17 knots. A former

Squadron Commander would eventually write a book about the squadron when serving on the Nairana in Arctic conditions. In one

passage he referred to the airmen’s ability “to land and take off from such a small ‘moving runway’ in 70 mph gales, with ship tossing,

corkscrewing and rolling sometimes at 100 degrees.” This is beyond belief. The aircrew did this hundreds of times, often on a snowcovered deck and in virtual darkness. At the same time, the ship and those in flight, were constantly at risk of attack from the enemy.



The seven aircrew who made the ultimate sacrifice:



Tony Costello, Jack Dalton and George Field took off in their Swordfish from HMS Nairana in bad weather to make a regular patrol of

the convoy. Sadly, they were never seen or heard of again.



Lou Wilmot and George Ferguson were both killed when their Swordfish crash-landed on the Nairana in bad weather and then fell into

the sea.



Charles Richardson, flying a Sea Hurricane from HMS Nairana, was shot down and killed when he engaged a 4 engine German JU290

that was attacking the convoy.



Dusty Miller, flying a Wildcat from HMS Nariana, seemingly despatched a Junker 88 before being shot down and killed himself whilst

engaging several enemy aircraft that were attacking the convoy.

name: Nigeria Police
description: There is no information in Collections

name: Heroes' Square
description:
Adjacent to the Remembrance Centre is Heroes’ Square, a cloistered courtyard, which provides a welcoming area to gather for events,

relax with friends and to look at the breath-taking vistas across the Arboretum.



Within Heroes’ Square are many crests, badges or cyphers which have been elegantly carved into the York Stone paviours, a material

chosen for its visual appeal and hard-wearing qualities.



The red oaks, providing a natural canopy above them, have been selected for their beautiful red foliage during the autumn, the season of

Remembrance.

name: Mesothelioma UK - Supporting our Armed Forces – Memorial
description:
In memory of members of the UK armed forces who have been diagnosed with the asbestos-related cancer, mesothelioma.



Mesothelioma is a cancer caused by asbestos that affects around 2,700 people in the UK each year. A number of those diagnosed are, or

were, serving members of the Armed Forces. As part of a Government-funded project, national charity, Mesothelioma UK supported

research into the effects of mesothelioma within our armed forces. Findings from the research informed the development of the charity’s

UK-wide specialist service for armed forces personnel and veterans who have been affected by mesothelioma.



As part of the project, the charity wanted to create a memorial to honour those who have lost their lives to the disease or are living with

it. The memorial depicts building blocks of life, engraved with information about mesothelioma, asbestos and our Armed Forces.



Materials Used



Ancaster Weatherbed limestone



Name of Designers



Graeme Mitcheson M.M.R.S.



Age of Memorial



The construction began in spring 2023. A dedication ceremony is due to be held in October 2023.



Symbolism and meaning



The building blocks of life are represented by solid blocks of carved stone, constructed in a format not dissimilar to the game Jenga. The

sculpture shows that even though the tower of blocks has been damaged in the middle, it is strongly supported above and below. This

represents the aims of the charity.



In addition to the tall tower of blocks. Each face will have carved across the surface of the stone, an inscription that describes both the

aims of Mesothelioma UK and details of the disease. Some of the sections are slightly jumbled as the blocks have collapsed. The

inscriptions are designed in such a way that the viewer is compelled to study the jumbled words and to try to rearrange the sentences in

their heads, all the time learning a little about the charity and about mesothelioma.



The Memorial has been created to allow families and friends of those affected to be able to visit the memorial and pay their respects or

celebrate a key milestone.

name: Queen Alexandra's Royal Navy Nursing Service and the Voluntary Aid Detachment Memorial
description:
At the corner of the Merchant Navy Convoy and the Ulster Ash Grove, a blue pearl granite tablet is dedicated to all who served, and

continue to serve, in the Queen Alexandra’s Royal Naval Nursing Service (QARNNS).



Matching curved benches are flanked each side by a rowan tree, known as the ‘healing’ tree. Its berries are used for medicinal purposes

and its wood was used to make handles for stretchers during the First World War.

name: Royal Observer Corps Seaborne Wing
description: There is no information in Collections

name: Royal Army Pay Corps
description:
RAPC Memorial - Fide Et Fiducia (In Faith and Confidence)



In celebration of the service given by those who wore the Royal Army Pay Corps or any of the antecedent cap badges ensuring their part

in history is recorded for future generations. It is not primarily a memorial to those who made the ultimate sacrifice, although it serves

that purpose as well, but it embraces everyone who served in the Corps. It is a project of regimental significance, supported by generous

donations from our membership.



Materials Used



The plinth is made of Cumbrian Sandstone. The two books of regulation which surmount it are Forest of Dean sandstone. The plinth

dimensions are 1300mm (l) x 800mm (w) x 1850mm (h) with a 300mm granite apron surrounding the monument.



The lion was cast in bronze in Birmingham and then nickel plated.



Name of Designers



Nick Johnson – Master Monument Mason.



Andy DeComyn – Sculptor.



Age of Memorial



In 2022, Nick Johnson (Master Monument Mason) and Andy DeComyn (Sculptor) were appointed by the Trustees of the RAPC

Regimental Association, with ground broken on site a year later. The dedication ceremony was held on 14th June 2023.



Symbolism



The memorial shows a lion standing atop the two most commonly-used books of reference for the RAPC - the Regulations for Army

Allowances and Charges and the Manual of Army Pay Duties. The lion is guarding a bag of coin, which lies open between its front

paws.



This represents the RAPC’s twin roles; it was both the Army’s guardian of the public purse, ensuring that monies were properly disbursed

and correctly accounted for, but also the soldier’s guarantor of receiving fair, accurate and timely pay and allowances – not things that

could be taken for granted in previous ages.



The plinth is carved with the four cap badges that make up our formal antecedence, although the role itself dates back many centuries:



The Army Pay Department



The Army Pay Corps



The Corps of Military Accountants



The Royal Army Pay Corps (prior to being granted the regimental motto Fide Et Fiducia)



The RAPC Memorial features prominently on the Army Parade next to the Beat. It offers those who served in the RAPC a place to

contemplate their service and to remember old comrades – the RAPC was a widely-dispersed corps in which you served with every part

of the Army but seldom with the same RAPC friends. It also offers families a unique opportunity to go somewhere to respect the service

given by a relative who served in the RAPC. The RAPC disbanded in 1992 and its regimental homes of Devizes and later Worthy Down

have been redeveloped or re-purposed. This monument is the RAPC’s only Corps memorial.

name: Shrievalty Avenue
description:
Millennium Avenue incorporates a number of lime trees sponsored by High Sheriffs, some of whom were in office at the time of the

Millennium. All these trees were propagated from the 2,000 year-old lime tree growing at Westonbirt Arboretum in Gloucestershire.



This Millennium sponsorship by High Sheriffs was singularly appropriate given that the office of High Sheriff (or Shire Reeve) is at

least 1,000 years old, having its roots in Saxon times, well before the Norman Conquest of 1066. It is the oldest continuous secular office

under the Crown.



Originally, a High Sheriff was vested with many of the powers a Lord Lieutenant, High Court Judges and Magistrates have today. The

office of High Sheriff remained first in precedence in the counties until King Edward VII, by Order in Council in 1908, gave that primacy

to the Lord Lieutenant. The High Sheriff remains the Sovereign’s representative in a county for all matters relating to the Judiciary and

to the maintenance of law and order.



The involvement of the High Sheriffs in the Millennium Avenue underlines their service to their Sovereign and to the counties for more

than a thousand years.

name: Stick Man Sculpture
description:
A larger-than-life carved wooden figure of Stick Man by Alistair Farson. Stick Man is the leading character in the book of the same

name written by former Children's Laureate, Julia Donaldson, and illustrated by Axel Scheffler.



The book tells the story of Stick Man who becomes separated from his family home and follows his adventure as he returns home.

name: United Nations Avenue; UN
description:
This is an avenue of giant redwoods planted alongside the mainline railway bridge, which will be clearly visible from passing trains as

the trees grow. Member countries of the United Nations have sponsored the trees and plaques.

name: Yeomanry Avenue
description:
This is an avenue of 48 large and small leaved lime trees where each tree is dedicated to a Yeomanry Unit.



In the 1790s, the threat of invasion of the Kingdom of Great Britain was high after the French Revolution and the rise of Napoleon

Bonaparte. In order to improve the country’s defences, volunteer regiments were raised in many counties from yeomen.



The word ‘yeoman’ refers to small farmers who owned the land they cultivated, but the officers were drawn from the nobility and many

of the men were their tenants. Yeomen were not obliged to serve overseas without their individual consent.



During the first half of the 19th century, Yeomanry Regiments were used extensively in support of the civil authority to suppress riots

and civil disturbances (including the Peterloo Massacre), but as police forces took over this role, the Yeomanry concentrated on local

defence. During the Boer War, companies of The Imperial Yeomanry were formed from volunteers from the Yeomanry to serve

overseas. In 1908, the Yeomanry became part of the Territorial Army.

name: YMCA Memorial
description:
The YMCA is an international Christian movement. The memorial is dedicated to all those who, through the YMCA, served the Armed

Forces in times of war and peace, some of whom gave their lives in the service of others.

name: M-211 Stirling X9-Y, 299 Squadron Memorial
description:
299 Squadron (Special Operations Service) Royal Air Force WW2

Memorial plaque is on a stone situated in the Special Operation Garden close to the Vera Atkins

memorial.



299 Squadron RAF Memorial - Special Operations Flights – Stirling X9-Y (Worry!).

Remarkably these lads, listed below, survived the war as well as all their hazardous missions: PO Bert

Horan, WO Jack Fry, WO Basil Jaggard, WO Reg Lowmanbaker, WO Maurice Davis & WO Gus Tyers.

This crew also participated in Operation Market Garden at Arnhem (September 1944) and Operation

Varsity (The Rhine Crossing) on 19th March 1945.



This memorial was contributed by WO Maurice Davis in 2006.



The 299 Squadron Motto 'Par Nobile Fratrum' (A noble group of brothers) symbolises the close

association with the Army Airborne Forces.



Behind the memorial is a Red Oak Tree which was grown from an acorn found in Oosterbeek

Cemetery!

name: M-212 The Dieppe Raid -18/19th August 1942- 'Operation Jubilee'
description:
Commemorating the 65th Anniversary, 18th August 2007



On August 18th 1942 more than 6,000 Allied soldiers, of whom almost 5,000 were Canadian sailed

from the south coast of Britain to attack the German held French Port of Dieppe.



The Dieppe Raid was called a 'Reconnaissance in Force' by the Combined Operations planners, and

was intended to be both a morale booster when the early stages of the war were going badly for the

Allies, and as a testing ground for a full scale invasion of Fortress Europe, along with an opportunity

to gain vital intelligence.



The Dieppe Raid turned out to be a military disaster, where nothing was achieved and about 60% of

the 5,000 soldiers who eventually landed ashore were killed, wounded or captured.



The Dieppe Raid Memorial, located in the Allied Special Forces Memorial Grove, remembers over

42,000 Canadians who lost their lives during WW2 with over 900 during the raid.



A second plaque honours Lt. Col. C. Merritt of the South Saskatchewan Regiment, John Foote of the

Canadian Chaplains Service and Capt. Patrick Porteus of No.4 Commando. All of which received the

Victoria Cross for their bravery. The scale of the Ground, Naval and Air Force losses are detailed here

and an accompanying plaque lists all the forces that participated in 'Operation Jubilee'.



The lessons learnt led to the successful invasion on June 6th 1944.



The memorial design was by Mike Colton who also helped dig the Old Red Sandstone out from a

quarry at Consall Hall and transport it to the site. The stone represents the formidable defences of

Dieppe.



Dedicated in 2007.

name: M-213 Popski’s Private Army
description:
Popski’s Private Army was founded by Major Vladimir Peniakoff in Cairo in October 1942. On 10

December 1942, it became officially operational as “No. 1 Demolition Squadron, PPA” an 8th Army

Special Forces unit formed specifically to attack Field-Marshal Rommel’s fuel supplies, in support of

General Montgomery’s offensive at El Alamein.



The squadron, which also served in Italy, was disbanded in September 1945 as well as the Long

Range Desert Group (LRDG) and the Special Air Service (SAS), PPA was the last and smallest of the

three main irregular raiding, reconnaissance and intelligence units formed during the North African

Campaign.



The stone built memorial is a truncated pyramid topped with the PPA astrolabe unit symbol

replicated from Popski’s original design which is also echoed in the shape of the surrounding low

hedge. The variegated laurel hedge represents the yellow of the deserts of North Africa and the

greenery of Italy.



Commemorative plaques feature on all four faces of the memorial. The front displays a small plaque

showing PPA's astrolabe cap badge, a small plaque commemorating the unveiling on 30 March 2008

(Popski's Birthday), together with the PPA Roll of Honour. To the rear PPA Honours and Awards are

listed. The right-hand plaque commemorates the 27th Lancers and all the units who comprised

"Porterforce" with the Italian Partisans commemorated on the left-hand plaque.



In 2010, two plaques telling the story Popski's Private Army were added to the memorial’s entrance.



The design of the hedge around the memorial was by Mike Colton.



Dedicated in 2008.



Note: - All the plaques are undergoing refurbishment. (19/2/23)

name: M-214 The Battle of Mirbat Memorial
description:
The Battle of Mirbat memorial commemorates a conflict, codenamed 'Operation STORM', which

took place between 1970-1975 in the Dhofar Province of Southern Oman.



Soldiers from 22 Special Air Service (SAS) Regiment were deployed under the guise of a British Army

Training Team (commonly known as BATT Men). The SAS objective was to help the armed forces of

Oman win the battle on the Jebel of Dhofar and so deliver the Province from armed communists

working from bases in South Yemen.



At dawn on the 19th July 1972 a nine man BATT team under the command of Mike Kealy were

"stood to" in their gun positions at the ancient capital port of Dhofar called Mirbat.



They came under attack by over 250 communist fighters. As the battle intensified Talaiasi Lablaba, a

Fijian was firing the 25-pounder field gun directly at the enemy forces who were only yards away

from the gun pit. Walid Khamis of the Omani gun team and Sekonaia Takevesi another Fijian had

been seriously wounded.



Tommy Tobin the medic was tending to them when he was shot in the jaw, a wound that was to

later to prove fatal. Labalaba was shot in the neck whilst trying to retrieve a mortar nearby.



The defence of the gun pit was taken over by Mike Kealy and Takavesi until about two hours later a relief

force of fighter planes and helicopter borne soldiers of 22 SAS arrived to rout the enemy.



This battle turned the tide of war to victory.



The memorial was dedicated on the 19th July 2009.



The memorial plaque was designed by Mike Colton.



Dedicated in 2009.

name: M-257 Vera Atkins and the women of "F" section (French)
description:
Special Operations Executive



Born in Romania in 1908, Vera Maria Atkins (née Rosenburg) was one of five children and the only

daughter of a wealthy German-Jewish businessman. Adopting the surname ‘Atkins’ (an Anglicised

version of her Jewish mother’s maiden name “Etkins”), she came to Britain in the late 1930s to

escape the threatening political situation in Europe and the growing extremism and antisemitism

developing in Romania.



Vera was recrutied by the Special Operations Executive and given special responsibility to the

women agents who were being sent into occupied France to act as couriers, radio operators and to

help train the resistance forces.



After the war she went back into Europe to find out what had happened to her women agents who

did not return and found that 12 of them had been captured and executed in German Concentration

Camps.



She is remembered as a resourceful, forthright woman whose special diplomacy and negotiation

skills provided much needed intelligence during the Second World War. Before her death in 2000

(age 92), Atkins was appointed CBE in the 1997 Birthday Honours. She was previously awarded the

Croix de Guerre in 1948 and made a Knight of the Legion of Honour by the French government in

1995.



Located in the Allied Special Forces Memorial Grove is a memorial dedicated to Vera Atkins,

Intelligence Officer of "F" section (French) - Special Operations Executive.



The geometric shape of the seat is a Hexagram with the inner line being a Hexagon. The Hexagram

has been a design used in all religions. This is built around a Pine Tree grown from a seed found in a

cone at Natzweiler Concentration Camp in the Vosges mountains of Eastern France.



The memorial was unveiled by Baroness Crawley, Baroness Verma, Colonel Nicholas Chambaz and

Zenna Atkins on the 24 September 2011.



This memorial was designed and constructed by Mike Colton.



Dedicated in 2011.



NOTE: - Six small information plaques are currently being manufactured. (19/2/23)



(The original memorial plaques have been relocated into the Sun Room.)

name: M-271 The Sun Room
description:
The Sun Room building at the heart of the Allied Special Forces Memorial Grove, has fine views

down each avenue. It is reached by a memorial way, which gently meanders past the memorials,

trees and shrubs. It is also just yards from the main roadway beside the River Tame.



The Sun Room constructed in 2011/2 was paid for by the people who's names are carved into the

French Oak frame and by a very generous donation from the office of the Sultanate of Oman in

London.



The Sun Room is dedicated to Flt. Lt. Jack Hesmondhalgh who was a RAF Radio operator and Rear

Gunner during WW2 and became the Chairman of the then Allied Special Forces Association for over

ten years.



Within the Sun Room are many memorials and in particular to soldiers of 22 SAS Regiment lost in

conflict and those that gently marched away. Here you will find the memorial to all the SAS soldiers

who lost their lives in the helicopter crash on the 19th May 1982 during the Falklands Conflict.



The Oak Frame was designed and installed by Oakwrights of Herefordshire with members of the

Friends of the Grove completing all the other construction work.



Opened in 2013 by Ian Dudson, Lord Lieutenant of Staffordshire..

name: M-286 624 (Special Duties) Squadron RAF
description:
This squadron was formed in September 1943 and carried out Special Duties Operations into Greece,

Romania, Albania, Italy, Corsica, Sardinia, Southern France, Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia. They

dropped agents and supplies to partisans and resistance forces and operated from Algeria, Tunisia,

Libya and Italy.



The squadron was disbanded in September 1944.



The memorial, Established in 2012, was instigated by Ron McKeon who has a plaque in the Sun

Room and is supported by members of the 4624 Royal Auxiliary Air Force and 624 Veterans. The

memorial is located in the Special Operations Garden opposite the 299 Squadron Stone and close to

the Vera Atkins memorial seat.

name: M-297 Moussey Memorial Seat
description:
During the Second World War the Croix de Lorraine (Cross of Lorraine) became an enduring symbol

of the Free French Forces and the French Resistance.



The memorial seat, which is shaped like the Cross of Lorraine and set amongst pine trees from a

Forest Guard’s cottage garden in the Vosges Moutain, which were brought over by friends from

Moussey.The seat is made from sawn timber representing the work in the forests above the “Little

Mountain Village”.



It honours the communities of Moussey and the Rabodeau Valley who resisted the invader and

suffered at the hands of the occupying forces because they would not betray the Special Air Service

soldiers operating in the mountains above Moussey during 'Operation Loyton'.



The memorial is orientated towards Moussey at an angle of 130 degrees. It is a distance of 587 miles

(944 km) by road from the National Memorial Arboretum.



This memorial is linked to the Phantom Memorial Garden located beside the Aspects Centre



This memorial was designed by Mike Colton.



Dedicated in 2013.

name: M-298 Sergeant Phil Curass
description:
This memorial is dedicated to Staff Sergeant Philip Preston Curass QGM who died on active service in

The Falklands conflict on 19 May 1982. It comprises a modern stainless steel sundial set on a piece of

stone from Old Radnor Quarry.



The sundial is inscribed with the following dedication:



Phil joined D Squadron 22 SAS in 1972 from the Royal Army Medical Corps. He completed

operational tours in Dhofar (Oman) and in Northern Ireland. In 1979 he was awarded the Queen’s

Gallantry Medal. During the Falklands War he helped liberate South Georgia and raided Pebble

Island to destroy enemy aircraft. Phil lost his life during a ship to ship transfer prior to carrying out a

diversionary raid near Goose Green.



Husband, Father, Brother, Son and Soldier. dearly loved and sorely missed by his family.



“There are moments when I wish I could roll back the clock and take all the sadness away, but I have

the feeling that if I did, the joy would be gone as well.” Nicholas Sparks



Lost in the South Atlantic 19th May 1982.



On the top right of the sundial an arrow points in the direction of Pebble Island (some 7934 miles

from this location).



M-307 Royal Marine Boom Patrol Detachment



"Operation Frankton"

name: "The Cockleshell Heroes"
description:
Located in the Allied Special Forces Memorial Grove is a seat in the shape of a Canoe which

commemorates the men of Royal Marine Boom Patrol Detachment – later known as the “Cockleshell

Heroes”.



On the night of 7 December 1942, ten Royal Marine Commandos climbed out of the submarine

“HMS Tuna” and were launched into five two-man canoes. Their destination was Bordeaux Harbour

and their mission was to destroy as many ships as possible using limpet mines which attach below

the water line.



This audacious raid was a success. However, some marines were lost in the icy cold waters of the

Gironde estuary on the route in, and others were captured and executed by the Germans. Only two

Marines survived the mission.



The memorial comprises a wooden seat in the symbolic shape of a 15ft. by 2ft. 6in. Cockle Mark II

canoe, as used by the Royal Marines during "Operation Frankton" in 1942.



This seat and the two memorial plaques commemorate the Royal Marines who took part and the



French civilians who assisted them during their attempted escape after the successful raid.



Behind the canoe is a large metal relief picture of the Marines leaving HMS Tuna which was a

practice casting before the Bronze Memorial which sits at the 'Cockleshell Heroes' memorial at St.

Genes de Blaye in France was made.



This memorial garden was designed by Mike Colton.



Dedicated in 2014.

name: M-334 Pegasus Bridge Memorial Flight
description:
'Operation Deadstick'



On D-Day 6th June 1944 six Horsa Gliders were released by Halifax pilots of 298 and 644 Squadrons

Royal Air Force.



Gliding down over enemy territory in complete darkness the crews of the Glider Pilot Regiment

crash landed 5 of the Gliders very close to the bridges over the Orne River and Caen Canal. Glider

No. 4 landed by a bridge over the River Dives about 10 miles away.



Capture of these bridges was vital to defending the D-Day landing beaches in Normandy to the North

and the Airborne Forces drop zones to the East in the vicinity of Ranville.



The operation was planned by Major John Howard and the successful assault by soldiers from the

2nd. Battalion Oxfordshire & Buckinghamshire Light Infantry who were supported by the Royal

Engineers, Royal Army Medical Corps and a 7 Para liaison officer.



The 5 metre high memorial depicts three stylised Horsa gliders spiralling down on a giant letter 'S'

representing this Secret operation that was carried out in Silence, using Speed, Stealth and achieved

complete Surprise.



The concept of the memorial was by Mike Colton and the memorial brought to life by Bromley

O'Hare, Blacksmith/Artisan with the sides left open to indicate that the Gliders were frail craft!



Memorial Established 2018
